column2: It's nice doing business with the Off-Track Betting Corporation they keep you up with what they're doing.
Billy Casper and Shirley Englehorn were named yesterday as winners of Golf Digest magazine's awards to the golfers with the most tournament victories of the year.

President Nixon's veto of the manpower bill is an expression of executive inflexibility that will disadvantage both the unemployed and the cities that could use their services in productive public jobs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) A new outburst of guerrilla terrorism in the Ethiopian province of Eritrea has sent thousands of women and children fleeing into neighboring Sudan within the last two months.

Dr. Jeremiah Stamler, who describes himself as "a meat loaf maven," yesterday offered his low-fat, low cholesterol recipe for this and other dishes to Americans who want to preserve their arteries and prevent premature heart attacks.
Those eight-foot-long contraptions in the streets that look like chimney pipes belching steam into the frosty air are safety devices.
DETROIT, Dec. 17 The automobile industry is gearing up to produce 2.6 million cars for the first quarter next year, which would be a record for the three months.

The sole defense witness on behalf of a man accused of setting fire to a neighbor's luxury apartment on the Upper East Side testified yesterday that the defendant had summoned firemen to put out the flames.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 President Nixon and Prime Minister Heath of Great Britain called today for the resumption of Arab-Israel peace talks "as soon as possible" under the auspices of Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations intermediary.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 17 Two Block Island authors were indicted today and then pleaded not guilty in United States District Court to charges of harboring the Rev. Daniel Berrigan at their island home last August when he was evading a three-year sentence and destroying draft records.

After two half-hour conference calls among New York, Detroit and Dallas, plus several other calls of varying lengths between Detroit and Dallas between New York and Chicago and between Park Avenue and Columbus Circle, the National Football League finally has figured out how to flip a coin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 The State Department warned American citizens today against unnecessary travel to Poland because of the "uncertain situation" there as the impression grew here that the initial economic protest was turning into a major political crisis for the Polish Government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 The Union Carbide Corporation received five patents this week on its Unox pureoxygen process for the treatment of sewage.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 The Air Force selected today two companies to build competitive prototypes of a new twin-engine craft to provide battlefield support to Army troops.

DALLAS, Dec. 18 Miss Nancy Bennett, daughter of King Wade Bennett, executive vice president of Macy's, New York, and Mrs. Bennett of New York and Summit, N.J., was married here this afternoon to William David Feniger. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Yale Feniger of Toledo, Ohio.
Willie McCovey of the San Francisco Giants is slugging his way into the record book as one of the greatest power hitters in National League history.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 18 (AP) A two-story Nativity scene that had graced a public playground here for 21 years was destroyed last night in a fire the police say was set.
Frank Marshall's Silver Isle will seek her fourth consecutive victory, and her first in a stakes race, in the $20,000added Saratoga Stakes at Bay Meadows race track in California today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) A winner of the Nobel Prize for Medicine, and three other Government researchers have suggested that habitual marijuana users, unlike heavy drinkers and those on hard drugs, may develop a "reverse tolerance" requiring smaller and smaller doses to produce highs.

Gov. Lester Maddox of Georgia walked out of a taping of the Dick Cavett Show in a huff last night after demanding that the host of the program apologize for a remark about Mr. Maddox's white supporters.

Major clinical laboratories here have raised their prices on blood examinations and other medical tests by as much as 400 per cent in response to what they contend is the impact of a law lobbied through the State Lgislature as a consumer protection measure.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 A joint Senate-House conference committee completed work today on legislation establishing, for the first time, a system of insurance for investors against financial losses resulting from the bankruptcies of brokerage firms. Losses of up to $50,000 per customeraccount would be insured under the legislation.
An American Airlines 747 with 121 passengers and a crew of 17 made a safe emergency landing at Kennedy International Airport yesterday after trouble developed in the landing gear.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (UPI) A former Army intelligence agent, John O'Brien, said today he revealed that he had spied on prominent politicians because he believed "unknowing people" should be aware of what he called a "menace" to civil liberties.

John D. Rockefeller 3d announced survey results yesterday that indicated the nation's top business leaders were just as ready to work with young people on finding solutions to society's problems as youths were to work with them
SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 18 The New York University basketball team lost to the University of Utah, 103-67, in the opening round of the Utah Classic tonight.

PARTIES Local 553 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, representing 2,200 oil truck drivers and 600 oil burner repairmen, and the New York Oil Heating Association, representing 300 independent companies that serve 40 per cent of the city's homes and businesses using fuel oil.
If you are like most laymen, you take comfort in the belief that doctors of medicine are closely regulated by stringent laws, rigorous government agencies and exacting professional groups.
BERLIN, Dec. 18 East Germany, clearly worried about the rioting in Poland, accused American and West German radio stations today of fomenting unrest among Polish workers, students and housewives.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Dec. 14 A commission appointed by President Nixon is here studying the ways in which the United States can help Jamaica remain politically stable and be a safe place for foreign investment.
David. B. Mulligan Jr., a hotel manager for many years, died Wednesday in Miami Beach, Fla., after a long illness. His age was 53.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Following is a summary of the recommendations sent to the President today by the White House Conference on Children:
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 18 (UPI) There's one college football game that may attract the biggest crowd of them all, more than the Rose Bowl, the Cotton Bowl and the Orange Bowl.

C. Cheever Hardwick, who retired as vice chairman of the investment banking firm of Smith, Barney Co., Inc., in 1968, died yesterday at his home, 825 Fifth Avenue, after a long illness. His age was 66.

A commuter from Allendale, N.J., riding his bus at 9 A.M. yesterday, was amazed when the realized it was speeding past trucks and automobiles inching along as usual on the New Jessey approach to the Lincoln Tunnel.
WALTHAM, Mass., Dec. 18 (AP) Charles I. Schottland, who has served as acting president of Brandeis University the last 10 months, was named the university's third president today.
A funny thing happened to the stock market yesterday on the way to the close: the underlying tone was firm and there were more advances than declines but the averages barely budged off dead center.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 18 (AP) Jim Ninowski, a former pro football quarterback, said today his pay was increased to $100,000 a year for four years as a result of a secret settlement reached in 1967 after he threatened the National and American leagues with an antitrust suit.

The Rev. Dr. John M. Krumm, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Ascension at Fifth Avenue and 10th Street since 1965 and former chaplain of Columbia University, has been elected Bishop of the Diocese of Southern Ohio.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 18 A three-judge Federal Court panel has blocked an Indiana recount in the re-election of United States Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana.
MUNDELEIN, Ill., Dec. 18 A private conference of Roman Catholic Bishops ended this afternoon with a rededication to the principle of parochial education.
Another day, another birthday concert, this time not in honor of you-know-whom (a moratorium on that name is now in force).

HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 18 The United States and the Soviet Union recessed the strategic arms limitation talks here today after seven weeks of discussions, which apparently clarified some issues but which failed to make any substantial progress toward an agreement. The two sides agreed to resume the talks next March 15 in Vienna.
The militant Jewish Defense League was barred by court order yesterday with interfering with the fund-raising activities of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.
The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations issued a report in Washington yesterday calling the multibillion-dollar F-111 fighter-bomber program a "fiscal blunder of the worst magnitude."

NASHVILLE, Dec. 18 Unbeaten St. John's University opened the eighth annual Vanderbilt invitation basketball tournament tonight with a 9580 victory over Southern Methodist University, its fifth of the season.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (AP) Roy M. Cohn and another man were freed today of charges they had violated Illinois law by controlling more than 15 per cent of the shares in each of two banks through a holding company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

Mohawk Airlines, Inc., which has been tied up by a strike and is experiencing financial problems, announced yesterday that the Jet Capital Corporation, a New York financial services company, will assist the company in developing a program for obtaining new capital funds and restructuring existing credit arrangements.
The 3-month-old son of a New York fireman was kidnapped from his carriage yesterday on a busy Brooklyn street while his mother was in a store Christmas shopping.

The Greater New York Bridge Association traditionally introduces new forms of competition at its December tournament. Today at the New York Hilton, enthusiasts in the metropolitan area will have their first opportunity to take part in a "Swiss pairs."
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its board of governors had severely disciplined a former allied member of the exchange and two securities salesmen for violating regulations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 The White House Conference on Children ended today with 24 recommendations for President Nixon to act on, topped by more than a dozen "overriding concerns" voted on by delegates from across the nation.

HONG KONG, Dec. 18 (UPI) The Hong Kong Government has reached an agreement with the United States on voluntary restriction of textile exports to America, the Commerce and Industry Department announced today.

BONN, Dec. 18 "It happened on the street right in front of the burning party headquarters in Szczecin. Tanks moved against the population to give them a shock. The people fled to avoid being run over, but a mother and her child were unable to make it. An oncoming tank struck both of them. A young soldier, standing nearby and watching, broke into tears."
Prices moved in a narrow range yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as the list ended slightly higher on moderate trading.
Negotiators for the striking taxi union and the fleet owners resumed talks yesterday, but there were no indications of significant progress toward a settlement of the two-week-old walkout.
BETHEL, Conn., Dec. 18 Walter L. Lowry, an airplane executive and consultant, was killed in a plane crash today near Henryville, Ind. He was 4l years old and lived here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Trying to break an end-of-session impasse, the Senate met for an hour and a half behind closed doors tonight without resolving any of the tangled issues that plague it.

Federal Judge Milton Pollack signed a temporary restraining order last night enjoining members of the drivers union and its officers from refusing to perform their normal delivery duties at The New York Times.
American silver is a lot easier to understand after a view of selections from the Garvan Collection now on exhibition at the Yale Art Gallery in New Haven.

LONDON, Dec. 18 A spell seems to fall over New Yorkers who visit London a mood of enchantment with the serene tempo of life, the quiet streets, the clean air, the ambience of a city where a brisk afternoon walk may encompass the extraordinary amalgam of bustling Covent Garden, trendy King's ...

A sunny street in Algiers, March 26, 1962. Young Moslem troops under French command, with no crowd-handling experience, suddenly panic when faced by civilian demonstrators and commence firing without orders into the crowd. When someone cries out, "Stop shooting! We're not armed!" two soldiers spin around and fire automatically in the direction the voice came from.

The New York Knickerbockers, who have been almost unbeatable in Madison Square Garden, will face the Chicago Bulls tonight but without the services of their leading scorer, rebounder and captain, Willis Reed.
LONDON, Dec. 18 For those in the West who have let the facts fade from their understanding, the riots in Poland are a sharp reminder of the character of the regimes of Eastern Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has recommended closing eight Public Health Service hospitals, including a large facility on Staten Island, Representative Paul G. Rogers, Democrat of Florida, said today.

"We can't keep these Benin bronzes in stock they sell too quickly," Prince Thomas said recently of the Nigerian sculptures. His good-natured dissatisfaction made the owner of IMPORT ant AFRICA Ltd., 228 East 80th Street, sound like a seasoned merchant. But it was only last month that Mr. Thomas assumed complete command of the basement emporium where old and new African crafts, clothing, jewelry and furnishings are sold.
A 73-year-old Russian count was held captive in his Fifth Avenue apartment for eight hours Thursday night and yesterday while two intruders ransacked the apartment.
The Waltham Industries Corporation disclosed yesterday that it had been holding discussions this week with its major creditors about a Waltham proposal for restructuring its debt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) The Senate passed tonight a compromise $2.9-billion housing bill containing increased Federal aid for new towns as part of a broad attack on problems of urban growth. The voice vote sent the measure to the House.
NELLIS AIR FORCE BASE, Nev., Dec. 18 A suggestion emerged tonight that Howard Hughes may have left Las Vegas on a stretcher.
When Public School 106 put on its annual Christmas play yesterday morning, the tension in the audience was caused by more than the plot, which threatened a Christmas without Santa Claus.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) The Senate Commerce Committee today approved a $125-million loan guarantee for the Penn Central Railroad. The measure is identical to a House Commerce Committee bill approved earlier this week.
Bob Cousy, Bill Sharman and Sam Jones, three players who were stars with the Boston Celtics, were named yesterday to the National Basketball Association silver anniversary team.

WEST ORANGE, N.J. Dec. 18 Solkind L. Levenson, a lawyer in New Jersey and New York, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital, Newark of cancer. He was 66 years old and lived at 115 Old Short Hills Road here.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 18 Harvard University is on the verge of appointing its 25th president after what has been perhaps the most exhaustive search ever conducted for a college president.

Most of the music being presented in Christmas programs in churches this season is traditional, but at the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation tomorrow a more modern sound will be heard, Richard Felciano's "God of the Expanding Universe" will be performed, and it is a work for electronic tape and organ.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation, the largest domestic producer of copper, formally recognized yesterday the unprofitability of its molybdenumproducing subsidiary in Canada.
Four men prominent in the field of aviation have been honored in ceremonies held at the viation Hall of Fame at Dayton, Ohio.
Six Criminal Court judges whose terms expire at the end of the year were reappointed and sworn in yesterday by Mayor Lindsay at City Hall.
Szczecin, the scene of violent demonstrations, is an important Polish port and one of the oldest towns on the Baltic coast.

VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 18 A strong French team accustomed to training on difficult courses is favored to win the women's downhill event tomorrow in the second international meet of the World Cup skiing competition.
Police corruption does more than protect illegal gambling, prostitution and narcotics enterprises. It helps to breed and intensify each of these evils.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration said today, a week before Christmas, that it was banning four classes of toys from the market as hazardous, but it refused to identfy them by brand name or to say how they would be removed from stores.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 19 In tomorrow's season finale with the Baltimore Colts, the New York Jets' defensive unit hopes to maintain its honor as the American Conference leader. According to Larry Grantham, the experienced linebacker who calls defensive signals, the Colts must be held to about 200 yards.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) Prospects for 1970 corn production improved slightly in November and output now is estimated at 4,109,792,000 bushels, the Agriculture Department announced today.

In 1874, the Oratorio Society of New York began its now traditional Christmas season performances of Handel's "Messiah." The venerable singing organization is now in its 98th season, but Thursday night, at Carnegie Hall, it gave its 148th performance of the work.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 18 (AP) The National Farmers Organization today selected Oren Lee Staley as its president for his 16th consecutive term.
SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Dec. 18 (AP) Svetlana Alliluyeva Peters, Stalin's daughter, confirmed through a spokesman today that she was expecting a baby.

The National Center for Health-Statistics has recently released the first comprehensive and reliable data on operations performed in the United States. Considering the fact that more than half of hospital admissions are surgical, this kind of information is long overdue. And, of course, such data are essential if we are to begin to plan, as we must, for comprehersive medical care on a national scale.
The Rev. Dr. Miles Mark Fisher, pastor emeritus of White Rock Baptist Church, Durham, N.C., and author of "Negro Slave Songs in the United States," died Monday in Richmond, Va., at the age of 71.

The western region of Poland, the scene of this week's riots, was gained by Poland at the close of World War II. Before the war the area was part of Germany, and its cities had German names Szczecin was Stettin, Wroclaw was Breslau.

DENVER, Dec. 18 A Colorado environmental scientist who has mounted repeated protests against nuclear testing and the handling of armaments filed suit in Federal Court here yesterday to block a nuclear rocket test that is scheduled for January in Nevada.

Stockholders of the LFC Financial Corporation and the Great Western Financial Corporation, at separate meetings yesterday, voted in favor of an agreement to merge LFC into Great Western. The combination of the two savings and loan companies, which must be effected by Dec. 31, will create ...
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that his office was investigating abortion referral services in the state as the result of complaints from several out-ofstate women.
The General Electric Company's board of directors played Santa Claus yesterday for the company's 520,000 stockholders by approving plans for a 2-for-1 stock split.
Two cousins, 82 and 75 years old, were found bound, gagged and stabbed to death in their beds yesterday evening in the apartment the two men shared in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I, Dec. 18(AP) Mel Daniels led the Indiana Pacers to a 129-117 victory over New York tonight in an American Basketball Association game in which Rick Barry of the Nets was ejected.

STONINGTON, Conn. When Behri Knauth needs fresh lobster or an extra ingredient or two for her cooking, she hops on her French bicycle and pedals the few blocks to the wharfside fish market or to the general store in this picturesque fishing village about 150 miles from New York.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Heeding demands of young reformers, a special House Democratic panel proposed today that seniority not be the sole basis for the selection of committee chairmen.

The millions of Americans who have waited long hours to see a physician or who have tried in vain to get one to make a house call will no doubt welcome the recommendation of the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education for a 50 per cent increase in medical school enrollment. Before we swallow this medication whole, however, it would be wise to consider what it will and will not accomplish.
MERCURY, Nev., Dec. 18 About 600 workers were evacuated from the Nevada nuclear test site today after an underground nuclear test blew a cloud of radioactive dust 8,000 feet in the air.
PRAGUE, Dec. 18 (Reuters) A 28-year-old United States student was sentenced to four years in prison here today because he had once worked for Radio Free Europe.
Police Commnissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that the department would expand an experimental plainclothes patrol that he credited with combating street crime.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 18 Compania Swift de la Plata, the Argentine subsidiary of Deltec International, Ltd., declared itself insolvent today after executives decided that the company, Argentina's major privately owned meat packing company, cannot continue to sustain heavy losses.
LAFAYETTE, La., Dec. 18 (AP) Oklahoma State moved to an early lead tonight and went on to defeat Connecticut 80-64, in the Bayou Classic.

The Metropolitan Opera House will revive Strauss's "Die Frau ohne Schatten" during the l8th week of its current season in a non-subscription matinee to be given on Jan. 16. The opera was last given here in the 1968-69 season.

A State Supreme Court judge rejected the city's request for an immediate stay of the fueloil strike yesterday despite pleas from city officials that the walkout had created health and housing emergencies.

The Leasco Data Processing Equipment Corporation reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 a net loss of $30,804,000 in contrast to a net income of $43,928,000, or $4.77 a share, in fiscal 1969.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 18 (AP) Lew Alcindor broke out of a brief scoring slump with a 40point effort to lead the Milwaukee Bucks from a 109-109 tie to a 124-114 National Basketball Association victory over the Boston Celtics tonight.

Angela Davis lost two bids yesterday to have her extradition to California blocked but the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit postponed her return to the West Coast, pending appeal to the Supreme Court.

The beauty salon at Saks Fifth Avenue looks like a disaster area these days, but that's not deterring women from going there to be beautified. The salon is getting a major face lift the store hopes that remodeling will be finished by the middle of February and most of the ...

WARSAW, Dec. 18 Tension began to rise in Warsaw tonight as reports continued to reach here of anti-Government clashes in other Polish cities. Some areas of the country were still sealed off today, on the fifth day of unrest.

ALSDORF, West Germany, Dec. 18 West Germany's thalidomide trial was discontinued today after two and a half years under a compromise settlement providing some compensation for those who are believed to have been victims of the sedative.

The London stock market closed slightly higher yesterday in quiet trading. Some buying of leading issues was stimulated by Wall Street's Thursday gain after a steady start pushed prices up, but volume remained depressed and special situations provided most of the trading activity.
The director of Maternity and Newborn Services for the city's Department of Health said yesterday that 26 fetuses had remained alive after legal abortions in the city since July.
TRENTON, Dec. 18 A $50million aid and tax package aimed at staving off municipal bankruptcy in Newark was given final legislative approval in the New Jersey State Senate today.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced yesterday that it would send a group to West Germany to investigate racial conflicts and charges of racial discrimination against black American soldiers.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, Dec. 18 (AP) Fifteen persons died and 200 were injured today in a fire that swept through a large section of the sprawling Volkswagen do Brasil plant here, the police said.

The holiday party whirl for debutantes was set spinning last night with a series of 28 dinner parties and one supper dance for 400, all in honor of Miss Melissa Carr Leib, back home for Christmas from Sweet Briar College.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, who is ending a 24year Senate career, was described today as "the conscience of the Senate" by his colleagues.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 19 (AP) Two enemy rockets crashed into Saigon early today, reportedly killing six South Vietnamese and wounding eight.

Peter Fuller, who bought his way into thoroughbred racing, has always considered himself an "outsider" in the sport, or at least an "independent." He made few concessions to the genteel plantation image: when his horse, Dancer's Image, won the 1968 Governor's Gold Cup in Bowie, Md., Fuller publicly donated the $62,000 purse to further the work of Dr. Martin Luther King, who had been murdered several days before the race.
A Staten Island ferryboat rammed its Manhattan slip yesterday morning, injuring scores of passengers who were knocked off their feet.
Members of the City Council raised sharp questions yesterday about a key provision of the tough air-pollution code proposed by the Lindsay Administration.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17 Downtown department stores here are open at night and are even open on Sundays during the holiday season. But the joy of the season has not yet pealed at the cash registers.
Reports circulated yesterday that Curt Flood had made "handshake agreements" with the Washington Senators that would circumvent the reserve clause which Flood has been challenging in court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 An important lesson for foreign countries and for American students and practitioners of foreign policy is being taught in the Senate in the waning days of 1970. The lesson is actually twofold.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Dec. 18 Oliver W. Larkin, professor emeritus of art at Smith College who won a Pulitzer Prize for history for 1949 with his book, "Art and Life in America," died yesterday in Smith College Infirmary after a long illness. He was 74 years old.
"To understand Poland," Eastern Europeans have said, "understand Gomulka."
Investors Overseas Services Ltd., and Gramco Management, Ltd., the two leading offshore mutual-fund organizations in the world, decided last night to break off merger talks.
Jim Webb, the popular young song writer, has decided to start a singing career and he is making his New York debut through Monday at the Bitter End, 147 Bleecker Street.

TOKYO, Dec. 18 A timehonored Japanese rite kaishaku, slashing off the head of a friend who has committed hare-kiri will be judged according to this country's, modern, Western-inspired criminal code for the first time when three of Yukio Mishima's followers are brought to trial early next year.

Only last week, Peter Maxwell-Davies's exciting "Eight Songs for a Mad King" had its New York premiere. And now we have George Crumb's "Ancient Voices of Children," which was heard at the Contemporary Chamber Ensemble concert at the Hunter College Playhouse on Thursday evening.
HARTFORD, Dec. 18 (UPI) A widower who is receiving welfare and who won $100,000 yesterday in the New York state lattery, said he would return with his four children to Puerto Rico.

The New York City Central Labor Council urged yesterday that the City Council reject Mayor Lindsay's proposal for compulsory arbitration in any contract impasse in negotiations between the city and the unions representing its employes.
MOSCOW, Dec. 18 (UPI) The Soviet Government has decided to call a conference of Baltic powers to discuss pollution of the Baltic Sea, Scandinavian diplomatic sources report.

Much has been said about the $25,000-a-man prize at the end of the Super Bowl rainbow, but for the New York Giant players who face the Los Angeles Rams tomorrow, the stakes are really much bigger and more immediate.
Sales volume of leading chain-store organizations in November rose 7.4 per cent compared to the level of sales in November, 1969, according to a survey by The New York Times.

TRENTON, Dec. 18 (AP) The State Senate today passed and sent to Gov. William T. Cahill a bill extending unemployment benefits an additional 13 weeks during periods of high unemployment. The vote was 30 to 0.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Prime Minister Heath said today that the "natural" relationship between the United States and Britain has lapsed in recent years.
ALGIERS, Dec. 18 (Agence France-Presse) Hundreds of students clashed with the police here today in a demonstration demanding the use of Arabic instead of French in high schools and universities.
The number of companies making first public offerings of stock picked up this week, but over-all activity remained only slightly above the low levels that have prevailed for most of 1970.

In 1961, the painting of Wojciech Fangor, who goes by the star-like name of Fangor, presumably because of the consonantal difficulties of his first name, was introduced to the American public by the Museum of Modern Art in a group exhibition entitled "15 Polish Painters."
The Board of Education vowed yesterday to tighten security measures in the city's public school system.
Does the new University of Michigan survey, which finds that consumers are still depressed and unwilling to spend, reflect actual attitudes or the General Motors strike?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today that he found nothing improper in certain statements made recently by J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Out of 3,000 artists represented in the permanent collection of the Whitney Museum of American Art, 450 are women, a showing of 15 per cent. Since the current population of this country contains a majority female representation of 53 per cent, we are entitled to one of several assumptions: (a) that ...

Herbert Kebeck, a 44-yearold former convict whose hatred for a neighbor apparently impelled him to set fire to the neighbor's luxury apartment on the Upper East Side, was found guilty yesterday of first-degree arson, assault and criminal mischief.
ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 18 The shooting of Larry Gordon and Bob Evans paced Columbia to a 67-58 victory over Cornell in the Ivy League opener for both teams tonight in Barton Hall.

MOSCOW, Dec. 18 (Reuters) A Soviet Jew accused of trying to hijack a Soviet plane and fly it abroad said in court that he planned the attempt because of anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union, informed sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Under Federal prodding, the nation's major soap manufacturers have agreed to remove from their detergent products a chemical that could be hazardous to humans, particularly pregnant women.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 18 (AP) Israel, the defending champion, advanced to the basketball final in the Asian Games today with an 83-78 victory over the Philippines.

At least 18 staff members, including its editor in chief and three senior editors, have been been discharged by the book division of the McCall Publishing Company as part of policy of economic retrenchment:

Karen Wyman, a small, button-nosed, black-haired, brighteyed, 18-year-old girl from the Bronx, is carving a niche of sorts at the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel as the youngest headliner in the room's 36-year history.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 The Army announced today detailed plans to destroy its biological and toxic weapons in accordance with pledges made by President Nixon. But the United States will continue research on defenses against weapons of this kind.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Dec 18 A special state grand jury indicted Hobart College in nearby Geneva today, charging that it had "recklessly" allowed two students and a professor to prevent the prosecution of students seized in a drug raid last June 5.

Rebounding from Thursday's drop, soybean and grain futures rose yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. There was a sharp rise early in the session but this was trimmed near the close by profit taking.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday that it had increased its prices by about 5 per cent on several types of Dacron polyester filament yarn for texturing, effective immediately.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 18 (AP) John Grover Bell, who founded Bonne Bell, Inc., in a one-room office here in 1927 and built it into an international cosmetics concern with sales of more than $20-million annually, died today in a suburban hospital. He was 80 years old and was chairman of the concern at his death.
CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (UPI) Harry J. Romanoff, a Chicago newspaperman from the days of "The Front page," died in Augustana Hospital today of a stroke suffered in October. He was 79 years old.

It is rare indeed when television contrives to make one think and succeeds at it. One is so used either to stimulation or to torpor from the tube. And it is unfortunate, but predictable, that such television, in most instances, will cause no critical ripples; will not arouse programers to think of seasonal renewals; nor cause much of a stir among masses of viewers, although it should.

Richard Anthony BromleyDavenport of London has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Antonia Bromley-Davenport of New York, to Basil Edward-Kaiser, son of Mr. and Mrs. David M. Keiser of New York and Wilton, Conn.

FAIRMONT, N.J., Dec. 19 The engagement of Miss Barbara Holmes Newman, a Vassar senior, to John Moorhead Trainer Jr., a student at Marietta College, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Allen Newman, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Trainer of Sewickley, Pa., and Muskoka, Ontario.

WARSAW "Citizens I am speaking to you at a serious time," said Polish Premier Jozef Cyrankiewicz last Thursday. "Hostile forces are endeavoring to create new seats of anarchy." The worst rioting since 1956 had erupted in at least three Polish cities, with 10 to 20 persons dead at that point, and hundreds injured.

SPRINAGAR, Kashmir, Dec. 19 The entire hemp crop grown this year on a wide area in Kashmir valley was destroyed as part of government campaign against an increase in the smuggling of hashish. About 30 Government officials were penalized for failing to prevent the cultivation of hemp.
Achievement tests given to public school pupils here earlier this year show that an increasing number of city youngsters in the intermediate grades have fallen behind national standards in reading.
LONDON, Dec. 19 (AP) A Royal Commission has recommended that London's third airport be built at Cublington, a village 50 miles northwest of the capital.

Miss Carol Ann Baker and Charles J. Seidler Jr. of New York, son of Mrs. Walter W. Plankinton of Tequesta, Fla., and the late Mr. Seidler of Bellerose, Queens, and Candlewood Isle, Conn., were married here yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Linda Dwight Taylor to Virgil Everett Barnes, associate professor of physics at Purdue University, took place in the Episcopal Church of the Resurrection here yesterday afternoon. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. Alan B. MacKillop, was followed by a reception at the Cosmopolitan Club.
Some automatic elevators might be death traps in a fire drawn by heat to the floor where the flames are raging.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) The Democratic National Chairman, Lawrence F. O'Brien, has named six members and four officers of the National Committee to recommend a site for the party's 1972 convention.

THE Guggenheim Museum has a surprise waiting for you if you are accustomed to thinking of Joaquin TorresGarcia as a minor but secure member of the constellation of artists who, with Picasso at the radiant center, lit the way to modern art. Minor he looks, without question, in this survey of his work. But secure? That becomes a question indeed.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 19 (AP) South Korea upset Israel, 81-67, the defending champion, for the basketball title and Japan increased its gold-medal lead with five more triumphs today at the sixth Asian Games.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 The Senate voted 48 to 43 today against forcing an end to the debate on the supersonic transport.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 In the Presbyterian Church of the Pilgrims here today, Miss Lavillon Elise Morrison was married to John Walter Gussenhoven by the Rev. Dr. John Randolph Taylor.

Mike Burton broke three world records in the national outdoor championships, but he didn't win a race. That's the kind of a year it was as Americans (and a few foreigners) battered the swimming record book.

MOSCOW Dec. 19 (AP) A Moscow weekly magazine tells how Tolya Meshcheryakov, a normal Soviet teen-ager from Tashkent, fell in with Crooked Apollo and his crowd of marijuana smokers. It is the first indication by the Soviet press that a drug problem has developed in the Soviet Union.

VIENNA, Dec. 19 (AP) A Prague court has sentenced three brothers to prison terms in the theft of a sheet of 80 rare Blue Mercury stamps issued by the former AustroHungarian empire and valued at more than $200,000.

PARIS While American mothers, Government officials and industry executives are just awakening to the necessity for day care centers, French working mothers have had a place to leave and educate their preschool children since 1887.

LAUREL, Md., Dec. 19 Dave Feldman's Sport King led all the way and scored an impressive 3 -length victory over Raymond Vogelman Jr.'s Count Judex in the $24,300 Monumental Handicap at Laurel race course today.
Broadway may soon find that it has another Fabulous Invalid not the Broadway stage but a clutch of impressive office skyscrapers with substantial space untenanted.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Dec. 19 The battle over oil production in the Santa Barbara Channel, where a huge leak erupted two years ago and brought a new public awareness of environmental problems, is still defying resolution by the nation's environmental "watchdogs."

The too-frequently expressed myth that symphony concerts are "white man's music" was exploded anew Friday night at the McMillin Theatre of Columbia University. The occasion was the debut of the Harlem Philharmonic Society, a training orchestra made up primarily of members of the black, Oriental and Spanish-speaking communities in New York, and devoted to finding, developing and displaying worthy minority-group talents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 This area's year-old effort to turn blueprints into real subways has run into difficulties that threaten to increase the project's eventual cost, but not kill it. "The question is not whether Washington will ever get a subway system built, but what the final cost will be in money and concessions," a Congressional source said yesterday.
The new drug rule passed by the American Horse Shows Association superseded the actual competition in the equine world in 1970.
VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 19 It was the same old story: The French won another Alpine ski race.
Taxi union negotiators and fleet owners reached tentative agreement yesterday on a new contract that could end the two-week-old cab strike today.

DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 19 Miss Susan Lapsley Persons, a graduate of Duke University, where she is assistant director of undergraduate admissions, was married this afternoon to Paul Anthony Robell, foundation relations officer in the Duke University Office of Development.
NEWARK, Dec. 19 The Central Railroad of New Jersey, a declining invalid in an era of ailing railroads, has been spared from death once again by another transfusion of state money.

EAST HILLS, L.I., Dec. 19 The engagement of Miss Margery Lee Gordon to Richard Kenneth Winters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Winters of Miami, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Monte Jeffrey Gordon.

EXHAUSTIVE attention has already been given to the variety of New Year's Eve entertain ment available to New Yorkers, but virtually nothing has been written about the exciting possibilities that await them on the morning after.

THE STAGNANT United States economy is beginning to stir slightly again from the stimulus of increased automotive and steel production, but consumer buying remains sluggish as the Christ mas season comes to a close. As a result, the ongoing debate about appropriate national economic policy continues to rage.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 19 Miss Susan Savier Perry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Merton Perry of Darien, was married here today to Allan Robert Pike, son of James George Pike of Lindenhurst, L.I., and the late Mrs. Pike.
PARIS, Dec. 19 The Rev. Marc Boegner, for several decades a leader of the Protestant Church in France, died at his home here last night at the age of 89.

BECAUSE of the peculiar timing of newspaper deadlines, this article will appear two days after a key part of the Washington Market urban renewal plan, 1,335 units of MitchellLama housing, has been presented to the Board of Estimate for approval of the tax abatement that the city must give for these "middle income" projects.

The marriage of Miss Jean Goldfrank, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lionel Goldfrank Jr., to Peter Eli Bronstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eli H. Bronstein of Scarsdale, N.Y., took place here yesterday at the Carlton House. The Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman of Temple Emanu-El performed the ceremony.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 19 Lightning toppled a 300pound, ornamental concrete ball from the dome of the Hoover Tower at Stanford University here a few nights ago, scattering fragments over a parking lot 285 feet below.

PARIS, Dec. 19 The French Communist party newspaper L'Humanit , acknowledged today that "honest workers" had taken part in this week's demonstrations in Poland and that shortcomings of the Polish authorities were to blame.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 19 A nationwide trial heat conducted by the Gallup Poll one month after the 1970 mid-term election has given President Nixon a slim, one-point lead over Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, as the choice for President.

One conclusion can be justified at this point in the development of the mystery novel. It is harrowingly difficult to sustain such a book without at least one murder a state of affairs that has brought its share of baleful condemnation in certain quarters. Even considering the genre more broadly, violent death still remains central in the large majority of cases.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Dec. 19 Mrs. Gail P. McKinney of New York was married here today to Emine Messiqua, a vice president of Norman, Craig Kummel, Inc., in New York, who will soon become managing director of the advertising agency's Paris office. Justice of the Peace Douglas Hudson performed the ceremony at Bellair Farm, home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Theodore H. Price Jr.

THE COUNTRY With a population of 33 million occupying 120,725 square miles in eastern Europe, Poland is bounded on the north by the Baltic Sea, on the northeast and east by the Soviet Union, on the south by Czechoslovakia and on the west by East Germany. Area is mostly lowlands with high mountains along the southern borders.

ROME, Dec. 19 The Vatican today denied reports that the health of Pope Paul VI had suddenly deteriorated. A statement said that the Pope who is recovering from influenza, is well and for some days has been receiving his closest advisers.

NAHA, Okinawa, Sunday, Dec. 20 (AP) Some 2,000 Okinawans hurled gasoline bombs, empty bottles and stones at United States military personnel and Okinawan policemen and damaged 60 American vehicles today at Koza outside Kadena Air Force Base.
BELGRADE, Dec. 18 Skilled Yugoslav workers, returning home from Western Europe for the Christmas and New Year's vacation, are being wooed to stay.
WARSAW, Dec. 19 Calm appeared to be returning to Poland tonight after five days of the most violent and widespread rioting in the nation's postwar history.

JAN. 26, 1971, is the 91st anniversary of the birth of Douglas MacArthur at Fort Little Rock, Ark., in 1880. On that day next month, a 6-cent commemorative stamp bearing a striking portrait of the fivestar general will be issued at Norfolk, Va., where he was to have been born, and where he is now buried. Preparations had been made by his father, General Arthur MacArthur, and his mother,...

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 19 (AP) Leon Burns scored his third touchdown and Rod Graves passed to Ken Matthews for a 2-point conversion in the fourth quarter to give Long Beach State a 24-24 tie with Louisville today in the Pasadena Bowl.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 19, (AP) The Boston Bruins slashed the St. Louis Blues' usually tough defense, 7-1, tonight for their seventh straight triumph.

ALTHOUGH the custom of the decorated Christmas tree can be traced to Strasbourg, Germany, in 1605, the tradition did not reach this country until two hundred years later. The German immigrants who settled in Easton, Pa., brought their beloved symbol of Christmas with them and by the end of the 19th century, the Christmas tree had become a national feature of family holiday celebrations.
Canada made its presence felt in United States harness racing in 1970, chiefly through the efforts of two competitors a 30-year-old driver and a 7-year-old mare.
The Nixon Administration has agreed to seek reimbursement for some of New York City's expense of being host to last October's 25th anniversary celebration of the United Nations.
When New York City starts its off-track betting system in January the gambling "industry" will enter the space age.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) The Census Bureau reported this week that one of every 10 Americans had an income below the Government-set poverty line in 1969.

Meteorologists of many nations are drawing up plans for what promises to be the most ambitious study of the weather ever undertaken.

IT'S the season, and what better time to talk about Santa Claus? The great work by William Henry Fry, that is: "Santa Claus A Christmas Symphony." MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 19 Miss Sarah Elizabeth Myers and John Edward McGinty plan to be married here July 31.

At the New York Choral Society's concert at Philharmonic Hall on Friday night, the audience sang 10 measures of music by Vivaldi five times. BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 19 The New York Rangers continued to fatten their winning percentage at the expense of the National Hockey's League's expansion clubs tonight.

Mr. and Mrs. James Waring Davant of New York, Mill Neck, L.I., and Maplewood, Wayzata, Minn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Jean Davant, to Michael Parks Dominick of Boulder, Colo., son of Senator Peter Hoyt Dominick, Republican of Colorado, and Mrs. Dominick of Washington, and Englewood, Colo. I STARTED teaching poetry writing at P.S. 61, which is in Manhattan on East 12th Street between Ave nues B and C, in 1968. I hoped to find a way of teaching the subject that would make children as happy to write poems as they are to draw and paint, and after a few months it seemed to me that I had found it.

THE recent Majorca, Spain, interzonal a round-robin of 24 chess paladins representing 14 different countries, was a knockout elimi nation. The top six qualify for matches, and they, together with the seeded former champion of the world, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union and his compatriot, Viktor Korchnoi, will vie in 1971 to determine a challenger for the world title, now held by Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union.

For more than two miles from Beach 34th Street to Beach 84th Street in Arverne, Queens the landscape consists of vacant land littered with acres of rubble from demolished or decayed houses.

WASHINGTON Speaking in London last week, Israeli Foreign Minister Abba Eban finally said in public what United States officials here have been predicting in private. The New York Times and The Washington Evening Star announced an agreement yesterday for an exchange of news dispatches, features and commentaries.

IN one of his final interviews, John Coltrane remarked to critic Frank Kofsky that Albert Ayler was one of the most promising new stars in contemporary jazz. Certainly that statement is as true in retrospect as Ayler's music was truth: the soulful embodiment of a boldly futuristic dream, rooted in a passionate, unyielding sense of morality and justice.

AMID the hullabaloo surrounding the sprouting ethnic theater, one organization has been carrying on for almost a year now without seeking the spotlight. Of all American novelists of the first half of the 20th century, F. Scott Fitzgerald seems now the one most likely to endure. Since the disastrous decline in popularity of his work in the 1930's and 1940's there has been nothing but a continual rise in his critical reputation.
The New York City Ballet's "The Nutcracker" continues on its merry box-office way at the State Theater, with occasional new casting to spark special interest.

DINANT, Belgium Christmas has an extra special significance in this quiet corner of southern Belgium. It was in this area on Christmas Eve 26 years ago that one of the most dramatic engagements of World War II the Battle of the Bulge came to an end with an Allied victory that led to the collapse of Nazi Germany a few months later.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 19 For what might be Weeb Ewbank's last season as coach, the New York Jets already have begun to associate 1971 with another Super Bowl triumph.

A group of writers, publishers, intellectuals and political figures calling itself the Spanish Emergency Committee 1970 has urged the Spanish Government to abstain from imposing death sentences in the trial of 15 Basques by a military tribunal in Burgos.

Dr. Ruth Dowling Neuman, daughter of Robert W. Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, has committed his union to a program of educational reform designed to help introduce the informal British approach to elementary education on a wide scale in New York City.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Dec. 19 May Singhi Breen, who as the "Ukulele Lady" was featured with her late husband, Peter De Rose, composer, on radio networks from 1923 to 1939, died today at the Jersey Shore Medical Center, Neptune. She lived at 606 Eighth Avenue here.

SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 19 President Chung Hee Park accepted today the resignation of Premier Chung Il Kwon and appointed Paik Too Chin, a former Premier, to succeed him.

SOUTH CARVER, Mass. Lilliput railroading still lives. Aficionados of nearly 20 two-foot gauge lines that existed in Maine in the first third of the century will find the last of those small railroads transferred to a site on State Route 58 here in the southeastern corner of Massachusetts.

Fashion goods and apparel are getting an unexpected dividend from the recession this year. BONN, Dec. 19 The greenery, that goes with Christmas and with other celebrations was never exclusively German, but the Christmas tree, still the center of the celebrations here, is German in origin, according to the Encyclopaedia Britannica and Willi Pfeffer. Willi is one of the country hucksters who sell the trees in the Munsterplatz here.

MOSCOW The gentlest thing that can be said about U.S. Soviet relations at the end of the year is that they are not exactly bubbling with the Christmas spirit. The official attitude here toward Washington is now hard and critical. It is not hostile or menacing, but clearly there has been a marked change for the worse since the first of the year.

THE adjective "objective" has frequently been applied to the photographs of Bere nice Abbott, an adjective which, in this deceptively subjective medium, is rarely applied correctly. WASHINGTON American and Soviet negotiators left Helsinki last week with little sign of any agreement to reach parity on strategic nuclear weapons. STUTTGART, West Germany, Dec. 20(AP)--Defense Minister Helmut Schmidt said today that the West German Government regarded with alarm the disturbances in Poland, "especially in the present phase of our Polish policies."

The New York Athletic Club triumphed in six of the seven weight classes contested yesterday and won the 13th annual N.Y.A.C. Christmas freestyle wrestline tournament.
HOUSTON, Dec. 20 (AP)-- Bill peterson, football coach at Florida State for 11 years, has become coach and athletic director at Rice.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 20-- For the second straight night no Willis Reed, and for the second straight night as easy Knick victory. This time the Phoenix Suns were the victims, 133-118.

PARIS, Dec. 20--A Dutch company gas taken a Scottish clergyman's invention of the early 19th century and come up with an engine that powers vehicles, the company says, without emitting noxious exhaust gases.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Dec. 21 --Paul Boepple, one of the nation's leading choral directors and professors of music, died early today of pnuemonia. Mr. Boepple, who had been in failing health for the past two years, was 74 years old. He made his home in nearby North Bennington.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Transportation Secretary John A Volpe today rejected the recommendation of a Coast Guard board of inquiry that called for the court-martialing of two officers for their decision to deny asylum to a seaman who defected last month from a Soviet fishing vessel.

Indiana's Earlham College Chamber Singers and Musicians concluded a brief December tour of the East Coast late Saturday afternoon with a concert in Town Hall. The program was, in part at least, of a seasonal nature, and the represented composers included Sch tz, Beethoven, Brahms, Poulenc, Thomson, Krenek and Manfred Blum, the group's musical director.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--In a dramatic illustration of the improved conditions in the mortgage market, the Federal National Mortgage Association announced today that it would sell, early next month $25-million out of its huge stock of mortgages. The mortgages will be those with an interest rate of 8 per cent. Officials said that the mortgage industry has been clamoring for a chance to buy these mortgages, now that thrift institutions appear to have plenty of funds.
Miss Sarah Perry Greene and Stoddard Dixon Fredricks, graduates of Shimer College in Mount Carroll, Ill., were married here yesterday afternoon.

Steel production last week felt 2.3 per cent, compared with output the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday in Washington. The trend of production in the next several months will be sharply upward, but current output continues to show the effect of depressed steel orders in October and November, industry sources said.

SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 21--The United States military headquarters in South Korea announced today that a wing of 54 American Phantom fighter-bombers and a detachment of EC-121 electronic reconnaissance planes would be moved to South Korea from Japan by the end of next June.

TRENTON, Dec. 21--The State Police were charged today in Federal court with pursuing a systematic policy of illegal searches of long-haired persons who travel the New Jersey Turnpike and other major highways in the state.

The Bronx County District Attorney, Burton B. Roberts, said yesterday that there was no cause for a grand jury investigation into the death last month of a 14-year-old resident of the Spofford Juvenile Center.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 21-- Frank P. Barrett, a well-known local lawyer and civic leader, died today in Stamford Hospital after a brief illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 3015 High Ridge Road.

Edward Gierek, Poland's new Communist party chief, has taken power in the midst of a comprehensive economic crisis for which Western analysts see no easy or quick answers.

MADRID, Dec. 21 (Reuters) --Generalissimo Francisco Franco's principal assistant, Adm. Luis Carrero Blanco, said tonight that Spain was the victim of a Communist campaign waged around the controversial trial of 15 Basque nationalists, and warned that the Government would maintain public order at all costs.

UAL, Inc., had a shake-up of its top management yesterday. The holding company for United Air Lines announced the resignation of George E. Keck, 58 years old, as president and chief executive officer of both the holding company and the airline, and the election of Edward E. Carlson, 59, to succeed him at UAL. It was also noted that Mr. Carlson would take over Mr. Keck's former positions at the airline "in a few days."

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 21 (AP)--Cambodian troops, supported by bombers, were reported pushing southwest along Route 4 today in an attempt to reopen the highway to the sea, which has been closed since Nov. 20.
The first widespread effects of the fuel oil strike became evident yesterday as supplies were exhausted in 13 city projects housing 50,000 people.
The Open Team Championship that ended the Greater New York Bridge Association's Winter Tournament at the New York Hilton Sunday resulted in an exceptionally close finish.

The American Cyanamid Company announced yesterday that it was planning to enter the cosmetics field and had reached an agreement to acquire Shulton, Inc., a producer of cosmetics, toiletries and perfumes. Under the agreement, stockholders of Shulton will receive 0.96 of a share of Cyanamid

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 21 (UPI)--The heart of Representative L. Mendel Rivers faltered last night but a quickacting physician restored the heartbeat of the 65-year-old chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.

The Supreme Court of the United States handed down a landmark decision yesterday which sustains the power of the Congress to extend the right to vote in Federal elections to a whole new group of American citizens, those from 18 to 21 years old.
A 6-year-old-Ohio boy is expected to become the first person on record to have survived rabies, public health officials said yesterday.

A 14-year-old Nassau County girl was subjected to "cruel and unusual punishment" when she was placed in what amounted to solitary, confinement at a state training school, a Federal district judge has ruled.
ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Dec. 21--Dr. Oscar K. Diamond, director of Rockland State Hospital, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home on the hospital grounds. He was 59 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (Reuters)--The White House is watching Soviet submarine ac tivity around Cuba "very closely" but does not yet see any threat from Soviet naval activity, a spokesman said today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 21 --Executive Jet Aviation, Inc., a flight charter service that was the subject of a critical Congressional report, has been reorganized under new management, is making a profit and is severing its ties with the Penn Central Transportation Company, its president said today.
ROCHESTER, Dec. 21 (AP) --The third of four men who escaped from the Monroe County Penitentiary yesterday surrendered tonight after taking a taxicab back to the jail.

Contemplate your Christmas tree ... "I like a real crooked tree that smells like a tree," said one woman as she examined a stand of spruce, pine and Douglas fir trees on a windy, cold street corner in Greenwich Village.
RIVER VALE, N.J., Dec. 21-- John A. Hughes, travel and aviation editor of The New York Daily News, died today of a heart attack at his home, 593 Baylor Avenue. He was 56 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21-- The United States accused the Soviet Union today of jeopardizing the success of Big Four talks on Berlin by allowing continued East German harassment of traffic into the city.

HONG KONG, Dec. 22--China today hailed the outbreak of resistance to Government authority in Poland and said that it illustrated the "crisis of colonialist rule in East Europe by Soviet imperialism and the bankruptcy of modern revisionism."

A new play, "The Carpenters," at the American Place Theater, suggests the demolition of a man's life, the death of his dreams, the erosion of his family. It is a first play by a young playwright, Steven Tesich, and it is concerned with that all-American theatrical theme, father, son and the years between. It is a decent play of some interest--not dazzling, but calm and clean, and in most respects well-crafted.

A Government report, viewed by speculative investors as bullish, plus the usual pre-holiday doldrums in the afternoon, sent grains and soybeans futures prices down yesterday in quiet trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Marian Sarach and Dance Company presented a program of her works Sunday afternoon at the Isidor Straus Theater on East Broadway. WASHINGTON, Dec. 21-- A peddler's cart of scientific paraphernalia, 25 pieces of fireworks and $15-million worth of new safety features, will be toted to the moon aboard Apollo 14 next month, the space agency announced today.

A man found guilty last Friday by a State Supreme Court jury of setting fire to a neighbor's luxury apartment, after the latter complained of "noisy parties," was sentenced yestday to an indeterminate prison term of up to three years..

Black Panther defense lawyers completed eight days of cross-examination yesterday of an undercover policeman, Detective Gene Roberts. Two defendants representing themselves, Mrs. Afeni Shakur and Michael Tabor, declined to question him.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 (AP)--Following are ski conditions from selected New England ski areas as reported by the ski area operators Monday afternoon.

Michael J. Maye, president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, announced yesterday that he would file Charges this morning that the city was refusing to bargain in good faith on a new contract.

The 35th Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball for the benefit of the New York Infirmary was held at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. Seventy-one debutantes were scheduled to be presented in the hotel's Grand Ballroom, where the decor was in the shades of pink that have become traditional with this party, but two young women developed flu and stayed home.

Truman, now the president of Mount Holyoke College, used to tell his students that lowering the voting age to 6 would make no great difference in election results unless free bubble gum were a major issue.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 21 (Reuters)--Fighting broke out near the northern Jordanian town of Irbid today between King Hussein's army and Palestinian guerrillas, the Damascus radio said tonight.

All during the week the Giant season ticketholders were grousing and grumbling something fierce. What Giant management was doing to them was insulting, inconsiderate and untrustworthy. They were being requested to come to Yankee Stadium ticket booths with certified checks in hand yesterday or today or tomorrow in order to pick up tickets for their regular locations for all postseason playoff games-- except the Super Bowl--in which the Giant football team might be involved.

PHILADEPJIA, Dec. 21--A special committee of the Philadelphia Bar Association charged today that procedures used by the State Board of Law Examiners discriminated against blacks seeking admission to the bar in Pennsylvania.

Mutual of Omaha has appointed John D. Minton as president and chief operating officer of the largest individual health insurance company in the world. Mr. Minton succeeds D.D. Ulfers who has served as president since 1964. V.J. Skutt, who remains as chairman and chief executive officer, announced the promotion of John F. Gaule to executive vice president for marketing and David S. Dodson to vice president for agency management and development.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21-- The National Association of Railroad Passengers said today that expansion of the proposed network of essential intercity passenger trains would improve the chances of financial success.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) --President Nixon has under consideration several recommendations for attempting to obtain the release of American war prisoners in North Vietnam, the White House said today.

YUCCA FLAT, Nev., Dec. 21 (UPI)--Underground nuclear testing has been discontinued in the area where radioactivity leaked into the atmosphere last week, the Atomic Energy Commission said today. WARSAW, Dec. 21--The new Polish leadership headed by Edward Gierek began its first day in office today with apparent support from both East and West.

The Detroit Lions will be bolstered by the return of their most dangerous running back, Mel Farr, for the National Conference semifinal playoff game against the Cowboys in Dallas on Saturday.

ROME, Dec. 21--A well-informed Vatican source said today, "The Pope's trip to Poland is off for the time being." The Vatican source explained that anything that might be construed as church interference in Poland's politics must be scrupulously avoided in the present period of political turmoil.

Three stockbrokers, a wall Street concern and a Canadian associate were indicted in Federal Court here yesterday on charges of attempting to evade United States taxes on the purchase of $20-million of foreign securities.
Lawrence Berenson, a New York lawyer and civic leader, died of a heart attack Sunday evening at his home, 1150 Fifth Avenue. He was 79 years old.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Dec. 21--Rhodes Scholarships for study at Oxford University in England were awarded yesterday to 32 young American men, including an All-Ivy League football player, a jazz clarinetist, a specialist in French African literature and a student member of the President's Commission on Campus Unrest.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 21 (AP)--Carlos Monzon of Argentina, the world middleweight boxing champion, will give Nino Benvenuti of Italy a chance to regain the crown in a rematch in San Remo, Italy, next spring.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--So many people have written with questions about Santa Claus this year that we have asked Norton Whizdom, holder of a doctorate in authority from the Pentagon and this nation's most dogmatic newspaper columnist, to answer some of the mail. Dr. Whizdom has, fortunately for us all, agreed, but only on condition that everyone act immediately on his advice. Let us proceed.
A key aide to Controller Abraham D. Beame whose responsibilities include matters involving labor unions is receiving a monthly fee as a consultant to a union local.

The eight-day long observance of Hanukkah, the Festival of Lights marking the Maccabean victory over Syrian tyranny more than 2,000 years ago, begins at sundown today with celebrations in homes and synagogues.
WESTPORT, Conn.--A political hurricane that is disrupting suburban complacency and ruffling the passions of the affluent has blown into this quaint, expensive town on Long Island Sound.
The American Smelting and Refining Company announced yesterday another cut, its fourth this year, in the price of lead.
BERLIN, Dec. 21--East Germans and West Germans exchanged bitter charges today over West Berlin as border guards increased harassment on the city's access routes.
The Paper Bag Players are in residence for the holidays at the Hunter College Playhouse, providing pure pleasure for children and for adults fortunate enough to be taken there by their children.

An official of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday criticized as "the worst in the country" a new city plan to train minority workers for jobs in the construction industry.

Memorex, the computerequipment issue that plunged 25 points last week, ranked as the market's big swinger yesterday with a gain of 7 points to 62. But, elsewhere, the stock market generally failed to produce any fireworks. It was another session that reflected, in the words of one analyst, "year-end crosscurrents and consolidation."

MOSCOW, Dec. 21--A Soviet prosecutor was reported today to have asked for the death penalty against two of the 11 persons on trial in Leningrad on charges of plotting to hijack a Soviet airliner last June.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21-- The Supreme Court refused today to consider a challenge to the constitutionality of New York City's two rent control laws.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 21 --The Minnesota Vikings and Oakland Raiders were favored today to reach the Super Bowl.

A power packed Clarkson hockey team extended its string of victories in its undefeated season to nine games by routing Bowdoin, 6-1, at Madison Square Garden last night. The game was the first of a doubleheader in the 10th annual Eastern College Athletic Conference tournament which will Conclude tonight. In the other game on the program Harvard beat Yale, 6 to 2.
Ernest Walling, a television director since the early days of the industry in this country died Saturday at his home, 83 Washington Place, after an illness of several months. He was 58 years old.

UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 21 (Reuters)--The United States circulated to all United Nations members today a detailed denial of North Vietnamese charges that the United States was following a general policy of massacring civilians in Indochina.

LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP)--The University of Louisville; capitalizing on free throws, upset eighth-ranked and previously undefeated Kansas, 87-75, tonight. PORT CHESTER, N.Y., (AP) The local police and Federal agents arrested four men suspected of running a counterfeit ring Monday night and seized an estimated $250,000 in allegedly bogus bills at the Gothic Printing, Company, the police said.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 22 (AP) Mining Minister Zepeda Orlando Cantuarias said today that the Government would hold a national referendum if Congress rejected a proposal to nationalize multimillion dollar United States copper interests in Chile.

DANANG, South Vietnam Dec. 22 (UPI) Cardinal Cooke of New York, dressed in a United States Army fatigue shirt, khaki trousers and a camouflage steel helmet, flew to the northernmost reaches of South Vietnam today to visit American servicemen near the demilitarized zone.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 (AP) A class action suit on behalf of bondholders and preferred-stock owners of the Pennsylvania Company has been filed in the Federal District Court here against 10 large banks involved in a $50-million loan to the Penn Central Transportation Company, the railroad-operating subsidiary of the Penn Central Company.

A Bronx man who was employed by two city hospitals as an X-ray technician for almost three years has been indicted by a grand jury for allegedly forging the papers that qualified him for the jobs, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 22 (AP) Phil Bengtson, the faithful soft-spoken aide who had been hand-picked by the late Vince Lombardi to continue Green Bay's football glory, resigned under fire today as the Packers' head coach and general manager.

Service on the Long Island Railroad between Woodside, Queens, and Penn Station was knocked out for an hour and a half during the rush hour last night when a panel that controls the switching system in the Sunnyside yards suffered an electrical failure.

Driven from their former livelihoods in small shops and trading enterprises in Burma by nationalization in 1964, thousands of Indians leave Rangoon each year for their own country, which many of them have never seen.
BERLIN, Dec. 22 East Germany, today removed the obstructions to road traffic be tween West Germany and West Berlin that it had imposed almost continuously since Satur day.

A class of fourth-graders in a city public school baked cookies not to sweeten their own Christmas, but that of others less fortunate than they. The children sold their handiwork and contributed the money to The New York Times Neediest Cases.

Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday that he was not aware that his law secretary, Harry Maze, had been also serving as a paid consultant to Local 810 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
The stock market found an old friend yesterday at the Chase Manhattan Bank and produced a mild rally after the Chase cut its prime rate to 6 per cent from 7 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 Another piece of Administration-backed legislation ran into a roadblock in Congress today when Senate liberals refused to accept a bill passed last night by the House to help school districts reduce segregation.

The Foxboro Company has announced the election of Ralph Hayden Jr. as chairman of the board and Earle W. Pitt as president. Mr. Hayden, who had been president and continues as chief executive officer since 1968 succeeds Rexford A. Bristol, who will become chairman of the executive committee and continue as a director. Mr. Pitt was previously executive vice president.

Miss Mary Louise Hawkins was married yesterday afternoon in the Community Church of New York to HerBert Blueweiss of Fort Lee, N.J., publisher of Daily News Record and a vice president of Fairchild Publications, Inc. The Rev. Chadbourne Spring performed the ceremony.
One child was reported killed and at least three persons were injured early this morning when fire swept through a combination synagogue and home in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 22 Mayor Thomas J. Whelan of Jersey City followed the example of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark today in appealing for more state aid to solve the city's financial problems.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 Congress completed action today on legislation authorizing the Administration's proposed $255-million military aid program for Cambodia but restricting the President from sending ground combat troops or military advisers into Cambodia.

Mrs. Concetta Bellini Cabral, professor of biology at Adelphi University, Garden City, L.I., died yesterday of cancer at her home. She was 48 years old and lived at 380 Garden Boulevard in Garden City.

The Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday cut the prime rate of interest from 7 per cent to 6 , and major banks throughout the country promptly followed suit. This was the fifth downward move this year in the rate that banks charge their most creditworthy business borrowers; last March the prime rate was at a peak of 8.5 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 House and Senate negotiators agreed today on a food stamp bill that retains a stringent "must-work" provision but frees the states from sharing the cost of the program.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Wednesday, Dec. 23 (Reuters) The French intellectual, Regis Debray, will be released from a Bolivian prison and flown to Chile today, a police spokesman said here.

Prices ended mixed on the American Stock Exchange yesterday for the second consecutive session on moderate trading. Most issues moved in a narrow price range throughout the day and there were few big price changes.

British and Australian challenges for the America's Cup in 1973 were received yesterday by the New York Yacht Club.

Early in the trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, prices of soybean futures declined nearly 6 cents a bushel and corn and wheat prices dipped about 1 to 2 cents. However, a late rally trimmed the early losses considerably.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 (UPI) Police Commissioner Frank L. Rizzo denied today that the Philadelphia police department discriminated in the hiring and promotion of blacks.

GENEVA, Dec. 22 Passenger fares for air travel between Europe and Africa, the Middle East, Asia and Australasia are to be increased an average of 5 per cent ou April 1, the International Air Transport Association said today.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 22 The tragic problem in this Holy City at Christmas time of 1970 is not only how to find peace, but how to be sure of the goodwill of its friends and the good faith of its enemies.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 The 91st Congress went home for Christmas tonight, still unable to dig its way out of two years' accumulation of public problems in time for the arrival of the 92d.

Residents of New York State who are unable to buy fire insurance in the normal market will be compelled to pay an additional 19.4 per cent to purchase it through the industry-wide fire insurance pool, it was disclosed here yesterday.

MANCHESTER, England, Dec. 21 Ibsen's "Peer Gynt" can be staged either as a lavish spectacle or as an unadorned poem that leaves everything to the spectator's imagination. Michael Elliott tried the first approach at the Old Vic seven years ago. In his new production for Manchester's 69 Theater Company he tries the second.
