The city's Consumer Affairs Department, in the first action for mass restitution under the Consumer Protection Act, said yesterday that it had obtained a temporary restraining order against a child model agency charged with "fraud and deception."
A vacant 11-acre tract of land fronting on Powell's Cove on the north shore of queens has been picked by the city's Site Selection Board for the long-delayed Mid-Queens High School.

As the wind moves through the dense thicket of Christmas trees lining the sidewalk, Dominick Vanacore, a state road worker on vacation, sits in a vacant store on Second Avenue near 87th Street and watches passers-by.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (Reuters) President Nixon is considering holding a news conference soon, possibly before Jan. 1, the White House announced today.

BETHLEHEM, Israeli-Occupied Jordan, Dec. 21 The politics of the Middle East have found their way into the local Christian Arab handicraft industries with the lucrative result of some untraditional customers and unexpected new products from the birthplace of Jesus. The New York Times/Micha Bar-Am

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 Food and Drug Administration officials are expected to announce tomorrow restrictions on imports of swordfish, which, like Alaskan fur seals. Great Lakes salmon, and tuna fish, has been found to be contaminated with mercury.

QUANG TRI, South Vietnam "Yeah, they ask for bacon at breakfast, but we've been out of it for so long they've almost forgotten what it is, Specialist 4 Louis McCullough said. He is one of the four cooks who work two shifts in the officers mess here, at headquarters for the First Brigade of the Fifth Infantry Division (mechanized).

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) Enrollment in college Reserve Officers Training Corps programs the source of more than half the regular officers in the armed services plummeted this year to the lowest level since 1947.
HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 22 Dartmouth officials said tonight that Bob Blackman was leaving Hanover to become head football coach at the University of Illinois.

Five State Assemblymen yesterday condemned the proposed closing of Irvington House, a private nonprofit clinic specializing in the care and treatment of children with rheumatic fever and allied diseases, calling the move "incredible and criminal."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 22 (UPI) The United States Embassy expressed regret today over the accidental shooting on Dec. 7 of a Vietnamese student by an American soldier at Quinhon, 250 miles northeast of Saigon.

The New York City Police Department has given $1,000 to the Neediest Cases Fund. The gift, from the department's charity fund, was one of 16 totaling $28,950 presented to representatives of charitable institutions yesterday in a ceremony at Police Headquarters.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 22 The Government of South Vietnam announced that it had decided to release at least 30 disabled or incurably ill North Vietnamese prisoners of war next month to mark the Tet, lunar new year.
The younger girls, the subject of one of John Sebastian's best known songs, were out in force to give the onetime member of the Lovin' Spoonful squeal-filled support Monday night at Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 For 12 years, Evelyn Dubrow, the lobbyist for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, has worked on Capitol Hill for liberal causes. Civil rights, education, consumer protection and Medicare, she says, have been her favorites.
Al Wilde, personal manager for Leslie Uggams, the entertainer, died yesterday after a heart attack in Hollywood. He was 55 years old and lived in Hollywood and at 25 Central Park West here.

GREEN POND, N.J., Dec. 22 David Earle Jones, retired director of research of the American Hard Rubber Company, died yesterday in Chilton Memorial Hospital, Pompton Plains, after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI) The Senate paid tribute today to Senator Ralph W. Yarborough, Democrat of Texas, the first of this election year's senatorial lame ducks, as "a champion of the weak, the downtrodden, the aged, the sick, the widowed, the orphaned."
MATTAPOISETT, Mass., Dec. 22 (AP) The captain of the Coast Guard cutter Vigilant says reports that a Lithuanian defector was beaten by Russians aboard the Coast Guard ship are false.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 22 Robert Wood Johnson Jr., a grandson of the founder of Johnson Johnson, maker of medical supplies, and its president from 1961 to 1965, died today in Holy Cross Hospital, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., after a long illness. He was 50 years old and lived here at 108 Edgerstoune Road.
In Utica, N.Y., Lorraine Asteri is selling ties to wives at the Boston Store this Christmas instead of offering their husbands "coffee, tea or milk."

Dr. Daniel Widelock, chief research scientist and deputy director of laboratory services for the New York City. Health Department, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness. He was 59 years old and lived in Scarsdale. N.Y.

There were almost tragic overtones to the ousting of Paul Brown as coach of the Cleveland Browns after the 1962 season. At that point in history he was the most successful coach professional football had yet produced Vince Lombardi was just then emerging and his removal by Art Modell, the comparatively new owner of the Brownies, was a shock.

CAMP EAGLE, South Vietnam, Dec. 22 Bob Hope introduced some marijuana jokes into his Vietnam routine for the first time today and immediately won the hearts and minds of 15,000 applauding troops.They also liked the girls.

No one, not even the author, is quite sure what kind of play "The Gingerbread Lady" is. Neil Simon quizzes himself: "Is it a comedy? No. It's not funny? It is funny. It's drama? No, it's too funny to be drama, too dramatic to be comedy. 'The Odd Couple' and 'Barefoot in the Park' were obviously comedies. This is not obviously a comedy."

Governor Rockefeller has been asked to invoke "whatever emergency measure is necessary for the State of New York" to prevent the possible demise of the New York Shakespeare Festival and its Public Theater.

TOKYO, Dec. 22 (AP) The suit filed against Japanese television producers by the National Union Electric Corporation of Greenwich, Conn., is another example of management shifting the blame for poor performance to imports in general and imports from Japan in particular, a Japanese Electronics Industry Association spokesman said today.

Business and consumer lending rates dropped across a broad front yesterday. Major commercial banks, led by the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York for the third time in a month and a half, reduced the prime rate on business loans to 6 per cent from 7 per cent, effective immediately.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 23 The president of the InterAmerican Press Association, a Brazilian newspaper publisher, has condemned Brazil's censorship of the press and what he termed persecution of journalists. The police prohibited the publication of the statement in Brazil.

ALBANY, Dec. 23 (AP) Governor Rockefeller today commuted the sentence of L. Judson Morhouse, the former Republican State Chairman, who was convicted four years ago in connection with the issuance of a liquor license to the Playboy Club in New York City.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 (UPI) A financial report covering the first 10 months of the year showed today that the Penn Central railroad has gone deeper into the red with losses of $252-million.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 23 (UPI) The South Vietnamese National Assembly voted today to hold the 1971 presidential election on Oct. 3.
The big New York City bank stocks ranked among the markets star performers yesterday following their Tuesday reduction in the prime lending rate to 6 per cent from 7 per cent.
William Humphrey's "The Spawning Run" (Alfred A. Knopf, Inc., 80 pages, $4) is the most delightful work this reviewer has read in a long time.
The urban-bred patience of Maurice S. Kanbar finally fell apart yesterday and he was angry and indignant.
The low esteem in which the social science are so widely held is well deserved; it is in large measure due to the timorous and parochial outlook of their practitioners.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 President Nixon ordered today new procedures that will require companies to obtain Federal permits to discharge wastes into virtually any of the nation's waterways.

Mrs. Teme Casten Brenner, president of Rogers, Cowan Brenner, Inc., public relations, with offices in New York and Beverly Hills, Calif, died Tuesday of cancer at her home in Beverly Hills. Her age was 50.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP) A contribution admission fee, like the one New York's Metropolitan Museum has been collecting since last summer, was approved today for the Art Institute of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Ralph Nader, a long-time critic of the automobile industry, said today that the Justice Department had been urged by some of its top antitrust officials over the last four years to bring a suit to break up the General Motors Corporation.

Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner suspended yesterday a controversial Brooklyn intermediate school principal who has been charged with promoting trouble-making students to high school without the proper academic credit allegedly to get rid of them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) White House negotiations with Japan over voluntary curbs on textile imports will be suspended until early 1971, Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stuns said today.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Dec. 23 (UPI) Charles Ruggles, the stage, screen and television performer whose wryly turned milquetoast image made him one of the most disarming comedians in show business, died in St. John's Hospital today at the age of 84. A member of the family said he had had cancer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 "When I was a Congressman I never realized how important Congress was," President Kennedy told the Economic Club of New York in 1962. "But now I do." As he gazes with the rest of us on the bald failure of Congress to get its work done, President Nixon must feel much the same; for if Congress is impotent, what of the nation itself?
A player who leads a short suit against no-trump contract generally has a valid reason for avoiding the lead of a long suit. Often he will have length in the suits the declaring side has bid.
Mayor Lindsay praised New York's policemen as the finest of the city, the country and the world during a promotion ceremony yesterday for 14 highranking police officials.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 The National Archides has made it hear the sweetest music this side of heaven the sound of his own voice arguing a case before the Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) The Agriculture Department forecast today a 1971 winter wheat crop of 1.04 bil lion bushels based on field conditions as of Dec. 1.

Six armed men wearing ski masks escaped yesterday afternoon with about $25,000 after robbing the Springfield Gardens branch of the National Bank of North America, at 216-02 Merrick Boulevard in Queens.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has announced the election of five senior vice presidents. They include: Boris S. Berkovitch, secretary, and resident counsel; Langdon P. Cook, head of the municipal band department; Bernard F. Curry, of the pension trust administration; Robert M. Hill, who handles international business for United States corporate customers; and Carl W. Klemme, of custoday and electronic tabulating.
DUBLIN There are some circles in Dublin in which "pill" is a four-letter word.

Two members of the New York Giants, Fran Tarkenton and Ron Johnson, were named yesterday to the National Conference all-star team that will oppose the American Conference squad in the Pro Bowl game at Los Angeles on Jan. 24.
The First Congregational Church of Flushing, a 114-yearold white frame building at 3814 Bowne Street, Queens, was heavily damaged by fire yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Parents of children enrolled in Head Start programs have been granted broad governing authority, including the right to hire and dismiss local program directors.
Dansk Designs Ltd., a tablewares producer that has been synonymous with prestigious, high-priced modern wares for cooking and serving, is working on a new, second image.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI) The total output of the American economy declined this year for the first time since the 1958 recession, the Commerce Department said today.

Mrs.Bessie Abramowitz Hillman, a vice president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and the widow of Sidney Hillman, the first president of Amalgamated, died yesterday in St.Vincent's Hospital. She was 81 years old and lived at 341 West 24th Street.

It would be "cruel and morally indefensible" to try to upset the so-called Corona compromise the plan to save 59 homes that were to have been razed for a new Queens high school without having some thing better to offer, the lawyer who drew up the compromise said yesterday.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 23 Correction Commissioner Ellis C. MacDougall testified in Federal Court here today that Bobby G. Seale, the Black Panther national chairman, had set fire to a television set and had broken other furniture in his isolation cell at the State Correction Center in Montville.

Waverly Logan, a suspended New York patrolman formerly assigned to Harlem's preventive enforcement patrol squad, went on trial yesterday on departmental charges of accepting $100 from a convicted narcotics dealer.
Twenty-five former heroin addicts sang and danced in a Christmas show yesterday, and the theme was a warning to 300 students at the Benjamin Franklin High School of the dangers of drug addiction.
A ticket to Radio City Music Hall's annual Christmas Show costs $1.75 to $3.75.

The appointment of a black teacher as acting principal of Benjamin Franklin High School in East Harlern without regard for a Civil Service list of eligible candidates was upheld in a Brooklyn Supreme Court decision yesterday.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23 The Soviet Union today scoffed at Western allegations that the trial in Leningrad of 11 persons most of them Jews for attempted hijacking of a Soviet airliner had anti-Semitic or anti-Zionist motivations. The trial, which began Dec. 19, is expected to end tomorrow when the three-man tribunal gives its verdict and pronounces sentence.

Wally Lemm, coach of the Houston Oilers, was asked recently about a linebacker named Dave Meggysey he coached several years ago at St. Louis. Lemm said: "He was strictly a borderline football player. Nobody would pay any attention to him if he had not been a football player, and yet he is ripping the game now.

Anyone who feels like taking to the couch after staging a year-end bash might take comfort in hearing about Trudy Cannon. The Thanksgiving turkey has scarcely been made into the last sandwich when she starts making the menu for a series of four sitdown dinners, with 20 or more guests each, to celebrate the Christmas holidays.

PARIS, Dec. 23?The North Vietnamese called on the Nixon Administration today to agree to withdraw American forces from Vietnam by next June 30 or to suggest another date. They offered to help the United States meet the deadline if need be.

Flip Wilson has been signed as host-narrator of "The Record Makers," a documentary on champions in all fields, which the National Broadcasting Company will televise Friday, April 2, from 7:30 to 8:30 P.M.
Restaurant Associates Industries, Inc., has decided to sell or close a number of marginal or loss locations in the next few months.

HONG KONG, Dec. 23 North Vietnam today defended its treatment of American war prisoners, which it called humane, and said their plight was a result of atrocities committed in Vietnam by United States military men and the failure of the United States to withdraw from Vietnam.
A number of wives of American prisoners of War in North Vietnam have selected their Christmas cards to honor their husbands this year.

Dr. Bailey B. Pepper, professor of entomology at Rutgers University and chairman of the department of entomology and economic zoology, died Tuesday in Doctors Hospital, after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived in Edison, N.J.

SEATTLE Merchants here and other businessmen are on the offensive about reports that Seattle is a disaster area as a result of aerospace-industry cutbacks but consumers seem more disturbed by inflation.

Mrs. Elizabeth Brosius Higgins Chapin Angell, wife of Ernest Angell, retired chairman of the American Civil Liberties Unions, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack. She was 70 years old and lived at 156 East 66th Street.

TRENTON, Dec. 23 Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey, signing into law a $50million urban-aid and city tax package for Newark, criticized President Nixon today and attacked Federal spending priorities that, he charged, shortchange the nation's cities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) Frances G. Knight, head of the passport section in the State Department, sent out at Christmas time last year a letter saying that lack of funds would mean delays of two weeks in the issuance of passports.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Dec. 23 The unbeaten Fordham Rams, fighting back from a 7-point deficit midway in the second half, scored 13 points in the last four minutes tonight to run their streak to eight games in defeating the University of Florida, 72-65, before 2,396 at Florida Gym.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Secretary of State William P. Rogers acknowledged today that President Nixon had gone beyond the terms of the 1968 understanding ending American bombing of North Vietnam when he threatened recently to resume bombing if the enemy stepped up the level of fighting in South Vietnam.

Elinor Ross, the American soprano who made her Metropolitan Opera debut in June as Turandot and did her first Tosca with the company a few weeks ago, appeared in another title role, that of Verdi's "Aida," on Tuesday night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 The Federal Trade Commission accepted today a proposal by eight of the country's nine cigarette manufacturers to list tar and nicotine ratings in their advertisements.

IQUIQUE, Chile, Dec. 23 The Bolivian Government released today the French Marxist writer, Regis Debray, who fought beside Ernesto Che Guevara in an abortive attempt to organize a peasants' revolt in 1967.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 The treasury welcomed today final Congressional passage of legislation permitting the United States to accept a higher quota in the International Monetary Fund, but warned that a separate appropriation bill must be passed by Dec. 31 to prevent a United States permanent loss of $130-million in "paper gold."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, appears to be succeeding with his plan to strengthen the Senate's hand in dealing with the House in the final moments of the annual drive to adjourn Congress.

ABOARD U.S.S. SPRINGFIELD, in the Mediterranean, Dec. 17 The continued westward movement of Soviet naval power has brought to the Mediterranean what Atlantic alliance planners view as a precarious naval balance.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ordered bail today for defendants in the Seattle 7 conspiracy trial pending a hearing on their appeal of contempt sentences.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Monthly Treasury bill rates at today's auction of 265 and 365day bills, posted a three-year low, the Government announced late this afternoon.

Fuel oil dealers worked yesterday at reducing the backlog of customers who had run out of oil and predicted a rise in the price of oil because of the cost of the new union contract that followed a sevenday strike that ended Tuesday night.
MADRID, Dec. 23 The army has begun to emerge in the last three weeks as a conscious political force, marking an important change in the politics of Spain.
MADRID, Dec. 23 The lawyers defending the 15 Basque activists charged with banditry and terrorism have been summoned to appear at Burgos military headquarters Saturday.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 23 (Reuters) Kris Kemmer of Los Angeles, the United States eighth-ranked junior, battled her way to the final of the South Australian women's tennis championship today.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Dec. 23 (AP) Bob Blackman, named officially today as head football coach at the University of Illinois, said that after 16 years of Ivy League play and six championships in nine years, he had "come to the end of the line."
Abraham Kupchik, the last member of a famous chessplaying quartet, recently passed away. The chess career of this stylist began in the coffee houses of New York's East Side.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23(AP) Thomas Kleppe of North Dakota may be No. 3 on the list of lame duck Republican Representatives given jobs by Presi dent Nixon after failing in bids for the Senate.

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Dec. 23 An attorney for Angela Davis charged today that the black activist was "roughed up" by the authorities in New York City while being transferred here yesterday to stand trial.

A physician in upper Manhattan shot and wounded one of two youths who attempted to mug him in a hallway of a building where he was making a house call yesterday, the police said. Some hours earlier another physician shot and killed a holdup man in his Queens office.
Steps have been taken to improve living conditions in hotels for welfare families and to reduce the need for emergency hotel housing, Human Re sources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman said yesterday.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Dec. 23 Miss DeAnne Adele Sloan and Christopher Elam Riddle, both of whom-served as Peace Corps volunteers in Tunisia, were married here this afternoon in St. Theresa's Roman Catholic Church. PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 23 Churchgoing among Roman Catholics continued to decline in 1970, with 60 per cent of adults of this faith attending church in a typical week compared to 63 per cent last year and 71 per cent in 1964, the Gallup Poll reported today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI) Agriculture Secretary Clifford M. Hardin said at a year-end news conference today that long strides had been made toward President Nixon's goal of eliminating hunger.

The Museum of Modern Art is threatened with a strike next Tuesday morning by a number of its staff members. The immediate issue is the museum's dismissal of 11 staff members as part of a "cost reduction" program.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 John B. Connally Jr., President Nixon's nominee for Secretary of the Treasury, has assured the top Treasury staff members that he wants them to remain on the job.
Leaders of the City Council said yesterday that there would be no immediate increase in taxi fares; thereby postponing a raise for the city's 36,000 licensed cabbies who ended a 15-day strike Sunday.

Fanciers have become interested in dogs for many reasons. Few, however, have turned to them for the reasons put forth by Dr. William Ptomey and Leon Duffer, owners of the Pine Hollow Kennel in Pensacola, Fla.
BUFFALO, Dec. 23 (UPI) The Erie County Sheriff's office said today that with the help of a, matchbook it had traced a helicopter stolen Sunday from a hanger in a suburb to somewhere in Alabama.

A break seemed to be developing yesterday in the impasse between the Continental Insurance Company and some major New York City banks threatened by a loss of coverage on Government securities.

Dr. Lucius Pitts, president of Miles College in Birmingham, Ala., is resigning from that post to become the first black president of his alma mater, Paine College, a 90-year-old predominantly Negro school in Augusta, Ga.

The Rangers had themselves another movable feast last night at the expense of another expansion team. This time the apponent was the Pittsburgh Penguins, and they never had a chance as they dropped a 6-1 decision at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Federal air pollution officials said today that the Union Carbide Corporation had presented the Environmental Protection Agency with "What looks like a showdown" over the company's plans to abate air pollution at its Marietta, Ohio, ferro-alloy plant.
The appointment of Alton G. Marshall as president of Rockefeller Center, Inc., was announced yesterday by J. Richardson Dilworth, chairman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI) President Nixon played "Jingle Bells" and "Silent Night" on an upright piano for a swarm of children gathered around him to sing Christmas carols in the East Room of the White House tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 The United States indicated today that it would consider participating with its troops in a Middle East peace-keeping force if the Arab countries and Israel succeeded in negotiating a "permanent contractual" agreement among themselves.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 (AP) The prosecution in the Sharon Tate murder trial characterized Charles Manson today as having an "insatiable lust for death, blood and murder." Manson, the prosecutor said in his third day of closing arguments, "thinks it's just grand to murder human beings."

BAY CITY, Mich., Dec. 23 (AP) William Kinard, 26 years old, of Bay City has been sentenced to spend the rest of his life in solitary confinement and at hard labor for the April 14 murder of a gas station attendant.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Mortgage lending by savings and loan associations was at record levels in November, as was the inflow of savings, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 (UPI) The state Supreme Court today ordered the release of Cesar Chavez, jailed since Dec. 4 for contempt of court.

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 23 A 34-year-old man convicted of killing two policemen as he was fleeing the scene of a holdup became today, the first man to face the death penalty in New York State in seven years, and the first sentenced to death under the State's revised penal code.

Dr. Sophie Koerner Gottlieb, a clinical psychologist who practiced in collaboration with her husband, Dr. Bernhardt S. Gottlieb, a psychiatrist, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack, at their home, 225 West 86th Street. She was 72 years old.

The unusual post-election session of Congress was expected to be a lame duck, but it has proved much more lively than lame. The productivity of both houses has been obscured by the spectacular impasse which the Senate Finance Committee created when it merged several unrelated bills into one huge unmanageable package.

Most of the 160 nurses on the staff of the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn refused yesterday to withdraw the resignations they handed in last week. J.J. Newberry Company yesterday announced the promotion of Daryl D. Milius to president of the nationwide department and specialty store chain. He was formerly executive vice president.

Forty high school athletes and their coaches pleaded at City Hall yesterday that unless the city allocates $375,000 immediately athletic and other extracurricular activities in the public high sohools would be sharply curtailed, if not stopped.

ALBANY, Dec. 23?The Public Service Commission has ordered telephone companies in the state to pay larger refunds for loss of service.

The 110-story World Trade Center was "topped out" yesterday with the emplacement of a steel column 1,370 feet above the streets of Lower Manhattan.

A Government report on a Penn Central collision near Darien, Conn., in 1969 in which four people died, says that some of the railroad's employes did not fully comply with the rules and that the line's officials had in some cases "condoned this practice of poor compliance."

A former Colombian vice consul who was convicted last month by a Federal jury in Brooklyn on two counts of smuggling $5-million worth of pure cocaine into this country was reported yesterday to have jumped $250,000 bail and fled to Colombia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans, who has been rumored to be "the next Cabinet officer likely to go," had a little fun with reporters today.

ROME, Dec. 23 International Jewish leaders and Vati can officials ended a four-day meeting here today with an agreement to join forces in fighting racism, anti-Semitism and all forms of discrimination.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 News item: Army intelligence agents have spied on 800 civilians in Illinois, including leading political figures, according to Senator Sam Ervin. To get oneself spied upon by the U.S Army, the Senator says, it was apparently necessary only to be in disagreement with Administration policies, foreign or domestic.

ROME, Dec. 23 (Reuters), Pope Paul's personal physician, Prof. Mario Fontana, said today that the Pope was struck twice during an at tempt on his life in Manila last Nov. 27, according to ANSA the Italian news agency.

Lonny Joseph Gordon's idea of choreography is that of a third-rate graphic designer, all trite effects with no underlying form. Tuesday evening at they Cubiculo he presented fours works on a program he shared with Gale Ormiston.

Lawrence L. Hammer of 20615, 26th Avenue, Bayside, Queens, a lawyer and retired captain in the New York Police Department, died yesterday in Booth Memorial Hospital after a short illness. He was 59 years old.

Secretary of State Rogers's public offer of United States participation in a U.N. peace-keeping force in the Middle East goes to the heart of a central issue in the ArabIsraeli talks which are expected to begin early next year under auspices of United Nations Ambassador Gunnar Jarring the question of security guarantees.
Prices advanced steadily throughout the session on the American Stock Exchange yesterday and the list finished at or near its best level of the day.

General Mills, Inc., a leading producer of packaging foods, showed small gains in sales and earnings for the second fiscal quarter ended Nov. 29, but half-year results were more favorable, according to the semiannual report issued yesterday.
DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 23 Monroe F. Dreher, retired head of Dreher Advertising, Inc., in New York City, died today of a sudden illness at his Salem Street home.

As the tall man with his hair combed back in what Poles call "hedgehog' style took the rostrum in the Sejm building in Warsaw, several foreign observers noted that he looked a bit like Lyndon B. Johnson.

GENEVA, Dec. 23 Gramco Management, Ltd., the mutual fund organization, was involved in a case of private telephone tapping during its merger negotiations with Investors Overseas Services, Swiss Federal officials asserted today.

Dr. John Kemeny of Dartmouth College has failed to convince the seven other Ivy League presidents that the league should permit its football teams to play 10 games a year. Ivy teams have long been limited to nine games, and no spring practice.

The 6-year-old daughter of a Brooklyn rabbi died in a fire early yesterday that destroyed the store-front synagogue of Congregation Hayoscher Veh Atov at 1345 46th Street, in the Borough Park section.
Bond prices drifted downward yesterday, paying no attention to the prime rate reductions Tuesday or the Federal Reserve's, purchases of securities this week.
With the frantic shopping behind them, many New Yorkers will relax at parties or at home with their fami lies tonight, as they did last year and the year before that.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 23 The Securities and Exchange Commission has pledged to write new regulations covering two major areas of the securities business a cash reserve against customers' credit balances and segregation of securities owned by customers but held in "street names."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Soviet negotiators at the recently recessed arms talks in Helsinki reportedly proposed that an arms agreement permit both sides to deploy mobile land-based intercontinental missiles, a development opposed by the United States.

PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 23 (AP) United States District Court Judge Edward T. Gignoux has set Jan. 19, as the new date for a hearing on a petition to place financially troubled. Maine Sugar Industries, Inc., into receivership.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Secretary or State William P. Rogers said at a news conference today that there had been some Soviet "naval activity" recently in the area of Cienfuegos, the Cuban port where the Soviet Union is reportedly developing facilities for nuclear submarines. But he said there had been "no new construction" since President Nixon's news conference 10 days ago.

Sander Vanocur will relinquish his role as anchorman on "First Tuesday," the National. Broadcasting Company's monthly televised news magazine, in favor of other correspondents, starting with the program ,of Jan. 5.

The Dallas Cowboys and Detroit Lions, who meet in the first round of the National Football League playoffs on Saturday, share an unusual distinction. They switched personnel at the game's most important position, quarterback, in the course of the season, Craig Morton for Roger Staubach at Dallas and Greg Landry for Bill Munson at Detroit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 The Food and Drug Administration recalled from the market today nearly every brand of frozen swordfish after finding excessive, amounts of mercury in 89 per cent of the samples tested.

NEWTOWN, Conn., Dec. 23 Mrs. Julie Benjamin Howson of Taunton Lake Road, widow of Roger S. Howson, retired librarian of Columbia University, died today after a long illness in Glen Hill Convalescent Home in Danbury. She was 84 years old.
WARSAW, Dec. 23 Jozef Cyrankiewicz resigned today as Poland's Premier and was replaced by a 61-year-old economist, Piotr Jaroszewicz.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 Jacob Davis's 33-foot jump shot in the final second of a fiveminute overtime period gave Pepperdine College an 86-84 triumph over. New York University last night at the Sports Arena. It was the second consecutive overtime defeat for the Violets, who have a 2-7 wonlost record.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24-- The White House backed and filled and finally fell silent today on reports that Tricia Nixon, the President's older daughter, would marry Edward Finch Cox, a Harvard Law student who has been a beau of Miss Nixon's for varying periods over the last six years.

Ham acting is trying to bully its way back into the New York theater, via Off Broadway. Nudity on the local stage is not so much a moral problem as an artistic one. Audience participation is a poor substitute for a play.

**Jolly Chan's Chinese Kitchen, 1069 First Avenue (at 58th Street), 486-1182. This is the latest in a long line of Chinese kitchens with take-home foods. It is in the Sutton Place area, and it may very well have the most extensive and best menu of them all. It is the enterprise of Robert Tsang, who owns the well-regarded Mon Sing restaurant on Mott Street in Chinatown.

PARIS--Peace prospects in the Middle East are probably less bad today than at any time since 1967. That is not to say prospects are good, simply that talks between both sides will almost certainly be resumed and that pressures by the Big Four powers and by public opinion in Israel, Egypt and Jordan are conducive to agreement.

For decades dreamers have envisioned a city growing out of the huge Hackensack Meadowlands. In 1968 the New Jersey Legislature appointed a commission to undertake the thirty-year task of converting a noisome swamp into a community larger in area than Manhattan. Publication of the commission's plan is a landmark, nonetheless historic for the serious questions posed by the swiftly changing nature of the metropolitan region.

Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., has received the required two-thirds approval from noteholders to reduce the collateral requirements on the 6 per cent notes in return for a higher interest rate, the conglomerate announced yesterday.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 24--Bobby G. Seale, the Black Panther party's national chairman, will be allowed to see his own psychiatrist under a compromise worked out in Federal Court here today on a suit involving the rights of jailed prisoners.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 24-- A fire wrecked the editorial and business offices and composing room of the Daily Register here this afternoon and officials said that they doubted that the next issue, which is due on Monday, could be printed in the plant.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 24 (UPI)--Adm. Charles M. Cooke, former Deputy Chief of United States Naval Operations and former commander of the Pacific Fleet, died today after a long illness. He was 84 years old.
ATHENS, Dec. 24--The Greek Government announced today that 305 political prisoners were freed this week in time to spend Christmas with their families, most of them for the first time in three years.

Beck Industries, Inc., a financially troubled concern, announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement in principle with Frank T. Grassie whereby a corporation controlled by him will acquire a substantial portion of Beck's present shoe and handbag operations.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 21-- The approach of Christmas this year has highlighted the growing North American influence on one seasonal aspect of life in Puerto Rico--gift giving. It is a trend that works to the advantage of the young.

Jewish organizations yesterday strongly protested the death sentences of two Jewish prisoners in the Leningrad hijacking trial and other groups staged demonstrations in front of the Soviet mission to the United Nations, at 136 East 67th Street.

Following the Agriculture Department's report on winter wheat production, the futures prices of that commodity rose sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The report predicted a reduction in winter wheat production for 1971.

DETROIT, Dec. 24 (AP)-- New car production in the United Staes will close out the year at about 6.55 million units, which is 1,669,463 less than in 1969 and the lowest number since 1961, a trade publication, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

CALEXICO, Calif., Dec. 24 (AP)--The United Farm Workers Organizing Committee called a strike today against six lettuce growers shortly after the union leader, Cesar Chavez, was released from jail.

The American Paper Institute said yesterday that United States paper and paperboard production in 1970 would total 52.5 million tons, a drop of 2.5 per cent from last year.

The board of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation will hold a special meeting here today to hear the report of its committee of independent directors on restructuring-- with indications that a major executive restructuring will take place immediately.
For most of the last two years, the parents of children at Public School 146 in the South Bronx have been undergoing trial by frustration at the hands of the New York City school system.

An off-duty detective foiled a holdup but was shot in the back in a gunfight with two robbers in a Bronx bank yesterday morning, and a guard was shot in the shoulder and a patron pistol-whipped in another holdup at a Brooklyn bank in the afternoon.

Willis Reed of the Knicks, who won every individual honor from players, coaches and writers last season while leading his team to the National Basketball Association championship, received another accolade yesterday.

A bloc of generally older college language teachers won approval yesterday for a new constitution for the Modern Language Association despite the objections of a generally younger and "radical" caucus, which argued for the status quo.
The Federal Reserve Board has proposed a broad overhaul of Section 8 of the Clayton Act to ban most, if not all interlocking directorships between financial institutions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) The National Association of Securities Dealers today revoked the registrations of five securities salesmen and suspended another salesman and one firm.

CAIRO, Dec. 28--In a sweeping political and economic reform, President Anwar el-Sadat ordered Premier Mahmoud Fawzi tonight to return property taken from Egyptians over the last decade, sometimes for political reasons.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 (AP) --A towering Penn team, led by 6-foot-8-inch Bob Morse's 27 points, downed Utah, 86-78, tonight and advanced to the final of the 10th annual Quaker City basketball tournament.

Herbert Coolidge Davidson, a retired vice president and trustee of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, died last Thursday in Rye Beach, N.H., where he had made his home since his retirement in 1948. He was 87 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission's Board of Suspension voted today to allow freight-rate increases for motor carriers handling about 80 per cent of the nation's truck shipments.

The Beatrice Foods Company posted record sales and earnings in the quarter and the nine months ended Nov. 30 for the 19th consecutive year, the company reported in Chicago yesterday. The three-month results were said to be the highest for any quarter in the company's history.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 28 (AP)--A 28-year-old mother of three was rebuffed today in her effort to remain eligible for welfare benefits while attending college full-time.

An advisory committee recommended yesterday to Mayor Lindsay that the city's Health Research Council be restructured to pay more attention to the health needs of the people and to sponsor community-involved research relevant to these problems.
REUTTE, Austria, Dec. 28-- Dr. Paul Schwarzkopf, internationally known scientist, industrialist and founder of the Plansee Metal Works in this Tyrolean community, died yesterday. He was 84 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) --Colleagues of Senator Stephen M. Young described the retiring Ohio Democrat as a model of courage and conviction in tributes on the Senate floor today.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 28--A military spokesman here said today that Israeli soldiers accomplished their mission last night by demolishing four houses in the Lebanese village of Yater, three miles from the Israeli border, which was said to have been a major base for Arab guerrillas.

SAN ANDREAS, Calif., Dec. 28--Mrs. Blanche Mitchell Ellinger, widow of Edgar Ellinger, New York City real estate developer and builder, died yesterday in the Mark Twain nursing home. She was 88 years. old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) --Mohawk Airlines officials were reported to have made a major contract package proposal to striking pilots today as talks between the two groups resumed after a 10-day recess.

JUBA, the Sudan, Dec. 13-- People are migrating in droves from the bush to this old market center and to nearby towns, which were virtually deserted a few years ago during the peak of the campaign to crush the separatist movement in the southern Sudan.
NEW ROCHELLE; N.Y., Dec. 28--Harry Crown, a retired industrialist, died of a heart attack last evening art his home, 83 Croft Terrace. He was 63 years old.

MONTREAL, Dec. 28--A three-month manhunt that involved up to 10,000 policemen and troops and brought on a national emergency decree ended today with the capture of three suspects in the kidnapping and murder of Pierre Laporte, Quebec's Minister of Labor and Immigration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28-- The death of Representative L. Mendel Rivers, chairman of the powerful House Armed Services Committee, will probably mean little fundamental change in the committee's attitude toward military policy, Congressional sources believe.
The Celanese Plastics Company, a unit of the Celanese Corporation, announced yesterday that it would raise prices on several segments of its film and sheet product lines.

A year ago the Kansas City Chiefs upset the Minnesota Vikings in the Super Bowl and at the start of this season both teams took dead aim for a return meeting, the Chiefs to prove that the victory was no fluke and the Vikings to prove that it was. In addition to this spiritual reward, of course, was the not-to-be-ignored item of $25,000 a man to the reigning monarchs of the football universe.

Harvey B. Scribner, Chancellor of the city school system, proposed yesterday a new budget of almost $2-billion that places the "highest priority" on teacher training and and retraining "to make education meaningful to each of our students."
A 20-year-old college student whose funds were cut off by her father because he disapproved of her "hippie" style of life has won a court order that he must resume payment or go to jail.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Dec. 28 (AP)--The Libya Oil Ministry, concerned about declining exploration activity, has issued a "supervisory edict" to oil companies in the country to set aside a percentage of their profits for exploration costs, a news report said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (Reuters)--The Export-Import Bank said today it had made a total, of $100-million available to three commercial banks in support of United States exports.

Mimi Farifia and Steve Baron, folk singers, are mixing with Uncle Dirty, a comedian, in what has to be one of the most powerful, if unusual, evenings of entertainment seen in a Greenwich Village club in some time.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 28 (AP)-- Judge John Carroll Young of the State Court of Claims died of a heart attack here Saturday in St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 66 years old.

Six years ago, soon after London fashion began to swing, Jean Muir, one of its swingers, brought her fashion collection to New York for the first time. Twiggy faded away, but Jennie remained here to become one of the most popular runway, mannequins.

Despite the best efforts of musicians in every part of the country, Peter Schickele presented another Evening With P.D.Q. Bach at Philharmonic Hall Monday. Greeted by a seated ovation, Professor Schickele maintained close rapport with his large audience ("Truth is impervious to hisses," he explained, en route) as he guided his New York Pick-Up Ensemble through three more works by the composer he has been championing for lo these nearly six years.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 29 Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller commuted today the death sentences of all 15 men awaiting execution in Arkansas to life imprisonment.

Michael Tabor, one of 13 Black Panthers on trial for as alleged bomb conspiracy, was remanded to jail yesterday and his $50,000 bail revoked after he failed to arrive for trial until the afternoon session.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 The appointment of Benjamin R. Schenck of Yonkers as the new State Superintendent of Insurance was announced today by Governor Rockefeller.
The Irving Trust Company announced yesterday that it would continue its role as a clearing bank for a number of dealers in Government securities.
The John B. Stetson Company, one of the oldest American manufacturers of men's hats, confirmed yesterday that it is ending production at its Philadelphia plant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 The Senate ended a long battle over imposing Congressional restrictions on the President's warmaking powers tonight by passing, 70 to 2, a compromise version of a $66.6-billion defense appropriations bill.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 29 (UPI) Lew Alcindor and Bob Dandridge tossed in 23 points each as the Milwaukee Bucks snapped Cleveland's two-game winning streak tonight by defeating the Cavaliers, 119-97, in a National Basketball Association game before the season's largest home crowd, 7,682.

The Coast Guard called off its air search yesterday for 21 missing crewmen from the Panamanian tanker Chryssi, one of two ships disabled in heavy seas in the Atlantic on, Sunday. A search by ships is to resume today.
The discovery of "the finest examples known of a mature fresco art" from the ancient world was announced to an audience of scholars here yesterday by Dr. George E. Mylonas.
Retail business early next year will begin a slow process of improvement, participants in a Wall Street seminar were told yesterday.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 29 Mrs. Helen Marie Chapman, the wife of Bertram D. Chapman, vice president and production director of Newsweek magazine, died of cancer yesterday in Lawrence Hospital; Bronxville. She was 54 years old and lived at 32 Homestead Avenue here.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 An annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science used to be a quiet, dignified and optimistic affair. The nation's established scientists gathered to renew fraternal ties, to report in an arcane language on their research and to speak of "endless frontiers" and the wonders and elegance of science.

Donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund often relate their shock at reading about the needy. Some indicate the stories made them pensive. Beside arousing sympathy, the stories invite comparison with the readers' own lives.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 The Federal Trade Commission accused The Reader's Digest today of deception in the promotion of magazine and book and record club subscriptions.

PERTH, Australia, Dec. 29 (UPI) Australia won the women's Federation Cup in tennis for the fifth time today as 19-year-old Evonne Goolagong and Mrs. Margaret Court led a 3-0 sweep of Britain in 122-degree temperature. Eleven persons in the crowd of 4,200 collapsed from the heat.

Once upon a time, Litton Industries, Inc., raised eyebrows in Wall Street with an unusual treatment of a $23.2million capital gain arising out of the sale of McLean Industries common stock to R.J. Reynolds Industries on May 23, 1969.
J. Bernard Quigley, a member of the law firm of Cahill, Gordon, Sonnett, Reindel Oil of 80 Pine Street, New York, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 46 years old.

CAIRO, Dec. 29 The authoritative Cairo newspaper Al Ahram today hailed the sweeping political and economic reform ordered yesterday by President Anwar el-Sadat as "one of the most important measures taken toward codification of the revolution" of Gamal Abdel Nasser.
ATLANTA, Dec. 29 A feud between a motorcycle gang and hippies erupted in gunfire here today, leaving one man dead and 17 persons charged with murder.

LONDON The British are grumbling at the end of the year about strikes, prices aad other awkward nuisances, but in a world of haters, their grumbling seems almost amiable. Maybe it was just an accident, but the long London garbage strike ended just before the Christmas holidays, and the airline workers shelved their grievances until after the holidays.

Miss Lena M. Biorck, daughter of Dr. Gunnar Biorck, personal physician to King Gustav VI Adolf of Sweden, was married in Stockholm yesterday to Gilbert E. Kaplan of New York, president of Institutional Investor Systems, Inc., a multimedia communications company.

The Mayor's office submitted a budget request of $15-million yesterday for the fiscal year beginning July 1. This is about $950,000 over the figure for the current year.

The arrest of three Staten Islanders and the recovery of $50,000 worth of merchandise allegedly stolen from the Brooklyn waterfront and the Port of Newark was announced yesterday by Edward R. Neaher, United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York.

Edgar Hoover, Director of the F.B.L, and Ramsey Clark, former U.S. Attorney General and Hoover's former boss; also Hoover's somewhat pointless reiteration of a previous charge that Martin Luther King was a liar, bring to the fore a question increasingly posed: "Is it not time for Mr. Hoover to retire?"

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Dec. 29 Sinking 29 field goals in 55 attempts, C. W. Post College gained the final of the fifth annual New Jersey Kiwanis Classic at Panzer Gym tonight, downing Monmouth College, 85-77.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 Three former doctoral chemistry professors, all of whom gave up science for social action, charged the scientific community with decadence and with indifference to and complicity in many of the problems in America today.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Dec. 29 Ed Kochakji of C.W. Post was named the outstanding wrestler for the second straight year and Lock Haven State won three individual titles to highlight the sixth annual C.W. Post invitation wrestling tournament, which ended tonight.

MADRID, Dec. 29 Generalissimo Francisco Franco met with his Cabinet in emergency session today amid a national groundswell of pleas for commutation of the court-martial death sentences imposed on six Basque guerrillas in Burgos yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29 Paul Fitzgerald, chief counsel for the defense in the TateLaBianca murder trial, ended his final argument to the jury today with an emotional plea in behalf of Charles Manson.

BERKELEY, Calf., Dec. 29 (UPI) Brutus Hamilton, a 1920 Olympic medalist in the decathlon, who coached track for 32 years at the University of California, died yesterday in an Oakland hospital after a heart attack. He was 70 years old.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29(UPI) The University of California Los Angeles, beat William and Mary, 90-71, tonight to advance to the final of the Steel Bow tournament against Pitt.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 29(AP) The Baltimore Colts' defensive line, a marvel of patchwork all season is hale and hearty again just in time for the American Football Conference championship game Sunday against the Oakland Raiders.

PARIS Dec. 29 A 22-nation economic organization predicted today a "fairly strong" expansion in the United States next year with a "sharp rebound" in foreign purchases of American corporate securities.
CAMDEN, Maine, Dec. 29 (AP) Cary W. Bok, retired treasurer and senior vice president of the Curtis Publishing Company, died today at his home here. He was 65 years old.

Senior officials of at least one major New York City bank are planning to resign from their positions as trustees of competing mutual savings banks. This was the principal development yesterday in the wake of the proposal by the Federal Reserve Board that Section 8 of the Clayton Act be broadened to prohibit interlocking directorships between all types of institutions that accept deposits.
Prices and volume on the American Stock Exchange rose as trading reached its most active level in almost three months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) The Agriculture Department, ending a two-year series of cutbacks, announced today that 1971 rice acreage allotments would remain at this year's level. The reprieve from a further reduction resulted mainly from an improved rice-export situation.
Preliminary indications are that the explosion that tore through the Humble Oil and Refining Company in Linden, N. J., on Dec. 5 was an accident not sabotage.

DACCA, Pakistan Average life expectancy on the Ganges Delta Islands is less than 40 years. A quarter of the children die of cholera, smallpox, typhoid and other diseases, before they are 5. Tuberculosis is like the common cold.
Bernhard J. Springer president of the Springer Publishing Company of this city, died Saturday of a brain tumor at his home, 80 Central Park West. He was 63 years old.
The National Liberty Corporation, which a couple of weeks ago named Doyle Dane Bernbach to its agency lineup, yesterday announced that it will also add Harvey Carlson.

Three old pros Jerry West, Wilt Chamberlain and Oscar Robertson were named yesterday as members of the West squad for the National Basketball Association's 21st annual All-Star game on Tuesday, Jan. 12, in San Diego.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 29 (AP) Four Seasons Nursing Centers of America, Inc., operated at a loss of more than $1-million during the quarter ended Nov. 30, according to court records.

New York City policemen have been ordered not to enforce the state Sabbath law, which bans the sale of some items during certain hours on Sunday, except to act on specific complaints.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. (UPI) Senator Gordon Allott asked the Justice Department today to investigate whether a Kennedy Administration official in the Post Office had been involved in "a scandal of major proportions" in the awarding of contracts to an air taxi company.
Federal officials investigating the crash Monday of a Boeing 727 jetliner in the Virgin Islands concentrated yesterday on the plane's right leading gear.
LONDON, Dec. 29 With the imperative slogan "Think decimal," Britain will begin a $3-million advertising campaign tomorrow to prepare the public for the change to decimal currency on Feb. 15.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., said yesterday that it expected a 9 per cent drop in earnings this year, on sales that would be close to the $3.6billion registered in 1969.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass For more than five decades, Norman Rockwell has furnished the memories of millions with stenciled rocking chairs and horsehair sofas, slant-front desks and potbellied stoves. These vestiges of early America, symbols of what the 76-year-old illustrator calls "those happier, more hopeful times," are now, in many cases, merely props with no more of a known provenance than their existence on old Saturday Evening Post covers.
Mrs. Yetta Shor Rubenstein, widow oaf Frank Rubenstein, a co-founder of the Franklin Stores Corporation, died yesterday in San Antonio, Tex., her winter home. She was 78 years old.

The Rev. Francis E. Bowen, a member of the Jesuit order since 1909, who taught philosophy at Fordham University from 1940 to 1965, died Saturday in a Poughkeepsie (N.Y.) hospital after a long illness. He was 79 years old.
About 1,050 people have died in New York City from narcotic-related causes this year the most in a single year in the city's history.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29 Harold Jacob Smith, an Oscarwinning screen ,writer, died yesterday of a coronary attack in the Kaiser Permanente Hospital in Panorama City in the San Fernando Valley. He was 56 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine has asked for a meeting with top Soviet officials during his tour of Europe and the Middle East, beginning next Sunday.
Wheat and soybean futures prices advanced shortly after the opening of trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, but profit taking thereafter trimmed much of the advance.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 Governor Rockefeller has decided not to disclose his tax plans in his opening-day "state of the state" message to the 194th Legislature here next week, preferring to wait until President Nixon addresses the new Congress next month.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 (AP) Dave Wohl, one of two "small" men on Penn's towering baskeball team scored 25 points as the sixth-ranked Quakers defeated Temple, 76-55 tonight to win the 10th annual Quaker City tournament.

BOSTON, Dec. 29 A Pulitzer prize-winning historian told a convention of historians today that their profession was in bad disarray, suffering "decay from within" and a precipitate erosion of professional standards and scholarly methods.

Bernard Cornfeld, former chairman of Investors Overseas Services, said in an interview yesterday that he was "seriously considering" waging a proxy fight to re-establish his dominance over the giant mutual-fund complex.

WATERFORD, Va., Dec. 29 Frederick B. Bate, who retired in 1949 from the National Broadcasting Company, died Friday at his home here of arteriosclerosis. He was 84 years old. A memorial service was held here today.

Arthur Ashley, manager of the Percy Williams Home, an organization in East Islip, L.I., named for the actor, that takes care of aged and indigent performers, died on Monday in East Islip. He was 85 years old.

The RCA Corporation announced yesterday that it would increase prices by 6 to 12 per cent on selected types of pencil tubes, cathode ray tubes, photomultipliers, super power tubes, photo diodes and image orthicons used in industrial and broadcast applications.

Julian Bond, Democratic member of the Georgia House of Representatives, was in New York yesterday as advance man for a new six-part Westinghouse Broadcasting Company television series, "Rush Toward Freedom," which begins next week. He is its host-narrator.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 (AP) Justice Samuel Rabin of Queens was designated by Governor Rockefeller yesterday as presiding justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, Second Department, to succeed Justice Marcus G. Christ.
Noise limits so strict that they would bar all present jet aircraft from landing here were proposed yesterday by the city's Commissioner of Air Resources, Dr. Robert N. Rickles.

The London Stock Exchange was firm in slack conditions yesterday. Selective buying of leading issues pushed prices up following initial uncertainty brought an by the anti-inflationary economic curbs urged by the organization for Economic Cooperation and De velopment.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 29 Miss Linda R. Baker and Leighton Howe Laughlin Jr., seniors at Colorado College, were married this afternoon at the Princeton University Chapel.

Now that the factories have withdrawn from the pony division of the TransAmerican Championship, the Sports Car Club of America is hoping the smaller TransAm sedans will catch on. The club has even invented an engaging name for them, the Two Five Challenge.

Two former heavyweight champions, Max Schmeling and Ezzard Charles, and the late Harry Wills, who never got a shot at the title, were named yesterday to the Boxing Hall of Fame.

HONG KONG, Dec. 29 Communist China today restated in emphatic terms the claim it announced early this month to the exclusive control of oil and other mineral deposits under the continental shelf extending off the coast.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 29 Mrs. Minnie Geiler Uihlein, the widow of August E. Uihlein, who had been president of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company of Milwaukee, died today in the Uihlein Mercy Center here. The center, built by the Uihlein family, cares for the ill and aged.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) Striking Mohawk Airline pilots today rejected a company offer that a spokesman for the regional carrier said would have added more than $3-million to pilot costs over the next year.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29 The Supreme Court of the Russian Republic announced today that it would hear appeals tomorrow of 11 persons nine of them Jews who were convicted of treason in Leningrad last week for planning to hijack a Soviet airliner.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 The Republican State Committee, which unlike its Democratic counterpart normally meets in an atmosphere of peace, tranquility and harmony, found itself in the middle of a dispute when it convened here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec.29 The Senate returned the supersonic transport controversy to a House-Senate conference tonight without formal instructions as to a possible com promise in the month-long SST impasse.

Paul Brown, who led the Cincinnati Bengals to a division title in the third season of their existence, was named the American Football Conference's coach of the year yesterday by United Press International.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) The House sent to President Nixon today a bill to establish an 18,000-acre Gulf Islands National Seashore off the coasts of Mississippi and Florida.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) An admiral being retired by the Coast Guard told a Congressional hearing today that he was concerned about fishing talks with the Soviet Union when the recommended returning to the Russians a Lithuanian sailor who tried to defect.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 The Government index of "leading indicators" rose in November, the Commerce Department reported today, but the widely hailed upturn in October turned out, after later figures were available, to have been a small decline.

Every summer for the last five years a group of young musicians have a gathered in New Hampshire's Monadnock region for several weeks of relaxed, informal music-making. Although not yet as prestigious as their senior colleagues, Serkin Casals, et al, across the border in Marlboro, Vt., these youthful professionals have already enriched New England's summer music scene.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 The marriage of Miss Sarah Ferguson and Melvin Eugene McClain, students at the University of New Mexico, took place in St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square, here this afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Wagner, assisted by the Rev. Dr. John C. Harper, rector of the church. A small reception followed at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. John H. Ferguson.
Bond prices drifted lower and interest rates inched a little higher yesterday as the credit markets continued to dawdle through the last few trading days of 1970.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 Mrs. Beatrice Blair Sibley and Richard Lewis Epstein, both of Rochester, were married here today. The Rev. Joel Baehr, former minister of the Unitarian Church in Rochester, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Montgomery Blair. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Harry Browdy Epstein of Yonkers and the late Mr. Epstein, who was a lawyer.

ATHENS, Dec. 29 The military-backed regime challenged the motives today of Elias Demetracopoulos, an exiled Greek journalist who asked three United States Senators to help him obtain a safe-conduct pass to enable him to visit his dying father in Athens.

ATLANTA, Dec. 29 (AP) Eighth-ranked Arizona State, an explosive undefeated power with enough speed to help most track teams, tangles with North Carolina and an all-America tailback, Don McCauley, tomorrow night in the third annual Peach Bowl football game.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 29 The Eritrean Liberation front, which is waging a guerrilla war against the Ethiopian Government of Emperor Haile Selassie, has called for urgent international intervention to end what it described as the "mass annihilation of Eritreans."
Following is the text of a statement by Mayor Lindsay yesterday in which he rejected the initial budget request by the city's Human Resources Administration:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 With only a few days left to complete its legislative business, Congress spent hours today eulogizing the departed and the departing and accommodating members who had television engagements or other personal commitments.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 29 (AP) Pablo Casals celebrated his 94th birthday today. He was in a hospital early this year with a kidney infection, but he is said to be in sound health now.

American Ballet Theater, opening the second week of its brief season at the New York City Center, last night moved into its general repertory with a bill consisting of Fokine's "Les Sylphides," Josh Limon's "The Moor's Pavane," Alvin Ailey's "The River" and George Balanchine's "Theme and Variations."

PARIS The only King who ever died in the United States was Peter II, former sovereign of Yugoslavia, who expired Nov. 3, 1970, in Denver, Colo. He left behind an inaccurate death certificate and a will including such curious provisions that some of his family suspect it might have been drafted when he was of unsound mind.
CAIRO, Dec. 29 President Anwar el-Sadat ordered today that the home front of United Arab Republic be put in a state of readiness for war.

Newly announced scientific results are best approached cautiously until they have been duplicated and verified by independent researchers. But, even with that caution in mind, the advance in brain chemistry just reported by Dr. George Ungar of Baylor College of Medicine will intrigue many and stimulate further related research.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 Senator William E. Adams, the Kenmore Republican who was acquitted last April of perjury charges but who lost his bid for re-election, was named today as general counsel of the State Board of Standards and Appeals.

The storm of protest stirred by the outcome of the Leningrad hijacking trial continued unabated yesterday as individuals and groups denounced the sentences and appealed to the Soviet leadership for clemency.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) Senator Warren G. Magnuson has asked Elliot L. Richardson, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, to investigate and answer charges that the Food and Drug Administration ignored the findings of its own scientists on possible food dangers.

Physicians who attended Representative L. Mendel Rivers said yesterday that the 65year-old South Carolina Democrat had probably been a victim of rheumatic heart disease. Mr. Rivers, who was chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, died Monday at the University of Alabama Hospital in Birmingham after openheart-surgery.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 Further evidence of the dramatic change in the mortgage market came today as the Federal National Mortgage Association reported it had not received enough offers to sell mortgages at its biweekly auction to take up all the funds made available.

George Kennan's reflections on a suitable international strategy for dealing with the admitted evils of apartheid are echoes of familiar pleas and warnings often voiced by architects of that rigid scheme of repressive laws and measures, which defined individual opportunities and burdens of life solely in terms of the accident of race and color.

The formal announcement originally had been scheduled for yesterday, but was postponed until noon today at Toots Shor's. At 1:52 P.M. the silver bell in the run-down fire house on Watkins Street in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn clanged out its number code.
ST. PAUL, Dec. 29 (AP) A Federal judge today imposed maximum, five-year prison sentences on three young men convicted of breaking into Minnesota draft offices.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Dec. 29 John J. Burns, Democratic state chairman, announced today that he would join a new public relations firm in New York City, on Jan. 1 but planned to continue in his $30,000-ayear party post.

TOKYO, Dec. 29 (AP) North Vietnam said today that defoliants dumped by United States, aircraft in South Vietnam had caused millions of people to suffer the same fate as victims of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki atomic blasts in World War II.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 29 Palestinian Arab guerillas operating from Jordan, Syria and Lebanon stepped up their harassment of Israel overnight.

The Metropolitan Museum's Centennial spectacular, the biggest and longest show ever put on by the venerable institution, is nearly over. When its last exhibition ends on March 21, the Centennial will quietly fade away, and operations at the face-lifted Beaux Arts edifice on upper Fifth Avenue will settle back into what one staff member calls "a peace-time economy."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 29 A new strain has been added to the already uneasy alliance between Cambodia and South Vietnam over Pnompenh's need to relieve its critical fuel shortage by importing gas and oil through South Vietnam by way of the Mekong River.
Legislation was introduced yesterday in the City Council For an additional taxicab meter charge of 25 cents between 8 P.M. and 6 A.M.

UAL, Inc., the holding company for United Air Lines, has announced the election of Edward E. Carlson as president of the airline subsidiary. Mr. Carlson was recently elected as president and chiefs executive officer of UAL, Inc. He succeeds GeorgeE. Keck, who resigned his position with the airline and the presidency of UAL, Inc., on Dec. 21.

Transformer trouble that delayed thousands of Manhattanbound Long Island Railroad commuters on Monday was reported cleared up yesterday. But riders of the Long Island, the Penn Central and the subways experienced other difficulties.

Earnings of the Grand Union Company in the 13 weeks ended Nov. 28 were $3,728,989, slightly exceeding the record $3,720,929 earned in the similar period last year, the food and general merchandise retailing chain reported yesterday.

Mayor Lindsay's rejection of the proposed budget for the Human Resources Administration is a despairing acknowledgement that New York City is in danger of collapse under the staggering weight of its welfare burden.

What with eligible young women announcing they can no longer relate to formal debuts and the stock market stump giving parents second thoughts about expense, it looked as though the big debutante bash might be on the wane this year. In fact, the Mistletoe Ball, which dated back to 1957 and was scheduled for Dec. 22, was canceled for lack of interest.

Continental Air Lines, Inc., which last month raised its offer to acquire Western Air Lines, disclosed yesterday it had filed a series of documents with the Civil Aeronautics Board in Washington in an attempt to block Western's merger into American Airlines, Inc. Continental is asking the C.A.B.
What started out as a bland game between the New York Rangers and the California Golden Seals last night at Madison Square Garden developed into a spirited encounter that increased in interest.
Spokesmen for the National Conference of Black Lawyers said yesterday that they planned to try to get the Army to rescind its decision to give a destitute black soldier a badconduct discharge.
After almost six weeks of talking about basketball on Knick radio and television shows, Cazzie Russell returned yesterday to playing basketball.

WOODSTOCK, N. Y., Dec. 29 Dr. William King Gregory, an ichthyologist and paleontologist who had been associated for many years with the American Museum of Natural History and with Columbia University, died after, surgery here this afternoon. He was 94 years old.
Judging from what some magazine publishers are saying, the first quarter doesn't look that bad. And isn't it about time?

DACCA, Pakistan Munshi's wife cries all the time now. She sits in the flimsy lean-to her husband has pieced together from the debris of the storm, hidden from strangers in the Moslem tradition. Her breasts ache because the baby is no longer there to nurse.

RUMSON, N.J., Dec. 29 Jacob White, who retired in 1964 as president of the Nitrogen Division of the Allied Chemical Corporation, died yesterday of a heart attack yesterday in Riverview Hospital, Red Bank. He was 71 years old and lived here at 168 Brigham Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 The Interstate Commerce Commission said today that the national railroad passenger network proposed last month by the Department of Transportation was inadequate and misleading with respect to the further service reductions it might allow.

The New York chapter of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences presented awards to eight local programs and to two individuals last night. The awards covered the broadcast period from Sept. 1, 1969 to Aug. 31, 1970, and were seen here last night over WNET, Channel 13.

Congress has passed and sent to the White House the long-awaited legislation to protect investors from brokerage firm failures. The bill establishes a Governmentbacked institution called the Securities Investor Protection , Corporation (SIPC), which will insure customers' accounts up to $50,000.

The city's firemen, who have been threatening a "job action" unless they have a new contract by Friday, plan to continue to answer alarms of fire and emergency but to curtail other services, according to a guide circulated among members of the Uniformed Firefighters Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI) Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt, the Chief of Naval Operations, has abolished the long-standing requirement that an officer must hold a major command at sea before he is promoted to admiral, the Navy said today.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29 Gov. Ronald Reagan's recent decision to veto $1.8-million in Federal funds for California Rural Legal Assistance, the nation's largest legal services program, raises two key questions about public efforts to give the poor some control over their lives.
A make-believe horse room on wheels, set up shop yesterday in Forest Hills, Queens.

DETROIT, Dec. 29 Inflationary wage settlements are likely to continue unless the Federal Government intervenes, and "conditions are likely to get much more serious" before such intervention comes, Roy L. Reierson, senior vice president and chief economist of The Bankers Trust Company of New York, said today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 29 (AP) Spokesmen said here that South Vietnamese troops had beaten back an enemy ground attack just inside Cambodia today, killing 74 of the attackers while losing 10 dead. But other enemy forces were reported to have staged coordinated attacks on points along three of the five main highways leading to Cambodian capital of Pnompenh.
SHARON, Conn., Dec. 29 Stayman L. Reed, a limited partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of J. W. Seligman Co., died last night in Sharon Hospital after a short illness. He was 75 years old.

A top-level management reorganization at F. I. duPont, Glore Forgan Co., one of Wall Street's largest brokerage houses, has resulted in the replacement of its two highest officers, including Edmund duPont, son of the founder.

By its last actions of 1970, Greece's military dictatorship has rendered even more ludicrous the claims of its apologists in Washington that it has established a "trend toward a constitutional order." SYDNEY, Dec. 29 (UPI) The New Zealand yacht Buccaneer, sailed by her owner, Tom Clarke, was the first to finish do the Sydney-Hobart race today, with a time of 3 days 14 hours 6 minutes 12 seconds.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 29 (AP) Notre Dame upset nationally ranked Kentucky, 9992, tonight, getting a 50-point outburst by its sharpshooting. guard, Austin Carr.
The stock market yesterday moved higher for the fifth consecutive session as some leading market averages finished at new 1970 highs in the heaviest trading in almost four weeks.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 (UPI) The Federal appeals court that had earlier ordered bail for the Seattle Seven conspiracy defendants said in effect today that all must stay in jail until Jan. 4.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 A study of defoliation in Vietnam, undertaken for the American Association for the Advancement of Science, has shown a catastrophic effect on some parts of the country.

Bridge is played in almost every part of the civilized world. The only major exception has been the Soviet Union, whose authorities have long encouraged chess, but have held the opinion that cardplaying is a capitalist gambling activity that might distract the workers from more serious pursuits.

As governments throughout Europe appealed to Spain to spare the lives of six Basque separatists condemned to death, the conviction of the Basques prompted work stoppages, boycotts and other acts of protest yesterday.

Bernard G. Walpin, a New York lawyer, pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday to a charge of conspiracy to defraud the Federal Housing Administration in the financing of a cooperative housing project in Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) The United States has engaged in activities in Vietnam for which Germany and Japan were prosecuted after World War II, a legal authority said today.

The seasonally adjusted Dodge index of construction contract value advanced 13 per cent to 202 in November, the first month since last August that the index was above 200 (195759 equals 100).

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 President Nixon signed today an occupational health and safety bill giving the Secretary of Labor authority to set safety standards for factories, farms and construction sites and creating a three-member panel to enforce the standards.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) The Rev. George W. Baber, a presiding bishop of the African Methodist Episcopal Church and an advocate of church involvement in social causes, died Saturday in Washington Hospital Center of an embolism. He was 72 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 Congress took a halting step toward adjournment today as the Senate approved, 81 to 0, a Social Security bill that had been stripped of virtually all controversial extraneous proposals. The measure would increase benefits $7.5-billion.

CHARLESTON, W.Va., Dec. 30--John D. Rockefeller 4th announced today that he would seek the abolition of strip mining in this state "completely and forever" to save it from "the spreading cancer" of surface despoliation by the coal industry.
