SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 11 -- The 18-month-old "cold war" between the Navy and the tiny island of Culebra ended in a truce today as Secretary of the Navy John H. Chafee signed an agreement that surrenders most of the Navy's control over the island.

The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, after almost a year of behind-the-scenes activity, announced yesterday that it had completed its proposed new guidelines to reform accounting procedures in the life-insurance industry. The long-expected move followed by only a few days the announcement by Investors Diversified Services, the largest mutual-fund organization in the country, that it was changing to the new method of accounting in its life-insurance operations.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced unusually large price increases yesterday on products used in construction and shipbiulding. At the same time, the company abandoned an industry policy, which had been initiated by Bethlehem, guaranteeing that no product would be raised in price more than one a year.

Any concert program on which the most familiar piece is Webern's Five Movements for String Quartet (Op. 5) starts off promisingly in these days when creeping standardization is a knife held at traditional music's throat.

The financial fortunes of Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer, Inc., have taken a turn for the better with earnings for the first fiscal quarter ended Nov. 21 marking the best since the second quarter of fiscal 1968, the report of James T. Aubrey Jr., president, disclosed yesterday.

ARNHEM, the Netherlands, Jan. 11 -- Prospects have improved for the resolution of two major monetary questions -- ways to make it easier for countries to change their currency parities and the problem of establishing a single currency area in the European Economic Community.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The United States Supreme Court refused today to grant a hearing on an appeal to reverse a $612,000 judgment against a former board chairman of the Cudahy Company in a stock deal involving insider information.

CARSON CITY, Nev., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Nevada has dropped 22 per cent of its welfare recipients -- about 3,000 men, women and children -- on grounds that they have been cheating the state at a rate of about $1-million a year, according to George Miller, the state welfare director.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- James R. Hoffa, the imprisoned president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, lost his bid to avert a new five-year prison term today as the Supreme Court refused to hear his appeal of a conviction for diverting union pension funds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI) -- United States domestic flights will have to be as thoroughly screened as international flights if airplane hijackings continue, the chief of civil aviation security said today.

Future prices of commodities traded on the Chicago Board of Trade opened on an irregular tone yesterday, weakened and then rallied about mid-session to close mixed.

"The entire new year will be better than 1970, but I'm afraid spring won't be," David Suskind, a Virginia retailer, asserted yesterday. The senior vice president and treasurer of Miller Rhoads, Richmond, added, "The strong Christmas windup is to me a definite augury for a good tempo in 1971, even though it apparently won't occur right away."

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 11 -- The Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, general secretary of the World Council of Churches, called today for increased contacts between his organization and Jewish religious leaders, including talks in the sensitive area of the content of religious belief.

HOUSTON, Jan. 11 -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association urged member schools today to put into effect a three-point plan aimed at cuting costs of intercollegiate athletics, particularly football and basketball.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 11 -- One recent afternoon as Derek Curtis Bok, dean of the Harvard Law School, was lunching with friends in the student cafeteria he wondered out loud why it wasn't possible to make a hamburger that did not taste like plastic and still sell for less than a dollar. Soon the personable 40-year-old dean, who has a degree in economics, was pouring over figures with the cafeteria manager.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President Nixon ordered into effect today a $2.6-billion reduction in the taxes that will be paid by businesses this year.

The spokesman for the Soviet Mission to the United Nations said that Soviet diplomats had been followed yesterday on foot and by car "by gangs of hoodlums" from the Jewish Defense League as major Jewish leaders and Government officials condemned harassment of Russians in the United States.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Frank Verdi, who managed the Syracuse Chiefs of the International Baseball League to a sweep of minor league championships last season, has terminated his contract with the New York Yankees.

PNOMPENH, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, flew to Pnompenh from Saigon today and conferred with Cambodian and American officials on the military situation in Cambodia.
The bull market, to paraphrase Mark Twain, proved yesterday that recent reports of its demise were grossly exaggerated.

MISATO, Okinawa, Wednesday, Jan. 13 (Reuters) -- The United States Army today began moving 150 tons of mustard gas from its Chibana ammunition depot in central Okinawa for shipment to Johnston Island, 750 miles southwest of Hawaii.
As the New York State Assembly got down to business this week, the dead hand of the past was omnipresent.

Rabbi Meir D. Kahane, the leader of the militant Jewish Defense League, was arrested yesterday in the organization's midtown office on a Criminal Court bench warrant issued after he failed to appear for a hearing on riot charges.
Sometime before the 1971 baseball season starts, a computer in Timmins, Ontario, may tell the Mets whether they can regain their championship this year.
SEATTLE, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Ralph Wilson Jr., owner of the Buffalo Bills, told Seattle area officials today he was "very serious" in his desire to move his National Football League team here.
Carl Spielvogel, executive vice president and general manager of McCann-Erickson, has been elected to the additional job of chairman of the executive committee.
PARIS, Jan. 12 -- President Pompidou's policy of building up French prestige and power in the Mediterranean is in trouble at one of its principal points of application, Algeria.

Much attention is paid to the unique but current phenomenon of recession, bordering on depression, combined with inflation. But one aspect of inflation, which is both a symptom and a cause, is being overlooked. That aspect is inflation through the declining quality of goods and services received.

The Polaroid Corporation, which has been under attack for its dealings in South Africa, has announced a one-year "experiment" there to improve the salaries, job opportunities and education of a group of blacks.

The trial and conviction in camera of eleven Russians for the alleged hijacking of a Soviet airliner once again raises grave doubts about the moral validity of the movement for detente between this country and the U.S.S.R.
HANOI, North Vietnam -- Troops throng this capital city, crowding its stores and markets and idling in its lakeside cafes.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 12 -- The Dallas Cowboys began their final series of practices today for Sunday's Super Bowl game against Baltimore, and Calvin Hill, all but forgotten the last two months, was back in the spotlight. Hill, the Yale alumnus voted the Na- tional League's rookie of the year in 1969, was running in the first backfield with the 1970 rookie who took his job away, Duane Thomas.

QUANGTRI, South Vietnam Jan. 12 (UPI) -- A fourth Negro soldier has been arrested with the slaying of one white major and the wounding of another following an argument over a loudly playing stereo phonograph, United States military sources said today.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Selwyn Lloyd, Conservative party Foreign Minister during the 1956 Suez crisis, was elected Speaker of the House of Commons today in an unexpected contest as Parliament reconvened.

Budget-priced modern furnishings are emphasized in Macy's winter furnishings show in the store's enlarged (by about one-third) collection of "The Affordables." (in the past, this show has concentrated on design or decor.
Jackie DeShannon, a small, slim girl whose straight, blond hair floods down across her shoulders, is making her New York cafe debut at the Copacabana, but she is no neophyte.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- With both Republicans and Democrats praising New York City's interim Board of Education, the Senate unanimously passed today and sent to the Assembly a bill that extends the board's life for another year.

Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, charged yesterday that the education budget proposed for 1971-72 by Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner was a "standstill budget" that did not meet the needs of the school system.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A retired Army general, named during an extensive Congressional investigation of military corruption, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of illegal firearms transactions and income tax evasion.

The six young men from the Jewish Defense League were standing on the northwest corner of 67th Street and Third Avenue, waiting for Russians to harass. Policemen and wooden barricades kept them out of 67th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues, where the Soviet Mission to the United Nations is situated.

In the wake of President Nixon's televised statement that his budget for fiscal 1972 would be in deficit but that expenditures would not exceed "full - employment revenues," there has been a spreading wave of skepticism, on the part of people who just don't believe that there is any such thing as a full-employment surplus, and fear that the President is playing games with them.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Undeterred by Governor Rockefeller's campaign for more Federal aid, the mayors of the state's six largest cities called today for "decisive state action" to aid the cities.

GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Francoise Macchi, 19 years old, led another French sweep today in the first special slalom of the 33d Grindelwald ski races. Six French girls finished among the top 10.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations intermediary on the Middle East, conferred today with the representatives of Jordan and Israel amid indications that a climate of serious negotiations was developing.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 -- A regulated rate reduction in interest paid to savers is quietly being considered in the savings and loan industry.

Anchormen for the three major television networks agreed yesterday that the networks have not been intimidated by Vice President Agnew; that they were professionals committed to objectivity and fairness, and that President Nixon is an adept television performer.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The 1970 rise in Christmas retail sales was far stronger than in 1969, the chief Commerce Department economist reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark will meet tomorrow with Vice President Agnew to plead for a "massive infusion of Federal funds" to head off a deepening financial crisis for his and other cities.

STEWKLEY, England, Jan 21 -- Agatha Christie's Miss Marple, that shrewd exemplar of village life, could live in Stewkley. It typifies the miraculous survival of village and countryside in this populous island.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 12 -- Christians around the world face an urgent new need to promote dialogue with members of the other major religions, according to Protestant and Eastern Orthodox leaders gathered here for a meeting of the World Council of Churches.
Gifts totaling $58,183.43 from 376 contributors were recorded yesterday by the Neediest Cases Fund, bringing to $765,980.40 the amount collected during the 59th annual appeal.
Irwin Shaw, the novelist, received the "best major work" award at Playboy magazine's annual writer's awards luncheon yesterday at the 21 Club, 21 West 52d Street.
Regular classes were resumed yesterday at troubled Julia Richman High School with about two-thirds of the school's 4,600 students attending.

The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and the Franklin New York Corporation reported increased earnings yesterday for the fourth quarter of 1970. The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, parent of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, said its net income rose by 5.4 per cent from the level in the 1969 period while income before securities transactions climbed 7.6 per cent.

TEL AVIV, Jan. 12 -- The Israeli authorities reported today that a ring of Arabs that included employes of the United Nations was among the espionage and sabotage cells smashed in the Jerusalem area in the last three weeks.
The New York Mailer Union No. 6 got a court order last night staying The Daily News from changing its press run schedules pending a hearing tomorrow in Manhattan Supreme Court.

The Federal Government is taking steps to speed up industry's "extremely slow rate" of progress in hiring and promoting minority workers, but the National Association of Manufacturers does not like the way it's being done.
The furor over the granting of credit and the increasing role of bank credit cards are causing many merchants to wonder if they can still regard credit as "the retailer's best friend."
Your Jan. 8 editorial "Arrogance of Power" is antagonistic and misleading.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Santa Clara County grand jury says that it has concluded its investigation into the stone-throwing, demonstration here against. President Nixon's campaign motorcade Oct. 29 and that no felony charges will be filed.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 -- When this city's upper-echelon society and the level that includes Hollywood learned a couple of years ago that there was to be a Ford in its future, everyone seemed genuinely delighted.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- The first problem in the critical negotiations here for peace in the Middle East is to get rid of the threats and maneuvers that make serious negotiation impossible.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Nixon Administration moved today to weld 40 million American women into "a people's lobby for highway safety" that would sweep drunken or drinking drivers off the nation's highways.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 -- The trial of Charles M. Manson and the three women who are accused of having carried out the murders that he allegedly ordered neared an end today with the completion of two weeks of defense summations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that state and local welfare officials could insist on the right to inspect the homes of welfare recipients and could cut off the benefits of those who refused to let them in.
Detectives posing as airline pilots last night raided what they said was a $100,000-a-day gambling operation n a luxury apartment in Forest Hills, Queens. Three men were arrested.

In Puccini's "La Boheme," Parpignol is a harmless vender of toys on Christmas Eve outside the Cafe Momus in Paris. In Frank Corsaro's staging of the opera, presented at the Hunter College Playhouse on Monday night, Parpignol has become a seller of dirty French postcards. As well as anything, this indicates the spirit of the production.

The Justice Department yesterday denied charges that Attorney General John N. Mitchell had intervened to ease the penalties against General Motors for polluting the Hudson River at its plant in North Tarrytown, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Jan. 13 -- The Rev. Walter E. Fauntroy, a 37-year-old Baptist minister who rose to prominence as an aide to the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., took a long stride yesterday toward becoming the District of Columbia's first nonvoting delegate to Congress in more than 90 years.

An interviewing panel wanted to know whether Georgia Louisa McMurray thought she could handle the job of creating a new city agency to promote opportunities and services for the city's 825,000 preschool children.

As the strike by 15,000 telephone repairmen, installers and other mechanics went into its second day, the New York Telephone Company charged yesterday that 800 phones had been put out of service in Brooklyn by sabotage.
When Walter Oechsle went to Japan a few months before Expo he was already convinced that the celebrated Japanese miracle of economic growth was a sometime thing.
An increase of 6,630 persons on the city's welfare rolls during November, the lowest rise in six months, was reported yesterday by Henry J. Rosner, Assistant Commissioner of Social Services.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Joe Kapp, the Boston Patriots' quarterback, became today the first active professional football player called before a Federal grand jury investigating National Football League operations. He testified for two hours.

BRUSSELS -- A few days ago Regis Debray, the young French leftist who has accepted a position in Chile's new regime, boasted that the Chilean revolution would have repercussions in Europe.

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 12 -- Many developing Asian lands face gloomy prospects both politically and economically in the years immediately ahead, according to views expressed by authorities on the area who concluded a week-long conference here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Two legal organizations accused state and local school officials today of gross misuse of Federal funds earmarked for the education of Indian children.
The president of the largest United States seamen's union called today for a three-point passenger-ship safety program based on the "urgent warning in the near tragedy" of the cruise liner Antilles.

The once-heralded stability of the boys' apparel business has disappeared in favor of a much more volatile industry, the president of Sears, Roebuck Co. said yesterday.

Leaders of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People charged yesterday that there was an "obvious effort to deny the presumption of innocence and thereby convict Miss Angela Davis of murder long before the first witness has been called."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The National Endowment for the Arts will lay $1-million in Federal funds on the line this year to help the country's museums -- more than the endowment has spent on them over the five years of its existence.

Mazowsze, the first-rate song - and - dance company from Poland, opened a two-week engagement at the City Center last night. Directed by Mira Ziminska-Sygietynska, the folk company has conserved its tastefulness and freshness and is composed on this visit, its third, of an extremely attractive group of young dancers, singers and musicians.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Five young military officers said today that they were asking the Secretaries of the Army and the Navy to convene formal courts of inquiry into the question of war crimes and atrocities in Vietnam.

THE HAGUE, Jan. 12 -- Roman Catholic Bishops in the Netherlands yielded to Vatican pressure tonight and decided to accept the controversial 39-year-old Dr. Adrien Simonis as the new Bishop of Rotterdam.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 12 -- Expressions of anger against the Government of King Hussein in Jordan came today from several parts of the Arab world.

MOSCOW, Jan. 12 -- Yehuda-Leib Levin, the Chief Rabbi of Moscow, signed a petition today accusing militant Jewish groups in the United States of "emulating Fascists" in their tactics. The petition said Soviet Jews did not want such "unsolicited protectors."

Airline take-offs and landings at Kennedy International Airport decreased 15.8 per cent in 1970 below the 1969 volume, reflecting the impact of the nation's economic recession and of the Boeing 747 jumbo jet on air travel.
Speaking of "a crisis in the housing of welfare families," Mayor Lindsay yesterday outlined plans to ease "the tragic conditions" in so-called welfare hotels.

MOSCOW, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Pyotr F. Abolimov has been named head of the Moscow State Circus. He had been deputy director of the Bolshoi Theater and the Theater of the Kremlin Palace of Congresses, and the circus job was considered a demotion.
Mayor Lindsay invited Federal officials yesterday to a first-hand inspection of the Model Cities program here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- In another major step in the recent dramatic decline of interest rates, the Government announced today the second reduction in six weeks in the ceiling interest rate on home mortgages backed by the Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Administration.
Lightly raced Hoist the Flag was honored with high weight of 126 pounds in the annual Experimental Handicap ratings announced yesterday by The Jockey Club.

Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio said yesterday that Mayor Lindsay would block three consulting contracts totaling $200,000, requested by Controller Abraham D. Beame, unless Mr. Beame removed the contracts from consideration by the Board of Estimate.

A series of 11 vintage films dating back to 1914 will be shown from tomorrow through Jan. 25, at the Museum of Modern Art. James Card, curator of the George Eastman House film collection in Rochester, which is lending the films to the museum, will introduce the program at 8 P.M. tomorrow.
New York horsemen took a significant step forward yesterday in their campaign to develop a workable pension fund for stablehands at Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Evonne Goolagong, Australian aboriginal tennis star, has accepted an invitation to play in the South African open championship in April, the tournament organizer, Owen Williams, said today.

We have here two works of fiction -- one a first novel, the other a collection of stories by an established European writer. But they do have this in common: Both are works of extreme talent, fresh and original.

The MacDonnell Douglas Corporation announced yesterday plans to acquire 100 per cent control of the Conductron Corporation and the Hycon Manufacturing Company, two companies in which it already has a large interest.
Every weekday 40 to 50 New Yorkers find their way to an unprepossessing building at 325 Hudson Street in lower Manhattan to confront cab drivers they have accused of mistreating them.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Mayor Peter F. Flaherty, dressed in old clothes, helped haul garbage from 12 hospitals and schools today to comply with a court ruling that the waste created a health hazard.

The Lindsay administration retreated yesterday from the taxi-fare package that formed the financial basis for the settlement of last month's taxi strike, agreeing to drop the 25-cent charge it had suggested for each additional rider.

Gamal El-Zoghby, like other architectural designers, used his own home as a launching pad for an unconventional interior design concept, both to test its practicality and to promote its sale to others.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The White House denied today that it was preparing for a reelection campaign by President Nixon in 1972 and Attorney General John N. Mitchell said he did not intend to be a political tutor.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 12 -- A fall-away jump shat that hung on the rim for a second or two before rolling into the basket proved the difference tonight as the West defeated the East 108-107, in the 21st annual All-Star Game at International Sports Arena.

THAIBINH, North Vietnam -- In what appears to be a calculated shift of emphasis, thousands of young North Vietnamese men and women of military conscription age have been assigned to development of the home front.

Last night's duocast on Channels 13 and 11, "The Beginning and the End," was a worthwhile and interesting experiment that failed. The idea itself was fascinating; to present two different but thematically complementary visual programs, one depicting the plight of the elderly and the other the beginning world of school children, with a single audio portion to unite the two visualizations.

DUNGENESS, England, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- A German freighter apparently smashed into the Submerged wreckage of a natural-gas tanker that sank barely 24 hours earlier in the English Channel, then went down herself today within two minutes.
MEMPHIS -- I would like to say that you can't lead to places you don't go. I feel that we should support anything that would unite us and oppose anything that would divide us.

TRENTON, Jan. 12 -- Warning that the danger of financial collapse of New Jersey's cities had become a crucial "issue of life or death," Gov. William T. Cahill reiterated his demand today that the Nixon Administration urgently redirect its fiscal priorities toward the Newarks of America.

MADRID, Jan. 12 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco today dismissed an outspoken rightwing general in an apparent attempt to stem growing rightist dissension in the wake of the recent court-martial of 15 Basque nationalists in Burgos.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 12 (UPI). -- Jim Lorentz scored two goals and Christian Bordeleau added a goal and three assists tonight to pace the St. Louis Blues to an 8-2 triumph over the California Seals.

The New York Stock Exchange will take up today the controversial issue of institutional membership on the exchange when the Dreyfus Corporation, one of the oldest and largest mutual-fund organizations, formally applies for approval to join.

ATLANTA, Jan. 12 -- Jimmy Carter was sworn in today as Governor and delighted blacks in his inaugural audience by making an unqualified call for an end to racial discrimination in Georgia. Mr. Carter is a 45-year-old peanut farmer who bears a strong physical resemblance to President Kennedy.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the second largest producer of American primary copper, cut the price of the metal to 50 3/8 cents a pound from 53 cents late yesterday. It was the third reduction in the basic copper quotation in the last four months.

HAWTHORNE, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- What the Bruckner Traffic Circle is to the Bronx, the Hawthorne Traffic Circle is to Westchester; a bottleneck, a battleground in the war of nerves, a place for the the unsure driver to avoid.

MANILA, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Court-appointed psychiatrists have reported that the Bolivian painter accused of the attempted assassination of Pope-Paul VI here on Nov. 27 appears to be normal although he has "delusions of grandeur," a Filipino judge said today.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 12 -- Mayor Thomas J. Whelan called on the state today to help meet Jersey City's expected $18-million deficit by allowing the city to impose a 2 per cent payroll tax.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Allied troop movements were reported today moving southward along Route 4 from Pnompenh and northward up the same road from Kompong Som, Cambodia's only deepwater seaport and site of an oil refinery.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Six persons, including the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan, were indicted today on Federal charges of plotting to kidnap Henry A. Kissinger, assistant to the President for national security affairs, and to blow up the heating systems of Federal buildings here.
Hunter College's 10-game victory streak in basketball ended last night as St. Francis scored a 74-64 triumph.

When the rubber fuel cell of a racing car is filled to the brim, the car is vulnerable to fire. The reason is that the tank is in effect a hydraulic chamber. If there is a collision or other impact, pressure is exerted on the liquid.

The Jim Walter Corporation, a major building materials producer and leader in shell housing, increased earnings in its first fiscal quarter ended Nov. 30 to $7,544,543, or 44 cents a share, from $6,157,796, or 36 cents a share, in the comparable three months a year earlier.

Vice President Agnew has been unusually quiet in recent weeks. But he may not merely be resting from his arduous political campaign efforts. If the reports and speculations emanating from Washington are correct, the nation is about to see a "new Agnew."

HOUSTON, Jan. 12 -- From an analysis of cosmic-ray tracks on the moon, scientists said here today that they had "conclusive proof" of the existence in lunar soil of fossils from chemical elements far heavier than any previously discovered in nature or in laboratory experiments.

" Parliamentary democracy resides with the people," India's Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declared recently in announcing plans for a general election early this year. "That is why we have decided to go to our people and to seek a fresh mandate from them."

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 12 -- The Board of Governors of the National Basketball Association, meeting today before the league's 21st annual All-Star game at the International Sports Arena, considered bringing charges against the Seattle SuperSonics that could result in the expulsion of the franchise.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan 12 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan told California lawmakers today that an expected 1971-72 state deficit of nearly three-quarters of a billion dollars could be met without new taxes.

Faced with the continued expense of $122,000 a week and with no prospects of early revenue, the city's Off-Track Betting Corporation asked its governing body yesterday for permission to begin operating a separate betting pool on races at Yonkers Raceway.

The Allied Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that it had developed a new pipeline-charging system that had the potential of reducing smoke and gases from by-product cokes by as much as 70 per cent.
CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- The Chicago public school system, the country's second largest, was closed today as 21,000 teachers went on strike.
Brian McElroy, a top Eastern schoolboy athlete who went west in search of world records, will transfer from the University of Kansas to Villanova next week.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 12 -- The kidnappers of the Swiss Ambassador, Giovanni Enrico Bucher, promised tonight to release him after 70 political prisoners, promised freedom by Brazil, had arrived in Chile.

FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Jan. 12 -- A statement by a South Vietnamese Army sergeant telling of a drinking bout by American infantrymen after, he said, they had been told that they were going to kill all the inhabitants of Mylai 4 was read today at the court-martial of Sgt. Charles E. Hutto.
MIAMI, Jan. 12 -- Toil has priority over labor for John Mackey of the Baltimore Colts this week.

A spokesman for the Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday that Procter Gamble had pulled two one-minute commercials from the C.B.S. News program, "Is Mercury a Menace?" broadcast last night from 10 to 11 P.M.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 12 -- When Bob Hayes walked proudly toward the victory podium in Tokyo to receive his gold medal for winning the Olympic 100-meter championship in 1964, he was wearing a cowboy hat. There was nothing symbolic about it and it was no portent of the future. At that time the newest world's fastest human had no knowledge he would some day be burning up the gridiron for the Dallas Cowboys.

The results of reading tests recently administered by the city's public schools raised more questions than they answered. The bright spot shown by these statistics is the marked improvement of reading ability in the second grade. The city's second-graders as a group now register slightly above the national norm, while all other grade levels lag behind.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 12 -- The United States command, which previously had disclosed that an American plane made a "protective reaction" attack inside North Vietnam last Friday, said today that there were actually two such attacks that day.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 -- A Federal District Court judge has ruled that it is unconstitutional for the Government to wiretap without a warrant in domestic cases, even if they involve the national security.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Federal Communications Commission tentatively approved today an increase in long distance telephone rates pending results of a new hearing.

Brown, the general manager of the Chrysler-Plymouth Dision since April, 1970, has been appointed to the newly created post of group vice president.U,. automotive sales.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Postmaster General Winton M. Blount forecast today that the conversion of the Post Office from a Cabinet department to a semi-independent public corporation would be completed by June 30.

At the Ritz Theater last night a new rock musical, "Soon," opened, and it is purest cornball romance -- all about the sheer agony of selling out as a successful pop-musician, and the cornfed blonde who is left behind, assuring the whole wide world that: "Life is rich and sentimental."

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Marquette University turned back a late Notre Dame rally with a flurry of free throws tonight and beat the Irish, 71-66, to avenge its last defeat nearly a year ago. Stanley Babin's piano recital at Tully Hall on Wednesday night made for an evening of pleasant listening on the whole. It was that of a musician whose talents, skills and interpretative ideas seemed about evenly matched, and who did not seem to be aiming for effects or goals beyond his powers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -The Supreme Court unanimously declared unconstitutional today two Federal laws that had authorized the Post Office Department to cut off postal service to mail order houses that deal in pornography.

JOHANNESBURG -- Americans who are repelled by a color bar, but are at least prepared to consider that the South African "separate development" political philosophy of apartheid may be something other than Jim Crow legislation under another name, have told me that they did not know what to think of the South African Government's resettlement schemes for blacks. Living so far away, ignorant of local conditions, is one qualified to judge?
MIAMI, Jan. 14 -- For two members of the Baltimore Colts, the Super Bowl game symbolizes a successful escape.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan 14 -President Nixon called on young and old alike today to "forge an alliance of the generations" and as evidence of his commitment to that goal, proposed setting up a new Government agency to enlist the energies and idealism of youth.
New York's eight harnessracing tracks have appealed to the state to block efforts by the city's Off-Track Betting Corporation to set up separate wagering pools.

SAN MAURIZIO D'OPAGLIO, Italy -- Italy exported nearly $100-million worth of faucets last year, many of them cast, cut, turned, chromium -plated, polished and assembled in this small town and two even smaller ones nearby.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 14 -Premier Suleyman Demirel has won another reprieve in his battle to keep the office he has held for more than five years, but his troubles have opened an unusually frank debate in Turkey over whether dictatorship can do more for development than democracy can.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 14 -- The Carrier Corporation demonstrated here today a new central air-conditioning system aimed specifically at the apartment building market. Called the Volumaster, the new system combines a solid-state variable air volume control with a 232-year-old aerodynamic effect known as Bernoulli's Principle, which causes conditioned air to cling to the ceiling and at the same time regulate the air temperature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -The United States left open the possibility today that it might provide logistic and airlift support for the South Vietnamese forces in Cambodia if required by the deteriorating military situation there.

Resolution of this issue will have a major impact on the future of the Exchange and the securities industry generally.

Violence, prejudice, segregation, freedom, discrimination, oppression and resistance were the seven "dictionary words" in Class 4-4 this week. The words came up in lessons on the life of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., whose birthday was observed yesterday as a public holiday by the schools.

The President's Cabinet Committee on Economic Policy, which has been ordered to review major price increases announced by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, will hold its first meeting on the subject next Monday, a White House spokesman said yesterday.

Consumers can look for slightly higher sugar prices in the wake of increases posted yesterday at the wholesale level.

ROME, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Vatican said today that it abolished the death penalty a year and a half ago. The abolition went virtually unnoticed.

The Singer Company has announced the appointment of Alexander H. Dunbar as group vice president. WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Personal income advanced $5.25-billion in December to an adjusted annual rate of $817.75-billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

Two foundations announced yesterday a three-year experiment at five medical schools to see if a computer can be used both to teach and to test medical students.

The Dec. 30 and Jan. 3 dispatches by Sydney H. Schanberg on the areas in East Pakistan affected by the cyclone that struck on Nov. 12 almost completely ignore Pakistan's own contribution to the relief operations. A proper assessment of Pakistan's effort would have to take into account the unparalleled magnitude of the disaster, the shifting nature of the deltaic land, the consequent impossibility of maintaining communications after major cyclones and the country's limited resources.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Nixon announced today a recess appointment of Thomas S. Kleppe, the unsuccessful Republican nominee for the United States Senate last year in North Dakota, to head the Small Business Administration.
Richard J. Schwartz has been named man of the year by Sports Lodge of B'nai B'rith and will receive its gold medal at the annual Bill Corum awards dinner, Saturday at the Roosevelt Hotel.

NEWARK, Jan. 18 -- A scheduled debate that was to include LeRoi Jones, the black militant playwright; Anthony Imperiale, the white militant politician, and several moderate community leaders was canceled here tonight after about 75 of Mr. Imperiale's supporters disrupted the meeting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- An article in the February issue of The Atlantic Monthly says two military pilots who monitored above-ground weapons tests by the Atomic Energy Commission in Nevada in 1953 later were stricken with leukemia and died.

Trans World Airlines recently asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for authority to work out joint agreements with other airlines to reduce excess passenger capacity. A somewhat similar proposal made last August by T.W.A., American and United ran into objections from both the C.A.B. and the Justice Department.
The Peace Corps' desire to recruit more skilled workers will be reflected in the first campaign by its new ad agency, Geer, duBois.

Mrs. Alice Crimmins, who faces trial Feb. 22 in the deaths of her two children in 1965, was granted permission in Queens Supreme Court yesterday to hire defense experts at public expense because she is financially destitute.

That part of Governor Rockefeller's State of the State message that dealt with the environment was evidently meant to be heard, not studied. It touched all the required bases -- air, water, waste and noise -- and sounded just the proper tone of sternness toward "those polluters with a 'public-be-damned' attitude." But for the most part his recommendations were mild, vague and insubstantial.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Senator George S. McGovern of South Dakota opened his Presidential campaign today, 22 months before Election Day, 1972, with a pledge to withdraw every American soldier from Southeast Asia if he reaches the White House.

Frank Mulzoff and Digger Phelps found out last week in Milwaukee that winning can do wonders for college basketball interest and attendance even when there is an outstanding pro team in the same city.
The London stock market closed lower yesterday, with an impending postal strike the main cause of the decline.
ADELBODEN, Switzerland, Jan. 18 (Reuters) -- Patrick Russel of France swept to victory in a giant slalom race today, but lost his lead in the World Cup standing to Gustavo Thoeni of Italy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Defense Department said today that the United States intended to employ the full range of its air combat power throughout Cambodia against enemy troops and supplies that "ultimately" might threaten American military men in South Vietnam.

In that medieval romance he appears as a demented, evil old man moping about crepuscular halls in a somber castle, dressed as a devilish monk, while dead men hang from gibbets in the courtyard.

John J. DeLury, head of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, used the occasion of a brief, but legal "job action" by 50 union men yesterday to hint at a serious work stoppage if a satisfactory contract with the city is not achieved by Feb. 1.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- More than 14 per cent of some 16,000 drugs tested for the Food and Drug Administration were found to be ineffective, the agency's commissioner said today.

Patrick J. Buchanan, Special Assistant to President Nixon, asserts in a letter published Jan. 8 that my Op-Ed article of Dec. 26 contains false statements about the President's sources of information.

MIAMI, Jan. 18 -- Maybe the experts are too expert. Most of them were so appalled by the bush-league performances displayed by both teams in the Super Bowl yesterday that they were inclined to regard this unfunny comedy of errors as not only a smear on football but as an inadvertent boost for baseball.

WIMBLEDON, England, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The All-England Tennis Club announced today that a tiebreaker would be used in this year's Wimbledon tennis championships. It is the first change in scoring since the tournament began in 1877.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Five subsidiaries of Cowles Communications, Inc., were fined $10,000 each today after they pleaded no contest to criminal charges of using fraudulent and deceptive practices in the sale of magazine subscriptions. and book club memberships.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -Senator George S. McGovern charged today that President Nixon had violated "the spirit and letter" of the Cooper-Church resolution by authorizing intensive American air activity over Cambodia.
WASHINGTON, Jan 19 -- As the Lady Bird Johnson campaign special rolled through the South in the fall of 1964, Thomas Hale Boggs of Louisiana drew wild cheers from the trainside crowds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -Charles C. Johnson Jr., an Assistant Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, was named today as associate executive director of the American Public Health Association, effective Feb. 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -House Democrats rejected today a move to strip the five Mississippi Representatives of their seniority because of their failure to register with the integrated party that was recognized by the 1968 Democratic National Convention.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 19 -- Israel's policymakers today welcomed what they viewed as evidence that Cairo was ready for the most serious attempt at peace negotiations since the Arab-Israeli war of 1967.

Carrie Smith, a singer with a dark, lustrous voice and a repertory that ranges from obscure blues and old pop tunes to contemporary rock, has been in town several times before but she has never had as good an opportunity to show her performing personality as she has now at the Downbeat, Lexington Avenue at 42d Street.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 -- The beautiful Bay of San Francisco was ugly today.

Analysis of markings on fragments of ancient bone, antler and stone has revealed what appears to be a system of notation used throughout most of Europe beginning some 34,000 years ago during the last ice age.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A South Vietnamese armored force reportedly pushed closer today to a link-up with Cambodian troops in the allied drive to clear Route 4, the nation's main supply route.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A Government scientific study group concluded today that widespread poisoning from mercury in food was unlikely. But it said that the Government must move with utmost urgency to remove deposits of the metal from polluted waterways.

The Board of Education, by a vote of 3 to 2, adopted a record operating budget request of $1,920,694,513, yesterday for the fiscal year beginning July 1.
DALLAS, Jan. 19 (AP) -An injunction suit alleging fraud in sales of stock was filed yesterday against former Texas Attorney General Waggoner Carr and others.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 19 -- Leaders of the World Council of Churches took a 24hour respite today to eat, drink and say an occasional prayer with millions of Ethiopians observing the national feast of Timkat.
BOSTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- The 14-team National Hockey League will not expand again before the 1973 season because of a "dilution" of playing talent, Clarence Campbell said today.

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company reported yesterday gains in 1970 operating revenues and net income. However, share earnings dipped as the number of shares outstanding increased by some 2 million to an average of 33,504,421 for the year.

To the Editor: Within two months (Nov. 10, 1970 and Jan. 8), The Times has given prominent space to a discussion by David Dalby of African contributions to the American language. The Times lists Mr. Dalby as "one of England's leading specialists in African linguistics."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced today that it would cut off a major portion of matching welfare aid to Indiana and Nebraska on April 1 because the two states are violating Federal public assistance regulations.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., the country's largest department-store chain, announced yesterday the establishment of a new division, Bullock's North, in the San Francisco area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -The White House today acknowledged a recent step-up in the type and intensity of American air operations in Cambodia, but insisted that Administration policy had not changed from the guidelines laid down by President Nixon last summer.
MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 19 -Nassau County policemen discontinued their job action today after the settlement early this morning of a contract dispute with the county.

Two restrained cheers for the United States Navy for agreeing to phase out its activities on Culebra rather than buying up more of the tiny Caribbean island as a target area for guided missiles and glide bombs. The third cheer will be delivered with greater enthusiasm when the Navy makes good its pledge to find an alternate target zone and clears out of Culebra completely, leaving its 726 residents in peace and unaccustomed quiet.
ROME, Jan, 19 -- Irene Galitzine, wearing black shorts and a thin silk blouse, upheld the honor of Italian fashion at her spring opening and proved that women over 18 can be trusted in short pants.

The slash in the discount rate was made to cope with the latest series of cuts in the United States Federal Reserve discount rate. The discount rate is the interest charged member banks when they borrow from the central bank.

On Monday, the Boston Patriots will announce their intentions regarding Jim Plunkett, the Heisman Trophy quarterback from Stanford, in next Thursday's National Football League draft.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 21 -- Representatives of oil-producing countries and Western oil companies failed to reconcile any of their differences at a meeting here today but agreed to continue talks here next week.
PARIS, Jan. 21 (Reuters) -- All 21 persons aboard a French Air Force transport plane, including two generals and an admiral, were killed when it crashed today, the Defense Ministry announced.

Regarding your Jan. 2 editorial entitled "Blame for the F-111," I thought your defense of Robert McNamara was solid and well deserved. It was nice to see a public official defended for good work done quietly.

The New York Stock Exchange filled a key executive position yesterday with the appointment of Richard B. Howland as executive vice president, effective March 1. He will replace R. John Cunningham, whose resignation takes effect the same date.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Federal Communications Commission announced tonight a comprehensive investigation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The F.C.C. will examine not only A.T.'s request for a major rate increase but also its mounting costs, charges of discriminatory hiring practices and the company's control of the Western Electric manufacturing subsidiary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Nixon's State of the Union Message was greeted with restrained approval by Congress tonight, with Republicans praising the President's goals and Democrats pledging cautious cooperation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Owners of theaters showing the film "Love Story" can post a new recommendation on their marquees tomorrow: "I recommend it -- R.M.N."

Pro football concludes a long television season with the Pro Bowl game tomorrow from Los Angeles (Channel 2, 4 P.M.). The pause to refresh will last until July 30, when the College All-Star game pits the Baltimore Colts against the top choices in next week's pro draft.

The Continental Corporation, parent of the giant Continental Insurance Companies and the financially ailing Diners Club, reported yesterday that net operating income fell to $56.1-million last year from $59.9-million a year earlier.
Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday that he thought New York patrolmen should be paid at least $15,000 a year.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 22 -- Highly placed sources said today that representatives of oil-producing nations and Western oil companies had taken an important step toward a settlement yesterday by "getting around" the controversial issue of whether their talks should cover only the Persian Gulf area or all the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers met with Senator John Sherman Cooper today in an effort to assure him that the Administration was abiding by Congressional Testrictions on American involvement in Cambodia.

The Ohio Edison Company reported yesterday lower net income for the fourth quarter and full year despite higher revenues in both 1970 periods. The preliminary annual report placed fourth-quarter revenues at $71,453,814 against $67,833,951 a year ago.

Trading on the London stock exchange was depressed yesterday. There were two main reasons: too many prospective buyers appeared to be indifferent and the postal strike kept many orders from coming through, which helped to keep volume very low.

MANILA, Jan. 22 -- The headquarters of two American oil companies were bombed and damaged extensively at about the same time tonight. A Filipino employe was killed and three others were injured in the blasts.

SEATTLE, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The University of Washington's Human Rights Commission, which investigated charges of racism in the football program, made public a report today recommending the dismissal of the head coach, Jim Owens, and athletic director, Joe Kearney.

CAIRO, Jan. 22 -- The leaders of four Arab countries declared tonight that Israel was trying with United States support to perpetuate the occupation of Arab areas seized in 1967 "by turning the temporary ceasefire into a permanent one."

BELGRADE, Jan. 22 -- The Yugoslav Government, which has already frozen prices and wages in its battle against inflation, is expected to devalue its currency by 20 to 30 per cent tomorrow, according to usually reliable sources here.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- On the prairies that reach 30 miles from the eastern cordillera of the Colombian Andes to the Orinoco River, the Colombian Government's petroleum corporation has devised an "association" with foreign corporations in an attempt to do something new in the often-wayward relations between such corporations and Latin-American governments.
TORONTO -- In November a few weeks after Canada and China established diplomatic relations, a group of foreign businessmen were returning to Hong Kong from the semi-annual trade fair in Canton.

MEXICO CITY -- Mexico's development strategy calls for an increasing emphasis on domestic savings and national enterprise, rather than foreign loans and investments, as the primary impetus for economic growth.

As South Vietnam's presidential election campaign gets under way, President Thieu's advantages are enormous. He is a wartime incumbent in control of the military, the police, the provincial governors, a far-flung bureaucracy and vast patronage in a country new to ballot-box politics. But the possibility that he might be beaten in the Oct. 3 voting, perhaps by a peace candidate, cannot be totally ruled out.
BERLIN, Jan. 24 -- East Germany protested today against the visits scheduled for West Berlin this week by West German politicians, among them Chancellor Willy Brandt.

YELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territories -- One morning the territorial government got a phone call from an oil company. It offered to hire two Indians for a drilling job that was about to start, part of the multimillion-dollar oil boom that is bringing enormous change, prosperity and problems to the Canadian Arctic and its peoples.

Sergio Mendes brought a revamped version of his Brasil '66 to Philharmonic Hall Saturday night for two performances. Gone was Lani Hall, the young singer who, in the last two years, had become the focal point of the group.

CERVINIA, Italy, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Italy scored a one-two sweep of the world two-man bobsled championships when competition today was cut short after two of the scheduled four heats because of a snowstorm.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- The Colombian Government has authorized this nation's three automobile assembly plants to produce 26,360 vehicles in 1971. In addition, 12,000 assembled vehicles -- the yearly average for the sixties -- are expected to be imported.
Revised customs regulations to combat cargo theft were announced yesterday by Eugene T. Rossides, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for enforcement and operations.

Nobody can predict the outcome of the examination of the New York Stock Exchange that will be undertaken by William McChesney Martin Jr., but few people in Wall Street doubt that it will be penetrating and perhaps controversial.
TORONTO -- The Canadian Government's effort to write a comprehensive foreign-investment policy that would diminish United States economic influence in Canada has bogged down.

If there is one thing concert-goers share nowadays, it is a hunger for novelty. Some performers have come to realize this and are beginning to break out of the repertory straitjackets that have made thousands upon thousands of programs almost indistinguishable from one another over the last two decades.
KAMPALA, Uganda, Monday, Jan. 25 (Reuters) -- Tank and rifle fire and explosions broke the early morning stillness in Kampala today and sporadic shooting was still going on some hours later.
One of the most vicious sales devices widely used by unscrupulous life insurance agents is a practice you may never have heard of -- even though you may have been a victim of it.

The Times editorial ("Las Vegas East," Jan. 8) gave an erroneous impression of my position regarding casino gambling in New York State. I do "warmly applaud" Senate Majority Leader Earl Brydges's proposal to amend the State Constitution, for I would like to see the total proscriptions concerning gambling removed from the New York State Constitution.
LIMA, Peru -- At one time all a United States businessman traveling in South America needed were dollars, the addresses of United States embassies and the names of local contact men -- or "fixers."
Mayor Lindsay yesterday ordered a halt to the placing of welfare and relocation families in hotels except for "cases of extreme emergency, such as fires."
The calm assurance of Leonid Kogan's performance was quite at odds with the air of tension in Carnegie Hall as the Soviet violinist began his recital Saturday night.

John G. Avrett, writer; Philip Parker, art director, and Fred L. Lemont, marketing man, who worked together in the early days of Wells, Rich, Greene, are together again as partners in The Project Group.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, said today current United States air support for the Cambodian Government was "contrary to the intent and spirit" of Congressional restrictions on United States involvement there.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 -- Mel Renfro of the Dallas Cowboys made two dazzling touchdown runs of 82 and 56 yards with fourth-quarter punt returns today to lead the National Conference All-Stars to a 27-6 victory over the American Conference All-Stars in the National Football League's Pro Bowl.

During a recent confrontation between King Hussein's bedouin troops and some guerrillas occupying a Palestinian refugee camp near Amman, a group of refugees attempted to quit the camp and march toward the Israeli-occupied areas west of the Jordan River.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay -- The tourist became a central figure in the battle last year between the government of President Jorge Pacheco Areco and the urban guerrillas known as the Tupamaros.

NIAVARAN, Iran, Jan. 24 -- The Shah of Iran said today that Iran and nine other producing countries would seriously consider stopping the flow of their oil to the West if their negotiations with Western companies broke down in the next nine days.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 24 (Reuters) -- Three California girls swept past their singles opposition today and moved into the third round of the Victorian open tennis championships.

Arthur Kantrowitz (Op-Ed Jan. 14) holds forth the hope that a large portion of mankind in the future may live, healthfully and comfortably, in stations -- perhaps even in cities -- in outer space. He is duly cautious in discussing this possibility. But he condemns "naive pessimism about the role that space can play in exhibiting the possibilities for unlimited progress."

SHERBROOKE, Quebec -- The words "unemployment" and "revolution" leaped from the front pages of every newspaper in Quebec a few days ago. The number of unemployed in this predominantly French-Canadian province of six million people had soared 30 per cent in a year to a December total of 197,000, or 8.4 per cent of the labor force.
WASHINGTON -- The Arena Stage opened its new Kreeger Theater last week with the American premiere of Peter Barnes's "The Ruling Class -- a double-barreled event of great theatrical importance.

KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Jean-Noel Augert, France's 21 - year - old world slalom champion, won the Hahnenkamm slalom race today and assumed the individual lead in the World Cup ski standings.
LIMA, Peru -- The military Government continued to march Peru down its "new path between capitalism and Communism" in 1970, and again managed to confound its enemies in both camps.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 24 -- Representative William R. Anderson, Democrat of Tennessee, a veteran of both World War II and the Korean War, hailed the Berrigan brothers today as heroes in the nonviolent struggle for peace.

Spinning, deflecting and chopping at the puck with his unusual assortment of moves, Dave Balon became one of the few Rangers in history to score four goals yesterday as he helped halt a New York skid in a 6-2 victory over the tired Minnesota North Stars.

Sometime this year, or perhaps in 1972, an American-built DC-8 bearing the ensign of Canadian Pacific Airlines will brake to a stop at Shanghai's Rainbow Bridge Airport in Communist China and discharge its passengers -- Canadian tourists, businessmen, diplomats and Latin American supporters of the Peking Government.

The United States should prepare itself to face new trade problems that will result if Britain joins the European Economic Community, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company said in its monthly survey for January, which was released over the weekend.
The days when the mother of an infant might have wrapped baby in a rabbit skin, and there was no question of diapers, were easy. Today, there are decisions, decisions, decisions.

OTTAWA -- This looks like the beginning of a pre-election year in the capital of Canada. The tang of electioneering is already in the air, stirring Government ministers and Opposition leaders to be politicians as well.
BRENTWOOD, L. I., Jan. 24 -- Thirty-seven persons were injured here today when a Long Island Railroad train hit an apparently sabotaged switch and hurtled off the tracks.
A capacity crowd of 2,400 showed up at Sunnyside Garden in Queens last night to see Joe Lewis and Ronnie Barkoot indulge in a new kind of mayhem for the first time on the East Coast -- kick-boxing.
LA PAZ, Bolivia -- The Shadows move in the weak light cast by the headlamps of the wiry tin miners as they load their carts with ore.

PARAMARIBO, Surinam -- At a time when nationalism is sweeping most of South America, the major fear of the 420,000 Surinamese is that The Hague may cast them adrift. Since 1956 this former Dutch colony has had a relationship with the Netherlands akin to that of the United States and Puerto Rico.
CARACAS, Venezuela -- The sudden development of a tight world petroleum supply situation last autumn did little to cheer the largely foreign-controlled oil industry here.

BRENTWOOD, L. I., Jan. 24 -- Dr. Joseph Judge, a mild-mannered physician, was sitting down to dinner at his home in nearby Brightwaters tonight when the telephone rang. It was a call from the South Side Hospital Disaster Unit, reporting the wreck of a Long Island Railroad train here, and asking him to aid the injured.

BEIBUT, Lebanon, Jan. 24 -- A representative of President Anwar el-Sadat of the United Arab Republic arrived in Amman, Jordan, today for what was described as a last attempt to reactivate the eastern front against Israel.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 24 (UPI) -- Two of the three Apollo 14 astronauts relaxed today but Capt. Alan B. Shepard Jr. of the Navy studied while engineers prepared to start the preliminary countdown tomorrow for the United States' most expensive moon flight.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- Drivers remaining in the Monte Carlo Rally faced roads blocked by a fierce Alpine blizzard today as they awaited a night of racing across Europe towards the sunny Mediterranean.

THE decade of the nineteen-seventies finds the inter-American community in a situation of disarray and confusion, which is fitting and proper for any self-respecting part of the world today. Strife and turmoil have become normal.
Six members of a Flushing, Queens, family were killed early yesterday when a flash fire swept their three-story frame home. Two neighbors who are firemen tried in vain to save the victims.
Foreign boats, like foreign cars, hold a special place in the hearts of many visitors to the National Boat Show that runs through Jan. 31 at the Coliseum.

To some people the word "librarian" conjures up the image of a whispery old lady in musty crepe, who exists only to stamp books, riffle through card catalogues and perhaps suggest the latest mystery novel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Whether he's talking with constituents in Cambridge pubs, debating on the floor of the House or negotiating behind the scenes with other politicians, Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts likes to make his points with stories and personal anecdotes.
MADRID, Jan. 24 -- Prince Juan Carlos de Borbon, Generalissimo Francisco Franco's designated successor, begins a five-day visit to the United States tomorrow with two difficult missions.

Few doctoral dissertations ever manage to leave the college library shelf. Stephen Dankner's Spmphony, offered in support of his Doctor of Musical Arts Degree at Juilliard, is an exception, and the work received its premiere Friday night in Tully Hall at the hands of the Juilliard Theater Orchestra.

It was Marilyn Horne's night at the Metropolitan Opera. Up to now she has been sharing the spotlight in "Norma" with her colleague and good friend, Joan Sutherland. On Saturday evening she appeared as Rosina in "Il Barbiere di Siviglia," and this time she was on her own as the mezzo-soprano star in the production.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 24 -- The Institute for Advanced Study here, dedicated to the expansion of knowledge and the preservation of Western culture, is under attack for alleged insensitivity toward the significance of 12 1/2 acres of ground in early American history.
GUATEMALA -- The Central American Common Market suffered its worst setback in a decade with the virtual withdrawal of Honduras from the five-nation group early this year.
Dr. Steven Muller, the vice president for public affairs at Cornell University, has been named provost of Johns Hopkins University.

COMMAND POST CHARLIE ONE, South Vietnam, Jan. 24 -- Thirty - seven disabled North Vietnamese prisoners of war paddled across the Benhai River in the demilitarized zone six miles north of here today after their captors told them they could go home.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 -- The steel inventory boom was regarded as an accomplished fact last week.

Synthesis of human growth hormone, the most complex biological chemical ever produced by man, is one of the great triumphs of modem biochemistry, a feat that almost guarantees Dr. Choh Hao Li and Dr. Donald H. Yamashiro of the University of California a Nobel Prize within the next few years. Yet this work has a dark shadow over its future because of growing Federal budgetary cutbacks.

WASHINGTON -- The recent publication of Albert Speer's memoirs, "Inside the Third Reich," has given many people the impression that at he trial held by the International Military Tribunal at Nuremberg Speer, driven by his conscience, risked his life by assuming full responsibility for the war crimes and crimes against humanity committed by the Nazi regime.
RIO DE JANEIRO -- Brazil, the giant of Latin America, made new economic strides last year, shattering all statistical records in business and industry.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- A book on methods of collecting blood for medical purposes: It would be hard to imagine a subject less likely to interest the general reader or throw light on broad issues of social organization and values. But that book has just been published in Britain, and it is attracting the fascinated attention it deserves.

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Jan. 25 -- Fifty-eight of 92 persons condemned to death yesterday in the aftermath of last November's seaborne invasion of Guinea were hanged today, the Conakry radio reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -The Senate Foreign Relations Committee decided today to investigate whether the Administration was complying with Congressional restrictions in expanding the American military role in Cambodia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -Western Hemisphere foreign ministers opened a conference here today to seek means to prevent kidnappings of diplomats and other political terrorism.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Mayor Thomas J. Whelan announced today a $109-million "starvation budget" for 1971 that will still necessitate an increase in the property tax rate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -The Nixon Administration, working to equip South Vietnam to take over full responsibility for the air war within its boundaries once American air power has been removed, has decided on another substantial increase in the size of Saigon's air force.
MIAMI, Jan. 25 (UPI) -- Needles N Pens scored his second straight victory at Hialeah today with a strong rally in the $8,000 allowance feature at 1 1/8 miles.
A guard and eight inmates or former inmates of the Tombs were indicted yesterday for their alleged role in the prison's riots last October.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 25 -- A belt of ice that had been protecting beaches near here from a giant oil slick in Long Island Sound has broken up, but so far no major damage has been reported.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -New orders for durable goods rose strongly in December, partly because of the end of the General Motors strike, the Commerce Department reported today.
The city's Department of Traffic is studying more restrictions on traffic in the midtown area, a City Hall spokesman said last night.
WARSAW, Jan. 25 -- A highranking delegation headed by Edward Gierek, Poland's Communist party leader, spent a second day in the north today, meeting well into the night with workers in Gdansk.

DETROIT, Jan.25 -- A Federal District Court judge here, in the second such decision in a month, reaffirmed today that the Attorney General does not have the right to order wiretaps without a court warrant in domestic cases on the ground of protecting the national security.
MERIDA, Venezuela, Jan. 25 (AP) -- A Venezuelan airliner with 48 persons aboard crashed today in the Andes. Rescuers located 30 survivors by tonight.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 25 -- As the countdown began today for the Apollo 14 flight to the moon, space agency physicians gave its three-man crew a medical green light for the launching that is scheduled for Sunday afternoon.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 25 -- The United States command said today that two American naval vessels had withdrawn after nearly two weeks of operations off Cambodia in which they were supplying and fueling American armed helicopters supporting South Vietnamese troops.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 25 -- Mayor Lindsay and Westchester County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian met for more than an hour in Mr. Michaelian's office here this morning to discuss what both consider their most pressing common problem: the financing of welfare.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Attempting to get the jump on the Administration, 30 Senators, including New York Republican Jacob K. Javits, introduced a bill today that would create federally funded public service employment.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today to review the merger of the Greyhound Corporation and Armour Co., the nation's second largest meat packer.
Prices closed mostly steady to higher in quiet trading on the London stock exchange yesterday. Industrial issues with financial ties to the United States did best.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -The nation's surplus of exports over imports doubled last year but monetary reserves declined, two Government reports disclosed today.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 25 (UPI) -- Ove Andersson of Sweden, racing over ice and snow in his Alpine Renault, swept into the lead today of the Monte Carlo auto rally at the end of the first stage.

The pro football establishment's efforts to continue the old National League-American League rivalry have fallen on hard times because of the candor of the coaches and players and the skepticism of the fans.

Two major commodity concerns that shared the same origin announced yesterday that they had rejoined forces. They are the A. C. Israel Commodity Company, Inc., and Leon Israel Bros., both with headquarters in New York and headed by first cousins.

DUSSELDORF, West Germany, Jan. 25 -- Kurt Georg Kiesinger, the West German opposition leader, accused Chancellor Willy Brandt's Government today of plunging the country into a "hectic adventure" by its policy of seeking better relations with Eastern Europe.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A State Department official said today that the United States Government had "done its part" to aid the negotiations.

New York, which has survived police strikes, subway breakdowns, blackouts and John Lindsay, had its first indoor motorcycle race last night. The town survived, but there are other tests to come -- the show may be repeated next year.

" Who put in the bathrooms -- the artists or the landlords?" demanded Mrs. Emil Strauss from her seat directly behind the bus driver at the outset of yesterday's tour to two artists' studio-homes and the Max Hutchinson art gallery in the downtown SoHo district.

Thirty-nine young men being sworn in as fire cadets in a South Bronx Model Cities program got an unexpected taste of their new careers yesterday. A fire interrupted the ceremony at Public School 161, at Tinton Avenue and 151st Street.

Thanks to intervention by their parent union, striking telephone repair crews throughout New York State have returned to work. They have agreed to arbitrate the issue of whether they can lock out fellow-unionists brought to this city from other areas to help pull telephone service out of its present deteriorated condition.
A panel of 12 black law professors from 11 colleges will "provide advice and counsel" to the defense of Angela Davis, according to Haywood Burns, director of the National Conference of Black Lawyers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Vice President Agnew charged today that a member of the House of Representatives was "popping off for political reasons" about Federal conspiracy accusations against the Berrigan brothers.
In the boxing office at Madison Square Garden yesterday, Duke Stefano picked up his phone.

The aluminum industry presented a plan yesterday for a recycling plant that could take in all municipal garbage as a raw material and process it into reusable material ranging from sand and paper to various types of metal.

FORT MEADE, Md., Jan. 25 (AP) -- First Lieut. Louis P. Font filed charges of dereliction of duty today against the commander of this military base, accusing him of maintaining barracks unfit to live in.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- Cardinal Cooke, the state's leading Catholic prelate, declared today that the repeal of the so-called Blaine Amendment, which prohibits state aid to nonpublic schools was not "a matter of urgency."

A high-level committee of the New York Stock Exchange broke with tradition yesterday and endorsed the concept of institutional membership on the exchange, coupled with negotiated commission rates for institutional transactions above a size to be determined.

Two of the nation's largest steel companies, the Republic Steel Corporation and the National Steel Corporation, reported yesterday that their earnings in the fourth quarter and in all of 1970 dropped sharply from the 1969 levels.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 25 (AP) -- A Roman Catholic nun named as a co-conspirator in the alleged kidnapping and bombing plot was granted immunity from prosecution today and ordered to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating the case.

Simeon Golar, chairman of the City Housing Authority, said yesterday his agency proposed to use one or more pending vestpocket housing projects and buildings renovated under the municipal loan program to help cut down the need for hotels for welfare recipients.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Senate game of musical chairs on committee assignments has resulted in a slightly more liberal cast to the conservativedominated Finance Committee. It has also given Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine a foreign policy platform on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

The Department of the Interior's draft statement on the proposed Alaskan oil pipeline is impressive. It presents the Government's first comprehensive view on the pipeline's probable impact on the environment -including not only those dangers that might be overcome by standards to be set for its construction but also those that the Department concedes cannot be overcome at all.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 18--The South Vietnamese armed forces are rapidly assuming the major part of the ground fighting in Vietnam. They are doing by far the most killing and dying, and they are doing it with bettertrained men, more modern equipment and greater mobility than ever.

MONTREAL, Jan. 25 -- Paul Rose, charged as a principal in the kidnapping and murder of Pierre Laporte, Quebec's Minister of Labor and Immigration, went on trial today in a Queen's Court. He told the court that his real trial would come "only when Quebec is truly free."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- One of the most eloquent passages in President Nixon's State of the Union Message followed his assertion that "as the forces that shape our lives seem to have grown more distant and more impersonal, a great feeling of frustration has crept across the land."
True to form, the Dessoff Choirs sang a program of music rarely heard anywhere for their concert at Tully Hall Sunday night.
Two shots were fired at a police patrol jeep in Central Park at West 101st Street yesterday, breaking the window next to the driver, who was cut on his forehead and left wrist by flying glass.

HOUSTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -The Houston Oilers traded Hoyle Granger, their career rushing leader, two other players and an undisclosed draft choice today to the New Orleans Saints for a defensive tackle. Dave Rowe, and a wide receiver, Ken Burrough.

The proposed $180-million merger of Spartans Industries, Inc., which operates the Korvette discount department stores, and Arlen Properties, Inc., a real-estate developer, calls for Spartans' chairman, Charles C. Bassine, to relinquish the top post in the merged company to his son-in-law, Arthur G. Cohen.

WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 25 -- Thirty-five high-school students here, disturbed by the widespread "hysteria and confusion" they say has developed over the possible recall election of the chairman of the Board of Education, have spent their entire winter and spring budget to publish a special edition of their school newspaper devoted entirely to the controversy.

SAIGON, Tuesday, Jan. 26 (Reuters) -- The Vietcong violated their announced four-day lunar new year truce twice within three hours of its start today, a South Vietnamese Government spokesman said, with attacks that left six persons dead and 22 wounded.
Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, outlined yesterday at New York University a revenue-sharing plan he said he would introduce today in the Senate.
