CERVINIA, Italy, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Fog, snow and spills hampered today's opening trials, dominated by the Italians, for the world four-man bobsled championships over the Blue Lake track.
The adoption of a state licensing examination for new teachers was urged yesterday by Murry Bergtraum, president of the City Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Two lawyers affiliated with Ralph Nader agreed today not to press immediately their suit to block a proposed $2.6-billion tax cut for business. They withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction barring the tax action after the Treasury Department promised, in open court, to hold public hearings on the issue.
TORONTO, Jan. 25 -- In a long-promised step to diminish United States influence in Canada, the Government introduced in Parliament today legislation to create a Canada Development Corporation.
The stock market leveled off yesterday at midsession for a bit of profit taking and consolidation. Then it promptly pulled another surprise by powering forward in the afternooon.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 25 -Operating income of the National Council of Churches decreased by 2.6 per cent in 1970, according to a report released here today by the council's Committee on Finance and Administration.

Werner Bamberger, a reporter for The New York Times, filed a suit for $2-million in damages against three shipping companies yesterday as a result of injuries he sustained while on a ship news assignment last Dec. 14.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 25 -- Libya and Syria, both ruled by military Governments, will soon hold national referendums to choose presidents.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia -- Ouch Keo Mony, a smiling and plump 18-year-old girl in the Cambodian Army, has almost completed her basic six weeks training. And she threw a grenade for the first time the other day.

George Young retired from track and field two years ago to run in the competitive world of big business. He found more fast hands, elbows and politics in corporate board rooms than he ever saw on an 11-lap board track.

Naomichi Toyama was in town from Tokyo yesterday to talk about the Japanese economy and, as executive vice president of the Nikko Securities Co., Ltd., the prospects for particular Japanese stocks in the months ahead.
William Griffith Wilson died late Sunday night and, with the announcement of his death, was revealed to have been the Bill W. who was a co-founder of Alcoholics Anonymous in 1935. His age was 75.
The site for a new intermediate school in Queens approved by the Site Selection Board yesterday is under a flight path to Kennedy International Airport.
The film of last October's World Series, starring Brooks Robinson, made its debut yesterday in a special preview at Toots Shor's restaurant.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 -Charles M. Manson and three young women who were members of his hippie family were found guilty today of the TateLaBianca murders.

William T. Dentzer Jr., who last April was named New York State Superintendent of Banks, laid out in definitive terms yesterday legislative proposals that would bring sweeping changes in the state's banking structure.

Consolidated Edison's most powerful generator, a millionkilowatt turbine that has been inoperative since last July, broke down again during testing over the weekend, delaying indefinitely its return to service.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- Well, there was no place for them to go but up, right? Even though the rise in hemlines was predictable, American manufacturers and retailer here for the spring couture shows tend to regard it as the end of the world.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany arrived today for one of the semiannual meetings with France and dissipated talk of a crisis in Western Europe over methods of achieving an economic and monetary union.

The American Museum of Natural History announced yesterday that Miss Miriam Colon Edgar, an actress known professionally as Miriam Colon, had been elected a member of the museum's board of trustees.

A college athlete obviously loses his varsity and other amateur eligibility when he signs a contract with a professional team. P. J. Barry calls his play, "Heritage," an "American folk tale about the Lincoln women." The women -- grandmother, mother, stepmother, sweetheart, wife -- are the principal characters on stage, but the play is about Lincoln Mr. Barry's contribution to theater history is that his is a Lincoln play in which Lincoln does not appear.

BONN, Jan. 25 -- West Berlin's million or more citizens who have been unable to visit their relatives in the city's eastern sector since 1966 will at least be permitted to talk with them directly by telephone starting Sunday under a new agreement.

Lovers of good dancers will find a lot of good dancers to love at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where last night the Belgian National Ballet, which calls itself the Ballet of the 20th Century, made its United States debut.

Throughout his history man has been battling cold as if it were an enemy. The Arctic squirrel, the marmot, the brown bat retire into hibernation and let the chilling winds pass them by. The bird, propelled by physiological drives from one continent to another, escapes from winter.
The American Stock Exchange scored its 11th consecutive advance yesterday as the list continued to move ahead in active trading.
Interest rates on short-term tax-exempt notes took a big step downward yesterday as the credit markets continued to display the extraordinary strength they have built up recently.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 25 -- American officials have developed a program for a "military equipment delivery team" that would send United States military representatives through the Cambodian countryside to check on deployment of American military equipment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A revised national health insurance plan that would pay $50-billion a year to cover more than two-thirds of the medical expenses of all Americans was introduced in the Senate today.

TRENTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- James Del Mauro, former presiding magistrate in Newark, was suspended by the state today for one year from practicing law on the ground that he accepted fees for performing marriages, a violation of a directive of the court.

DETROIT, Jan. 25 -- New-car sales continued to run ahead of last year in mid-January with all four United States car makers showing gains. An improvement was expected because of last year's sales slump in January and because of the General Motors Corporation's strike make-up now.

TEHERAN, Iran Jan. 25 -- A Venezuelan official said today, after conferring with Iran's chief oil negotiator, that the Persian Gulf oil countries were on the way to a price agreement with Western companies. He said an export embargo by oil-producing countries was unlikely.

VIENNA, Ill., Jan. 25 (UPI) -The private secretary and the chief administrative aide to the late Paul Powell Illinois, Secretary of State, were charged today wth illegally transferring a portion of Mr. Powell's cash hoard after his death.

The preliminary net income of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., in the final quarter of 1970 fell to $63,258,000, or $1.29 a share, from $79,246,000, or $1.55 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1969, it was reported yesterday.

Smith, Kline French Laboratories announced yesterday a major realignment of the corporate organization, plus the retirement of Walter A. Munns, chairman, in April. Brian Mahoney scored 26 points last night to lead Manhattan to a 90-54 victory over St. Francis before 400 fans at the 69th Regiment Armory court.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- A document attributed to shipyard workers in the Polish port of Gdynia during the riots there last month accuses Maj. Gen. Mieczyslaw Moczar, then an alternate member of the Politburo, of using brutality to suppress them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -Senator James L. Buckley said today that he regarded President Nixon's revenue-sharing proposals as an emergency solution, rather than a permanent one, to the fiscal problems of state and local governments.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 27 -- With the arrest today of a 31-year-old bartender, the police said they had broken up a $2-million-a-year policy operation.
The head of the West German central bank yesterday defended the bank's decision to hold the discount rate at 6 per cent as a means to counteract inflation.

When Community Planning Board 4, covering the Corona and Elmhurst sections got around to discussing a city proposal for a new expressway in Queens, one of its members raised the question of the board's responsibility.

Platinum, a high-priced metal, has long been swayed in price by the political and economic winds blowing in two countries, the biggest suppliers of the metal, namely the Soviet Union and South Africa.
TUBINGEN, Germany -- Is a church credible when it preaches peace, justice, freedom and democracy to the world, but finds itself incapable of realizing these ideals within its own walls?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Nixon Administration will attempt to abolish all funds for the Appalachian Regional Commission, the five-year-old Federal-state economic recovery agency designed to aid the largest impoverished area of the country, Congressional sources said today.
Federally backed tax-exempt housing bonds were sold yesterday at an interest cost below 5 per cent for the first time since 1968.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 27 -- Israel submitted a new written policy statement today for transmission to the United Arab Republic in the indirect Arab-Israeli peace talks.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 27 -- A New York-based conglomerate with assets of $1-billion has "agreed in principle" to take over Suffolk Downs from Realty Equities, Inc., a spokesman for the financially troubled race track said today.

Bernard J. Lasker, chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, will attempt to obtain a moratorium on any more institutional membership on any of the nation's stock exchanges, pending a resolution of the institutional issue by the Big Board.

In announcing his first season as music director of the New York Philarmonic, Pierre Boulez said he thought he would follow the lead of the art museums. Museums, he noted, always have masterpieces on display, but they also arrange special exhibitions devoted to a big painter, an important period, special phases of art, research and experimentation.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 27 -- Milwaukee policemen returned to work today after their four-day strike was broken by a court order.

Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, called yesterday for state teacher and supervisory examinations similar to those given in medicine and law, instead of those now administered by the controversial Board of Examiners.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- A bill permitting school districts to stagger their vacation schedules and keep schoolhouses open year-round was introduced today in both houses of the Legislature.

Exhausting the 17,250 frenetic fans at Madison Square Garden, who were ready to roar at the least excuse, the Rangers and the Boston Bruins clawed their way to a 2-2 tie last night in a rugged game with playoff overtones.
Wall Street has been looking in vain for a way to make money in pollution-control stocks over the long term. At last, a sensible approach may be in sight.

MIAMI, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Cloyce Bradley Cook, the runaway son of a Piedmont, S. C., preacher, was barely 17 years old, blond, polite and adrift with only a few dollars in this city of expensive hotels and palm-studded beaches.

Breed standards are changed because of a desire to conform to modern fashions, or because of an attempt to improve the breed in soundness, health or beauty, or just because of the general restlessness and boredom that afflict many in America today, according to Mrs. Hayes Blake Hoyt of Washington, Depot, Conn., a world authority on poodles.
Members of an official advisory committee sued St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday, charging that the hospital was deliberately withholding information they needed to perform their duties.

Carnegie Hall-Jeunesses Musicales, Inc., an organization that presents young foreign artists by arrangement with the Jeunesses Musicales of other countries, offered a recital by Keiko Furiyoshi, Japanese violinist, in Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night.

Three West Coast banking giants announced yesterday across-the-board reductions in the rates charged on consumer loans, the second cut of half a percentage point since Thanksgiving. The Bank of America, the nation's largest, kicked off the round of cuts and was followed within a few hours by the Wells Fargo Bank and the Crocker-Citizens National Bank.

THE HAGUE, Jan. 27 (Reuters) -- South Africa said today that she was willing to hold a plebiscite in the territory of South-West Africa to let the people decide if they want to remain under South African administration or would prefer United Nations supervision.

A 77-year-old Queens guard, although fatally wounded by two gunmen, managed to kill one of his asailants, a former patrolman here, during a holdup in a Bayside savings and loan association, the police said.

In the first set of elimination matches to determine the world championship challenger, Grandmaster Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles will play Grandmaster Mark Taimanov of the Soviet Union. Though Taimanov is sure to play with spirit, nobody seriously thinks he will score an upset.
Captain Beefheart the Magic Band, a Los Angeles group, is playing through tonight at Ungano's, 210 West 70th Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced today that it would cut off $36.8-million in welfare aid to Arizona on April 1 unless the state complied with Federal public assistance regulations.
Two textile dye companies were indicted on Federal water pollution charges here yesterday as a special grand jury neared the end of its investigations of alleged industrial polluters in the area.

It was chamber-music time for the Little Orchestra Society at Tully Hall on Tuesday night, and Thomas Scherman devised a program that, characteristically for him and his organization, contained works one seldom hears.
An attempt to form a unified group within the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to oppose Edward J. Kiernan, the acting president, in next June's union election appeared to founder yesterday.

Philip Morris, Inc., realized a 32.8 per cent increase in 1970 earnings on a revenue gain of 32.1 per cent, both establishing records, Joseph F. Cullman 3d, chairman of the diversified, multinational tobacco company, reported yesterday.

The Jan. 2 letter by Aubrey J. Wagner, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, postulates two points, both of which are absolutely false: (a) T.V.A. has pioneered in reclamation of strip-mined lands and (b) stripping can be done in the nation's coal fields without lasting damage to the environment.
OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Kaiser Aluminum Chemical Corporation today reduced its distributor discounts on a wide variety of large volume sheet and plate products effective April 1.
Maj. Gen. Idi Amin, Uganda's new head of state, was the Ugandan army's heavy-weight boxing champion for nearly 10 years.

Philip Morris, Inc., realized a 32.8 per cent increase in 1970 earnings on a revenue gain of 32.1 per cent, both establishing records, Joseph F. Cullman 3d, chairman of the diversified, multinational tobacco company, reported yesterday.

The Jan. 2 letter by Aubrey J. Wagner, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, postulates two points, both of which are absolutely false: (a) T.V.A. has pioneered in reclamation of strip-mined lands and (b) stripping can be done in the nation's coal fields without lasting damage to the environment.
OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Kaiser Aluminum Chemical Corporation today reduced its distributor discounts on a wide variety of large volume sheet and plate products effective April 1.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second largest steel producer, announced a cut in its quarterly dividend yesterday, to 30 cents a share from 45 cents, payable March 10 to stockholders of record Feb. 9.
ATLANTA, Jan. 27 -- Those who look for logic in basketball were given no encouragement whatever tonight as the New York Knicks defeated the Atlanta Hawks, 116-108.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -Secretary of State William P. Rogers assured a restive Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that the Administration had no intention of expanding the scope of American military activities in Cambodia.

The current feature in the Whitney Museum's New American Film Makers Series is Cassandra Gerstein's "Tales," which will play through Feb. 3. For this film only, the museum is limiting admission to persons 18 years of age and older. As you might surmise, "Tales" has something to do with sex.

KAMPALA, Uganda, Jan. 28 (Reuters) -- Uganda's new ruler, Maj. Gen. Idi Amin, today freed 55 political prisoners, dismissed the Cabinet of the ousted President, Milton Obote, and imposed a temporary ban on political activities.
Airline stocks, the Wail Street wallflowers of late 1970, blossomed into favor yesterday. In the process, airlines led the stock market higher after Wednesday's wave of profit taking.
KHARTOUM, Sudan -- Politically and economically, Sudan maintained its leftist trend in 1970.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- A South Vietnamese convoy in which fuel ships were escorted to Pnompenh was organized and commanded by radio by an American admiral, allied military sources said today.
ABU GHOSH, Israel, Jan. 28 -- "As Israeli Arabs, our problem is that other Arabs dismiss us as Israelis and other Israelis suspect us as Arabs."

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- The growing economic role in southern Africa of the three former British territories of Swaziland, Botswana and Lesotho was recognized last year by the signing of a revised customs agreement between the three countries and South Africa.

Playing in Philharmonic Hall Wednesday night, on the eve of his 84th birthday, Artur Rubinstein did not sound as if he were growing old gracefully. After hearing his performances of Liszt's "Funerailles" and Twelth Rhapsody, the listener could only conclude that the great pianist was growing young magnificently.

In the spoken preface to his play "A Memory of Two Mondays," put on last night by National Education Television over Channel 13, Arthur Miller remarked that he doesn't share the nostalgia for the thirties that he finds cropping up now among the young, who never lived through those times.

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast -One of the problems of analysts trying to assess economic performance of this prospering West African country last year was to find substitutes for the terms "stupendous" and "fabulous," liberally used in past years.

Like many New Yorkers I have been robbed, and had my apartment broken into. For the burglar it must have been a soft touch because I was unprepared and had taken little in the way of precautionary measures. As did this country after Pearl Harbor, I vowed that never again would I be caught unprepared.

Natalia Makarova, the Soviet ballerina who defected to the West last September and is now dancing with the American Ballet Theater, won a State Supreme Court order yesterday to enable her to reenter her Park Avenue apartment and get her costumes and ballet shoes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Change and revolution are generally supposed to be two of the most painful processes in human experience, but most of the talk in Washington now is about painless change and painless revolution.
WASHINGTON -- Samuel Simon works for a secretive monk-like bachelor who frowns on hard liquor, cigarettes, bridge, suburbanites staring at television and other frivolous activities.
"THERE'S no such place as Africa!" I was told not long ago by an official from East Africa, tired of the way people regarded the continent as an entity.

The principal of troubled Julia Richman High School in Manhattan has been removed by Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, Chancellor of the city schools, on the basis of an "unsatisfactory" rating, a spokesman for the Board of Education said last night.

Birny Mason Jr. announced yesterday that he planned to retire as chairman and chief executive officer of the Union Carbide Corporation and that F. Perry Wilson, president, would succeed him in both posts, effective after the company's annual meeting April 21.

LUSAKA, Zambia -- White Rhodesians used to chuckle as they pointed out that the United Nations economic sanctions against their break-away British colony were hurting neighboring Zambia. And they were right.

When the Jets' turn developed in the first round of the National Football League draft, their primary choice, J. D. Hill of Arizona State, had been selected by the Buffalo Bills. Presumably, the Jets now would choose John Brockington, the big running back from Ohio State.

CAIRO -- The mighty Aswan High Dam has finally been completed after 11 years of toil by Egyptians and Russians in the heat of Upper Egypt. Its 12 Soviet-supplied turbines stand ready to generate a total of 10 billion kilowatt hours of electricity annually. And the Nile has filled Lake Nasser to about half of its ultimate capacity of 157 billion cubic meters, assuring Egypt of a steady flow of water for its irrigated fields.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -Gordon Chase, the New York City health services administrator, appeared before Congress today to accuse medical insurance plans such as Blue Cross of helping to drive up spiraling health care costs by failing to crack down on the inefficiencies of hospitals.

There is unpleasant news for practically everybody in the state-tax increases Governor Rockefeller plans to ask the Legislature to enact this year. Even without the projected increases, New Yorkers have been carrying the heaviest combined load of state and local taxes in the nation -- a total of $576 per capita, more than double the figure of a decade ago.

Before I began it, my curiosity about Karl Dietrich Bracher's "The German Dictatorship" had been aroused by a couple of reviews of the German edition and by an emphatic declaration from Peter Gay -no pushover -- in his introduction to the American edition that this was "the first serious comprehensive history of the Nazi phenomenon.
FAIRFAX, Va., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Former Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall was cleared today of a charge of shoplifting after the store involved dropped the case.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Stung by criticism of the massive South Mall state office building project, Governor Rockefeller declared today that the mall "is going to turn out to be the greatest thing that has happened to this country in 100 years."

WASHINGTON -- The President's proposal to reorganize eight of the Cabinet departments into four departments -- human resources, community development, natural resources, and economic development -- will raise the hackles of virtually every special interest group in Washington.

I support your editorial conclusion of Jan. 8 that President Nixon's Emergency School Aid Bill should be enacted by the 92d Congress without delay. This bill would authorize $1.5 billion in new funds for schools throughout the nation. As the editorial correctly notes, these funds would "help Southern school districts eliminate dual school systems and underwrite Northern efforts to attain better-integrated quality education in de facto segregated schools."

In most of Maurice Bejart's work, even the worst, there is usually a shrewd kind of theatricality. In "Messe Pour Le Temps Present," which was given its United States premiere Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, there seemed to be no quality at all to redeem or even mitigate the boring, pretentious pomposity of a work that was numbing in its intentions and excruciating in its execution.

A. Frank Reel's revulsion at the conviction of General Yamashita for atrocities of which he could not have been aware is understandable. (Letter Jan. 19). But it is the counsel of dangerous despair that war is "an essentially criminal pastime" for which no laws can be formulated.

NAIROBI, Kenya -- Problems are inevitable when sovereign states co-operate on joint undertakings and the East African Community is no exception, President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania said last November.

The Boston Patriots, looking for a future hero to help fill their new stadium in suburban Foxboro, Mass., are going to hold on to Jim Plunkett, their new gem they acquired at the top of the National Football League draft yesterday.
DETROIT, Jan. 28 -- The General Motors Corporation today reported a $135-million loss in its fourth quarter, the largest for such a period in G.M.'s history.

LISBON -- Premier Marcello Caetano's offer of greater autonomy to Portugal's colonies has opened new economic as well as political perspectives, particularly for the two vast and potentially wealthy African territories of Angola and Mozambique.

Louis Hemsey, a 22-year-old guitarist and a graduate of the Mannes College of Music, gave a recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night. His program included Britten's "Nocturnal," an arrangement of Bach's Chaconne in D minor for unaccompanied violin, pavanes by Milan, a suite by John Duarte, preludes by Villa-Lobos and Turina's "Rafaga."

John J. Cassese, former president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, testified in State Supreme Court yesterday that the P.B.A. reached a "final, absolute agreement" with the city on Jan. 29, 1969, and that it contained a parity adjustment provision without any conditions or qualifications.

A group of national and local Jewish organizations reaffirmed their opposition yesterday to state aid for religious education, saying that such aid posed a "grave threat to the independence of religion and the stability of government."

The following letter was handwritten inside a South Vietnamese Government jail on Dec. 21 and smuggled out shortly thereafter. It is signed by three monks, representing some 500 of different religions, who are mainly imprisoned for their refusal to bear arms.
In airline boardrooms from one end of the African continent to the other, 1971 is expected to be an exciting and challenging year for the carriers that make their bases south of the Mediterranean.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe issued today a final outline of basic rail passenger service to be operated by a quasi-governmental corporation beginning May 1.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 -Ralph Ginzburg, the New York publisher who has remained free since being sentenced to prison in 1963 on an obscenity conviction, fought today to have the sentence reduced to probation.
Analysts studying loan demand for early signs of an economic recovery saw little to encourage them in yesterday's weekly banking data published by the Federal Reserve.
In more and more cases, looking for a dreamboat means looking for a boat that floats on air.

After talking endlessly about the need to bolster their defense, the New York Giants wound up making two little publicized offensive players their first two draft choices yesterday. They were Ralph (Rocky) Thompson, a running back from West Texas State who will be used as a wide receiver, and Wayne Walton, an offensive tackle from Abilene Christian.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Western oil companies dropped their demand for a global price agreement with producer countries today, according to oil industry sources and news reports, but found stiff conditions attached to even a regional agreement covering the Persian Gulf.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- In a seemingly routine press release issued late yesterday, the Office of Education announced the appointment of an acting director of the Teacher Corps, which sends 3,000 young teachers to help out in schools in poor communities across the country.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 28 (UPI) -- Vice President Agnew met Harry S. Truman for the first time today in the 86-year-old former President's hospital room. Mr. Agnew described Mr. Truman as "alert and very relaxed."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The United States command today reported an increase in American casualties in Indochina last week, and spokesmen attributed the rise largely to two plane crashes that killed 14 servicemen.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 28 -- United States District Court Judge William K. Thomas ruled illegal today a report by the Portage County grand jury on the disorders last May at Kent State University.

The Lindsay administration is weighing a plan to decongest midtown Manhattan by closing portions of Broadway and Madison and Lexington Avenues to automobile traffic and making them permanent pedestrian malls.

AS African countries push on with development, their problems are getting more complex. Some, such as integration of urban and rural economies, are familiar in the developed countries. But all are new to Africans, especially an increasingly critical African phenomenon -- the "educated unemployed" who are jobless despite a shortage of trained manpower.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 -- The United States command made public today a general summary of American involvement in last week's joint Cambodian-South Vietnamese operation to clear Route 4 south of Pnompenh but refused when asked to provide a specific count of American bombing strikes or other air missions.

NEWARK, Jan. 28 -- A team of Federal housing specialists charged today that the Newark Housing Authority was "top-heavy" with superfluous employes and "wasteful" in its management of this city's public housing and urban renewal programs.

Dr. John H. Fischer, president of Teachers College, Columbia University, advocated yesterday a plan for the state licensing of the city's public school teachers, under which they would have to prove their competency at least twice during their careers. He said he did not favor the present tenure for life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -House Democrats completed their biennial game of musical chairs with committee assignments today, leaving two angry freshman members from New York holding seats they did not want.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Eleven college newspaper editors discussed American policy in Indochina with Secretary of State William P. Rogers today and, in an unexpected 15-minute meeting, with President Nixon at the White House this afternoon.

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Jan. 28 (Reuters) -- President Sekou Toure of Guinea has refused to spare those condemned to death for having taken part in last November's abortive coup, the Conakry radio reported today.
MINAQISH, Kuwait, Jan. 10 -- Abdul Aziz al-Ghanim ignored the desert around him and the Bedouin retainers who had kissed the bridge of his nose as they greeted him.

The Boston Patriots picked Jim Plunkett of Stanford first in the National Football League draft yesterday, spurning trade offers right up to 9:50 A.M., 10 minutes before the selection of 442 college players began.
LIBREVILLE, Gabon -- The French-speaking African republic Of Gabon entered the 1970's with the scales loaded heavily in her favor.
ENUGU, Nigeria -- After being closed for nearly three years because of Nigeria's civil war, the Permatex Spinning and Weaving Company here is back in business.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 28 -- Secretary General Thant and Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, his special representative for the Middle East, were reported today to be preparing a public statement asserting that the indirect Arab-Israeli peace talks had begun satisfactorly and must be continued.
A Federal indictment charged here yesterday that the Teleprompter Corporation obtained an exclusive cable television franchise by bribing the Mayor and two other officials of Johnstown, Pa.
PRA LOUP, France, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Austria's Alpine marvels raced back to form today with a 1-2 finish in the 12nation World Cup women's downhill ski competition.

The Bach Aria Group had to change its Bach program substantially for its concert at Tully Hall Wednesday night. Its soprano, Lois Marshall, was ill, and so alto, tenor and bass arias were substituted wherever there had been soprano ones.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The penalty phase of the Sharon Tate murder trial began today with Charles M. Manson shouting at the judge and being ejected from the courtroom for punching his lawyer.
BOSTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) -Bill Veeck said tonight he had resigned as president of the Suffolk Downs race track.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- Despite a labor shortage, a growing balance of payments deficit, rising living costs and the threat of inflation, South Africa's economy showed a healthy growth in 1970 and Government officials say the country can look to the future with confidence.
LAGOS, Nigeria -- The postwar recovery of Nigeria's booming oil industry is complete, according to yearend statistics and insiders' evaluations here.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the sixth largest American steel producer, which is 81 per cent owned by Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., reported yesterday that it sustained a net loss -- counting nonrecurring charges -of $19.7-million in the final quarter of 1970.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 28 -- The Anglican Dean of Johannesburg, detained eight days ago by the security police, was released on $7,000 bail here today after being charged with distributing Communist pamphlets calling for guerrilla warfare.
FORT-LAMY, Chad -- The unpromising economy of this landlocked African republic will probably continue to be sapped this year by the rebellion of nomadic tribesmen against the Government.
Numbing cold continued to assault much of the East yesterday, provoking power shortages and mishaps and more than the usual number of sighs for spring.

History is repeating itself in Southeast Asia. The insidious insertion of American military power into Cambodia in support of a faltering regime ominously parallels the events of early 1965 which entrapped the United States in a major war in neighboring Vietnam.

John J. Concannon, an assistant editor of Newsweek, has been elected president of the New York Financial Writers' Association. He succeeds Leonard Sloane, a business and financial reporter of The New York Times.
Applying the term "jazz singer" to a performer is one of the easier ways to start an argument. But there is never any doubt about Jimmy Rushing.

CULVER CITY, Calif., Jan. 28 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., will improve its profits in the second fiscal quarter and remain profitable throughout the year, James T. Aubrey Jr., president, told the annual meeting of stockholders here today.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 28 -- A federal court today ordered a Jesuit priest to testify before a grand jury that has indicted six persons on charges of conspiracy to blow up Washington heating tunnels and kidnap a Presidential adviser, Henry A. Kissinger.
Interest rates on high-grade tax-exempt bonds turned upward yesterday, halting the pronounced swing toward lower yields that lasted through most of January.

BONN -- Currently, Europe's most talked about foreign policy is that of West Germany's Chancellor Willy Brandt, which seeks, by taking the initiative, to lower existing barriers with the Soviet bloc. Brandt's much debated Ostpolitik gambles that Communist society so desperately needs access to Western techniques and materials that it is willing to pay with political concessions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -The Supreme Court instructed all Federal magistrates today that they do not have to inform defendants in "petty" cases that defense lawyers will be furnished by the Government if they are too poor to hire their own counsel.

KAMPALA, Uganda -- One of Africa's most fertile countries, Uganda is unlikely to suffer any setback to her productive agricultural economy as a result of the military coup that overthrew the Government of President Milton Obote earlier this week.

Prentice-Hall, Inc., in Englewood Cliffs, N. J., announced yesterday the election of Richard Prentice Ettinger, chairman and co-founder, to the post of chairman emeritus. He was succeeded by Paul R. Andrews as chairman. Frank J. Dunnigan, executive vice president, was appointed to replace Mr. Andrews as president and chief executive officer.
The LASH Italia, a new type of ship that has been plagued by labor problems, arrived here yesterday, introducing a different concept of cargo handling to the port.

The Department of Justice and Samuel J. Lefrak, one of the nation's largest builders, reached an agreement yesterday in which the Lefrak Organization promised to prohibit discrimination in apartment rentals.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 28 -- Mayor Teddy Kollek announced today that controversial new Israeli housing projects on the rocky hillsides around Jerusalem would be delayed pending further esthetic and urban-development study.

The Joint Legislative Committee on Crime opened a public hearing yesterday into the alleged connections between organized crime and the "business dealings and associations" of Lewis S. Rosenstiel, the multimillionaire former chairman of the board of Schenley Industries, Inc.
KINSHASA, the Congo -The recent vigorous expansion of the Congolese economy reached a high point last year as copper production and exports set records.

ACCRA, Ghana -- Take a walk through any African city, visit its markets. In an hour you will learn more about why there is such a strong urge for development in Africa than from any long study of the latest five-year plans.
YAOUNDE, Cameroon -- In filling public health needs, most African countries must still depend on foreign universities to train their medical students.
A 61-year-old Detroit widower won the top prize yesterday in the second special $1million New York State lottery.

The men who sell the product of the Miller Brewing Company (beer) who have been wondering what direction they'd be taking with a new owner (Phillip Morris) and new ad agency (McCann-Erickson) found out yesterday.

BOSTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- Ken Hodge and Fred Stanfield scored consecutive power-play goals tonight and Don Marcotte added a short-handed tally to pace the Boston Bruins to a 6-2 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -President Nixon asked Congress today to approve $1.5-billion in pay increases and other benefits for servicemen to help achieve his goal of ending the military draft by mid-1973.
Wide fluctuations continue to dominate soybean trading. At one point, prices for the beans were down almost 3 cents a bushel yesterday.

LAGOS, Nigeria -- "This country has a genuine and powerful economy, and that makes it different from its neighbors," a member of Nigeria's growing middle class explained the other day. "If only we can remain unified politically, there will be no way that we can be stopped," he said.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 28 -- The United States military teams that are to move through Cambodia to check on the use of American military aid are to travel in civilian clothes with instructions to remain out of combat areas, official sources said today.
The Court on the Judiciary will be convened this year to investigate the judicial conduct of State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer.

Earnings of the Phillips Petroleum Company last year declined 8 per cent to $117.1million or $1.58 a share from $127.8-million or $1.73 a share in 1969, despite record revenues of $2,304,500,000 which gained 3 per cent from $2,227,300,000.

One of the world's great partnerships returns to international competition today after a long period of retirement. Robert Jordan and Arthur Robinson of Philadelphia, who have played brilliantly for America in several world championship contests, begin play in London in the Sunday Times Invitation Pair Tournament.

BLANTYRE, Malawi -- Despite pressure from the rest of black Africa, Dr. H. Kamuzu Banda, the controversial President of Malawi, consolidated his policy of neighborliness with whiteruled South Africa during 1970.

David Wiggins, 10 years old, lives within walking distance of Central Park's Lasker Rink at 110th Street, but he never ventured down Lenox Avenue to watch the skaters gliding across the ice, and he certainly never figured to take up ice skating.

NEWARK, Jan. 28 -- The United Auto Workers and the National Committee Against Discrimination in Housing filed a complaint here today charging that local zoning laws are depriving union members -- many of them low-income blacks -from living near their jobs at the Ford Motor Company assembly plant in Mahwah.

Skaggs Companies, Inc., has started preliminary discussions to acquire Albertson's, Inc., operators of more than 200 supermarkets, through an exchange of stock valued at approximately $103-million based on the closing price of Skaggs yesterday.

Marty Liquori says he is ready, Tom Von Ruden predicts it will happen, and Fred Schmertz is praying for the first sub-four-minute Wanamaker Mile tonight in the 64th Wanamaker Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden.

In a report replete with details of leaking roofs and dilapidated rooms, of official confusion and of teachers who sometimes refuse to teach, a special panel investigating the city's three juvenile detention centers recommended yesterday that their administration be transferred from the judicial system to the Mayor's office.
Arthur Ashe paid Rod Laver the supreme tribute last night after the red-haired Australian had won his seventh straight $10,000 match in the $210,000 Tennis Champions Classic.

"Art is, after all, a developed taste -- like eating olives," Assemblyman Louis DeSalvio told the Board of Estimate yesterday as he took issue with a provision of the new zoning being created for artists in a 43-block area south of Houston Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President Nixon's busy courtship of Congressmen from both parties this week is without precedent in his Administration. It arises both from the importance he attaches to his domestic program and from the new "open door" approach to Congress brought to the White House by former Representative Clark MacGregor of Minnesota, now Mr. Nixon's top adviser on Congressional affairs.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today the appointment of Norman F. Gallman as State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance. He has been Acting Commissioner since the resignation of Joseph W. Murphy July 1, 1969.
When Dr. James G. Emerson Jr., was named to head the Community Service Society in 1969, he said his first job would be to see how the family-service agency could best contribute to the city.

Herbert Stein's Jan. 20 Op-Ed statement on the Nixon economy correctly stresses the respectable antecedents of the full-employment budgeting concept. What Mr. Stein neglected to say was that the Nixon Administration really has no alternative but to use the concept in putting together the new budget.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan 28 -- The horses are running slightly more to form in the early part of the Santa Anita season this year and the California Horse Racing Board thinks Butazolidin may have something to do with it.

BATHURST, Gambia -Shortly after proclaiming Gambia a republic last April, Sir Dauda Jawara, former premier and new president, announced that his Government would defer, for another year or two, the establishment of a permanent mission to the United Nations.

The opening-night performance of the Siberian Dancers and Singers of Omsk of the Soviet Union was interrupted briefly at Carnegie Hall last night by a telephoned bomb threat and the scattering of 10 bottles of ammonia throughout the orchestra section and balcony.

"The Cage," a proto-women's lib ballet featuring an ingenue earning her fangs, was danced Wednesday evening for the first time by Gelsey Kirkland as the Novice. The work, long a staple of New York City Ballet's repertory, was prodded interestingly by Miss Kirkland's virulent spontaneity as the girl learning to destroy the male she loved as well as the one she didn't love.

When gusty wind begins ripping through southern Vermont, Hans Thorner, the colorful ski area operator of Magic Mountain, quickly ascertains from which direction it is blowing. If it is coming from the west, he ignores it.

CAIRO -- For the Egyptian people burdened by the costs and casualties of warfare with Israel, 1970 brought a respite through a cease-fire along the Suez Canal and, importantly, promises of a new period of attention to the economic and social needs of the "common man."

The past two weeks have proved that New York City's electric power problems are not confined to the summer when air conditioners are turned up to maximum performance. Four times in the last few days Con Edison and other New York State power companies have had to reduce voltages as their resources proved inadequate to meet the demands generated by the intense cold weather.
SAN DIEGO, Jan. 28 -- Ralph Johnston, a rookie on the pro golf tour from New York scored an amazing 66 in the opening round of the $150,000 Andy Williams San Diego open tourney today.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania -- The biggest economic event in this East African country last year was the start of construction by Communist China of the muchdiscussed, long-awaited TanzanianZambian railway.

WARSAW, Jan. 28 -- A medical report indicating a worsening of Wladyslaw Gomulka's illness has ended speculation that the former Communist party chief might seek to defend himself at a forthcoming meeting of the Central Committee.

FREETOWN, Sierra Leone -- A slump in diamond markets, one of the relatively minor effects of the economic slowdown in the United States and elsewhere in the developed world, is threatening a major economic setback for this small West African country.

BONN, Jan. 28 -- Chancellor Willy Brandt called on the leaders of East Germany today to stop trying to undermine his policy of seeking improved relations with the Soviet bloc and to help set an example for the outside world of two friendly but contrasting states.

William E. Phipps's startling announcement of the marriage of Jesus of Nazareth to Mary Magdalene is based on his studies revealing "not a single instance of life-long celibacy recorded anywhere in the records of Palestinian Judaism."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- By unanimous voice vote and with fewer than a dozen members present, the Senate confirmed today the nomination of former Representative Rogers C. B. Morton to be President Nixon's new Interior Secretary.

Much Venetian music of the late Renaissance was meant to be played antiphonally, which is to say by instrumental groups divided into opposing bands facing off across town squares or church interiors. MONROVIA, Liberia -Buoyed by record production of iron ore and rubber, her two main products, Liberia is hoping that rising revenues will begin to ease the burden of heavy debt payments.

The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

BUFFALO, Jan. 28 -- With only one flaw in their program, Ken Shelley and Jo Jo Starbuck of Downey, Calif., successfully defended their senior pairs title in the United States figure-skating championships tonight at War Memorial Auditorium.

Bloomingdale's, the Manhattan - based department store chain, announced yesterday that it would erect a 250,000-square-foot store in Garden City, L. I., to open in fall 1972. It will be only two blocks from a branch store of Abraham Straus, which, like Bloomingdale's, is owned by Federated Department Stores, Inc., of Cincinnati.
NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania -- The Mauritanian economy improved solidly in 1970 and hopes run high for this year.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- The American Civil Liberties Union, which filed the suit challenging the report and is defending several of those indicted, said today that it doubted whether a fair trial was now possible.
GANVIE, Dahomey -- Although still in the early stages of economic development, Dahomey has learned that technological gains sometimes pose ecological problems.

LOME, Togo -- In these inflationary times, an American, or almost any foreigner, strolling through the markets of this West African city might briefly wonder whether his eyesight or arithmetic was failing.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., stomped off the court in anger today after losing a close match to Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia in the quarterfinals of the Victorian tennis championships.

ACCRA, Ghana -- Although still burdened by the heavy debts inherited from the government of Kwame Nkrumah, Ghana made encouraging progress last year toward the goal of again becoming one of West Africa's most prosperous countries.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 28 -- The Apollo 14 countdown, described by a space agency official as the "cleanest" ever, proceeded smoothly today with launching technicians putting the finishing touches on the $305-million moonship.

WINDHOEK, South - West Africa -- Mining, the infant prodigy of South-West Africa's economy in the sixties -is an infant no longer. The industry has expanded rapidly since 1966 when the World Court dismissed an Ethiopian suit challenging South Africa's League of Nation's mandate over South-West Africa.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 28 -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi sits in the back of her convertible as it speeds along the Faizabad - Gorakhpur highway in Uttar Pradesh on the way to an election meeting at Maniram.

YONKERS, Jan. 28 -- In 1962, a 2-year-old pacing horse named Gaviland won 13 races and was the fourth best standardbred in number of victories in the nation. The horse's career seemed promising.

BUFFALO, Jan. 30 -- Janet Lynn, a 17-year-old high school girl from Rockford, Ill., shook off a fall earlier in her freeskating program today and won the United States senior women's figure skating championship for the third straight time. WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -One of the Nixon Administration's most controversial crime control measures, the omnibus District of Columbia Crime Control Act of 1970, goes into effect Monday amid efforts to strike down several of its key provisions as unconstitutional.

When it comes to a question of height, Donald Davidson of the Atlanta Braves is no more to be trusted than an oversized basketball player. Like them, he exaggerates. According to the unreliable Donald, he is 4 feet 1 inch tall, a palpable misstatement of fact. Everyone in the baseball business knows that he is exactly 4 feet tall.

NORTH HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30 -- John Trembley of Tennessee tied a National Collegiate swimming record last week and Rick Colella of Washington missed a record by a tenth of a second. I was interested to note in The Times of Jan. 13 that Joseph Curran of the National Maritime Union is once again advocating the return to the high seas of the once-proud passenger liners of the United States flag lines. I certainly agree with him that these ships should be sailing from American ports and foreign ports as well, for that matter.

After 14 months of opposition from more than 30 bus companies, including Greyhound and Continental Trailways, a black-owned charter bus service was begun in Harlem last week.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30 -- Space-ship stylists have kept the familiar exterior look on the 1971 Apollo vehicle that takes off for the moon tomorrow. But on the inside there are more than a dozen changes -- contributions to safety dictated by the near catastrophe on the Apollo 13 flight last April.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 30 (UPI) -- Dave Soutar of Gilroy, Calif., won the 11th title in his 10-year pro career today when he defeated Dick Ritger, 235210, for the championship and $6,000 in the $50,000 Greater Los Angeles bowling tournament.

MILFORD, Mich., Jan. 30 -- The General Motors Corporation says that overlapping responsibilities of various government bodies caused a delay in the installation of antipollution systems at its Chevrolet plant on the Hudson River at Tarrytown, N. Y.

THE American Revolution Bicentennial Commission's advisory panel on coins and medals has reached no decision on issues to commemorate the nation's 200th birthday in 1976. A cosmetic company that had just developed a new line of products in the men's toiletries field was puzzled about which distribution systems to use in selling the merchandise. The New York Mets received five signed contracts yesterday, raising the total of satisfied players on their major league roster to 26. Fourteen remain unsigned.

HAVE you made your plans for the four-day holiday coming up the weekend after next? And for the other eight long weekends (see box on Page 7) in store this year? The year 1971 will have more three-day and four-day weekends than any previous year in the modern era because the Monday Holiday Law enacted by Congress a couple of years ago is just now taking effect.

The General Motors Corporation, in a tacit recognition of the growing demand for controls on air and water pollution created a new department yesterday to supervise company activities related to the environment.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 1 -- The United States command reported today that six American soldiers had been killed and more than 26 wounded in an upsurge of enemy attacks on American positions in South Vietnam.

For discouraged silver speculators who have suffered from months of low prices, there was an ounce or two of optimism yesterday when Handy Harman, the big silver refiner and fabricator, issued its latest annual silver review and forecast.

Your surprising, unsupported reference to New York State's sales tax as "particularly repressive" (editorial Jan. 23) flies in the face of considerable empirical evidence.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller forecast in his budget message today that the state would spend only $6.916-billion of the $7.127-billion approved last year in the budget for the current fiscal year. But much of the $211-million saving was more apparent than real.

A crowd of 200 turned out in nearzero weather last night to hear most of the speakers at a raucous public hearing in a Flushing synagogue protest the city's plan to build a new mid-Queens high school in the Powell's Cove area.

The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday a sweeping reorganization of its domestic banking structure along functional rather than geographic lines.

The three-way deal that sent Mike Walton from Toronto to Philadelphia to Boston marked the first time in National Hockey League history that a psychiatrist's report enabled an unhappy player to be traded.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The largest Federal survey of marijuana on American college campuses, made public today, showed that almost one-third of the students had tried marijuana and that one-seventh used it regularly.

HARTFORD, Feb. 1 -- On a recent afternoon in the ornate marble and granite Connecticut State Capitol, the business before the Senate was a resolution thanking the Wadsworth Anthenum -- the nation's oldest art museum here -- for a free lunch given to members of the General Assembly on opening day.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- The Soviet Union today formally opened a high-level business administration school to train Soviet industrialists in the modern management techniques of the computer age.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- When President Nixon asked Congress, a year ago, to provide $1.5 billion in emergency assistance for desegregating some schools and easing racial isolation in others, the idea might have seemed simple. Federal financial assistance would play carrot to the stick of court orders in eliminating Southern dual school systems.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The following is an excerpt from the forthcoming worst seller, "How to Fail in Business, Government and Practically Everything Else Despite a Heroic Struggle." It is by the distinguished American failure, John Fluppel.

A first prize of $50,000 will be the incentive in the final match of the $1-million World Championship of Tennis, officials of World Championship Tennis announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Nixon Administration set a new target today for the nation's economy: a decline in unemployment to about 4.5 per cent and in the rate of inflation to about 3 per cent by mid-1972.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 1 -- Faced with a $19.2-million deficit this year, Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso announced today that he would attempt to obtain "a fair share" of the tolls collected by the state on parkways in the count.
The countup is on at St. John's and it goes like this . . . 996 . . . 997. . . 998. . . 999. . . 1,000.

NEWARK, Feb. 1 -- Six members of the Paterson, N. J., Police Department were found not guilty today of Federal charges of conspiring to violate the civil rights of black residents and businessmen during racial disturbances in July, 1968.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Federal antipoverty officials insisted today that, contrary to a statement by Gov. Ronald Reagan of California, their new six-month grant to a controversial legal services program "is not a phase-out or a transition grant."

CLEVELAND, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Cleveland Cavaliers traded McCoy McLemore to the Milwaukee Bucks today in exchange for Gary Freeman plus Milwaukee's second college draft choice this year and an undisclosed amount of cash.
Tobias Clarke, assistant treasurer of the London office of the Bankers Trust Company, married in London Thursday Miss Charlotte Walter, whose ancestors founded The Times of London two centuries ago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Council of Economic Advisers formally took note of its 25th birthday today with an unyouthfully modest claim concerning the achievements of its lifetime.
A one-day boycott to protest overcrowding kept most students out of De Witt Clinton High School in the Bronx yesterday.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., announced yesterday that its 1970 earnings were $208-million, or $2.80 a share, in United States dollars. The Inco statement made no mention of the fact, but this was a record profit by a considerable margin.
"Man of La Mancha," now in its sixth year of existence, will move from its Broadway home at the Martin Beck Theater to the Eden Theater at Second Avenue and 12th Street on March 2.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Council of Economic Advisers published today two new measures of the United States balance of international payments. It said both were under consideration as improvements over the two measures now used, which are widely regarded as unsatisfactory.
The city came up with a tentative set of figures yesterday to show that taxable real estate values here have soared nearly $2-billion over last year's final total.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- The Agriculture Department announced today that 22 commodity brokers who admitted violating Federal regulations on trading in pork belly futures have agreed not to engage in such practices again.

Black children are being destroyed by heroin in Harlem and across the country, while the nation flutters about surburban kids dropping acid and smoking pot. The Horse has ravaged our communities for decades, but no one would hear our cries of anguish.

The President's Council of Economic Advisers forecasts a tremendous increase in national output for 1971, with gross national product averaging $1,065 billion -- some $15 billion to $20 billion higher than most private economists are predicting, as the Council itself concedes.
STANTON, Del., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Sunday racing and a split meeting at Delaware Park were approved unanimously today by the Delaware Racing Commission.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Evonne Goolagong, Australia's 19-year-old tennis sensation, upset Mrs. Margaret Smith Court, the world's leading woman player, today in the final of the Victorian championships.

HOUSTON, Feb. 1 -- The astronauts of Apollo 14 are prepared to take a "space walk," if necessary, to rejoin their mother craft after lifting off from the moon next Saturday, it was reported here today.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Wildcat Country tired in the stretch at Pimlico today but won the $6,500 allowance feature for 3-year-olds at six furlongs.

VIENTIANE, Feb. 1 -- Authortative Laotian military sources said today that Laotian rightist generals had a secret agreement with the South Vietnamese that would permit South Vietnamese troops to cross into southern Laos in division strength if Saigon considered it necessary.

YONKERS, Feb. 1 -- Coffee Solicitor, a brown colt by Coffee Break out of the prolific brood mare Solicitor's Queen, is regarded as a dark horse in the Hopeful Pacing Series, which will start Wednesday night at Yonkers Raceway.
MADRID, Feb. 1 -- The police arrested five prominent

BRASILIA, Feb. 1 -- Eleven days ago a 15-year-old Brazilian girl watched her prominent father, his head covered by a black hood, led from their home by unidentified Government security agents. The next day she was hooded and taken with her mother to an army police barracks in Rio de Janeiro.

The concept behind modern public broadcasting is that the network shouldn't be merely a parochial showcase for the likes, say, of Channel 13 in New York. Ideally, the service should be a collective agency for TV deserving of national distribution, a two-way network enabling a set owner to learn about people, problems and pledges of other sections of the country besides his own.

DURHAM, N. C., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Gary Melchionni hit six consecutive free throws in a seemingly endless Duke parade to the foul line tonight to pace the Blue Devils to an 82-71 upset victory over South Carolina.

The Episcopal Church in the United States urged the General Motors Corporation yesterday to cease manufacturing in South Africa and said it would offer a resolution on the matter at the company's annual stockholders' meeting.
RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., Feb. 1 -- Howard J. Samuels said today that the bill that created offtrack betting in New York "was hastily drawn up and is in obvious need of revision."

COOKE CITY, Mont., Feb. 1 -- Raging winds turned a 54-mile snowmobile trip into the spectacular Bear Tooth country just northeast of Yellowstone National Park into a winter survival test that cost the life of the president of the Ninth Federal Reserve District in Minneapolis.
MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin called on Israel today to take "concrete peaceful actions" toi avoid worsening the Middle East situation, which he said was now at a critical juncture.

MIAMI, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Manuel Ycaza, severely injured 12 months ago in a fall at Hialeah Park, returned to the winner's circle at the same track today with a victory aboard Delta Traffic in the fourth race.

The daring decision has been made to try to have Apollo 14 carry out its full scheduled program of lunar exploration. Whatever the cause of the difficulties in the five unsuccessful docking efforts Sunday night, the sixth attempt was successful and the astronauts' subsequent examination of the mechanisms involved revealed nothing wrong, nor any reason to suppose that there will be a malfunction when the next crucial docking maneuver is scheduled to take place.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange posted their third straight advance yesterday in active trading.

The Amerada Hess Corporation reported yesterday consolidated net income of $114,009,829, or $3.22 a share. In 1969 the net was $84,655,776, or $2.36 a share after deducting an extraordinary charge of $1,820,000, or 5 cents a share.

Dorothy Vislocky is interested in clutter. She incorporates it into her dances and even passed some empty cartons out among the audience at her concert Sunday afternoon at Kaufmann Concert Hall of the Young Mens' and Young Womens' Hebrew Association, Lexing Avenue and 92d Street.

The Federal Reserve System should expand the nation's money supply this year at an annual rate of at least 6 per cent if the economy is to achieve the 9 per cent rate of growth in total output projected by the Nixon Administration, the President's chief economic adviser said here yesterday.
Mayor Lindsay toured the Tombs yesterday and talked with prisoners, including four under indictment for their participation in last October's prison riot.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Six Latin - American delegations walked out of a conference of foreign ministers of the Organization of American States here today in protest against what they described as an inadequate draft convention to prevent the kidnapping of diplomats and political terrorism in the Western Hemisphere.

TRENTON, Feb. 1 -- A sweeping liberalization of New Jersey's divorce law -- including a provision to eliminate the requirement of finding fault with a spouse in some cases -- won initial legislative approval tonight in the Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The little - known, multi - million dollar business dealings of the United Mine Workers of America and the union's even wealthier subsidiaries -- the U.M.W. Welfare and Retirement Fund, Inc., and the National Bank of Washington -- began to unfold publicly today for the first time.
Yves Saint Laurent, the darling of the Paris couture for almost 10 years, has just received a drubbing from store buyers, manufacturers and most of the fashion press.
BUFFALO, Feb. -- With the national championships behind them, the best of the figure skaters left today to prepare for the North American championships.

NEWARK, Feb. 1 -- For the second time in less than a year, teachers in the public schools went on strike here today. The strike, by the Newark Teachers Union, reduced teaching staffs and student attendance in the city's schools by about 50 per cent.

Senator Jacob K. Javits warned yesterday that plans of the new Marxist Chilean Government for "discriminatory" expropriation of American companies would harm Chile's economy and "scare off" needed development investment elsewhere in Latin America.

In the regular election for Baseball's Hall of Fame no one made it, which is underdoing it. In the special election by the veterans' committee the day before yesterday, seven men made it, which is overdoing it.
Physicists from the University of California reported yesterday that they had discovered a rare and elusive nuclear particle within the atom.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- The Food and Drug Administration spurning an industry offer to pay the bill, announced today a six-month scientific study on alleged health hazards of detergent enzymes.
A wall that split the jazz world into two bitter factions in the nineteen-forties came tumbling down Sunday evening at the Overseas Press Club. 54 West 40th Street.
"I can't stand not to be busy," says Jerrold Ross, who took over the direction of Town Hall yesterday. The ways things look now, he is in no immediate danger of suffering from idleness.

ROCHESTER, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Brooks Robinson, the outstanding player of last year's World Series in the field and at bat, was named tonight as the winner of the 21st annual Hickok Professional-Athlete-of-the-Year Award.
Interest rates rose and bond prices declined yesterday as Wall Street began to worry that the Nixon Administration's plans for the economy and the Federal budget would be inflationary.

Having demonstrated to skeptics that they still possess in abundance the glittering talents that brought them to the National Basketball Association championship last season, the Knicks will try to keep their current winning surge alive tonight against the Cincinnati Royals at Madison Square Garden.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller sent to the Legislature today an $8.45-billion budget for the 1971-72 fiscal year, along with proposed tax rises of $1.1-billion -- the largest tax-increase request in the state's history.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz accused two of the country's leading soap and detergent producers yesterday of failing to obey a month-old state law requiring the labeling of the phosphate content of their products.
The New York City Commission on Human Rights has just concluded hearings on the Board of Education's hiring practices.

ATLANTA, Feb. 1 -- Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia appointed today a close political ally, David Henry Gambrell, the Democratic State Chairman, to fill out the unexpired Senate term of the late Richard B. Russell.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 1 -- The Justice Department has rejected a request from the Alabama Law Enforcement Planning Agency for Federal funds to set up a black-uniformed special night police detail designed to frighten criminals.

HOUSTON, Feb. 1 -- A sliver-thin, inch-long tube that doctors inserted by microsurgery into the left side of Capt. Alan B. Shepard Jr.'s head has enabled the 47-year-old Navy astronaut to come back from a grounded flight status to the command of Apollo 14 on its moon-landing mission.

KAMPALA, Uganda, Feb. 1 -- Maj. Gen. Idi Amin, Uganda's new military head of state, dismissed all mayors, district councilmen and other local officials today because of their identification with the Government that he toppled in a coup d'etat on Jan. 25.

The largest commercial bank in Philadelphia announced yesterday a cut in the interest rate it pays on passbook savings accounts to 4 per cent from 4 1/2 per cent, and at the same time the largest savings bank in that city disclosed that it had reduced from 6 per cent to 5 3/4 per cent the maximum rate that it pays on two year savings certificates.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- New York City was told by Governor Rockefeller today that no new state aid was available for the coming year beyond increases already mandated.
A community school board meeting in Queens was broken up last night, and a board member reportedly knocked unconscious, during a heated discussion over a boycott of a South Jamaica school.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 1 -- The Common Market hardened its position tonight on a key British demand in the membership talks, but acted in such a way as to avoid an immediate crisis.

The Metropolitan New York Retail Merchants Association, made up of the city's leading department stores, plans to urge all state legislation from here to vote against Governor Rockefeller's proposed increase in the state sales tax.

A spokesman for the teamsters union here said yesterday that the ideas being discussed in the Lindsay administration to close some major streets to weekday traffic would raise "horrible complications" for truck drivers and could increase shipping costs of merchandise by 50 per cent.

TRENTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The New Jersey Assembly today authorized an investigation of the possibility that the names of fictitious and dead persons appeared on petitions seeking to recall Mayor Thomas J. Whelan of Jersey City.

The American Cyanamid Corporation announced yesterday that it had started legal proceedings in Federal District Court here against Goldman, Sachs Co. and Sidney J. Weinberg Jr., one of the partners in this investment banking firm, seeking $120-million in damages.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- A white teacher was shot to ideath in the back of the neck today by an eighth grader he had suspended for cursing in the hallway of a junior high school, the police said.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -Treasury bill rates, continuing their decline at today's auction receded last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

More than 100 lithographs, wood engravings and other prints collected by Vincent van Gogh and used in his studio as source material for his paintings went on exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum yesterday, preceding an exhibition of his paintings and drawings that opens Feb. 14.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 1 -- Gen. Thongphan Knoksy, a Laotian military spokesman, reiterated today that Laos would be opposed to any military incursion by South Vietnamese troops.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Waiter W. Heller, the economist who was an adviser to Presidents Johnson and Kennedy, commended today President Nixon's new approach to solving the nation's economic problems but said that it did not go far enough.

WASHINGTON -- Not all Congressmen's wives in Washington play tennis, wear miniskirts to the White House, and sail from party to party, beaming and gracious, on the arms of their husbands.

CHICAGO -- At 7:30 Friday evening at the Conrad Hilton Hotel here, participants in the 59th annual convention of the College Art Association faced a choice of entertainments -- an official banquet (9.75 a head, drinks not included), or a competing caucus (free, no food), organized by members of the New Art Association, a group of younger dissidents critical of the parent body.

You don't have to be a flutist to have liked Jean-Pierre Rampal's flute recital at Philharmonic Hall Sunday night. As usual, the Frenchman played his instrument to a final trill and turn: musically, smoothly and with astonishing ease of delivery.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- There is an old rule of politics that you should never give your opponent a clear and easy target to shoot at, but President Nixon seems to be hoisting a new one every other day.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- A student rights group that has been attempting to weld the campuses of the huge State University into a sizable power bloc filed its first lawsuit today, demanding greater due-process protection in student disciplinary procedures.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Representative Herman Badillo of New York, the first Puerto Rican to be a voting member of the House, appeared to have gained support today in his efforts to change his assignment from the Agriculture Committee to a committee dealing with urban problems.

HARRISBURG, Feb. 2 -- Gov. Milton J. Shapp proposed today Pennsylvania's first state personal income tax, a 5 per cent levy retroactive to Jan. 1, to raise $1.5-billion through the next fiscal year and avert "bankruptcy."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 --The health care proposals that the Administration will send to Congress later this month will include both a cut in Medicare hospital benefits and a rise in payments by the 20 million Americans in the insurance program.
The International Playtex Corporation and Young Rubicam yesterday mutually announced the termination of a 10-year relationship.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 2 -- Secretary General Thant appealed to the United Arab Republic, Jordan and Israel today to continue their indirect peace talks under Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, his special representative, and to "withhold fire" and" exercise military restraint."
The Police Department announced yesterday the consolidation and expansion of its warrant squads to halt the practice that has long permitted hundreds of defendants each week to escape prosecution.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 -- Frank L. Rizzo, Philadelphia's police commissioner, resigned today to run for mayor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The most intensive Congressional review of the military draft since World War II began today with the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, John C. Stennis, expressing renewed skepticism that the Nixon Administration could meet its goal of ending draft calls by the middle of 1973.

HOUSTON, Wednesday, Feb. 3 -- The Apollo 14 astronauts coasted closer to the moon today, quietly relaxing aboard a spacecraft pronounced sound for the nation's third manned lunar landing early Friday. Their aim was only a few miles off target. But that could be corrected, if necessary, with another firing of the spacecraft's main rocket.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 2 (AP) -- John Mackey, tight end of the world champion Baltimore Colts, is expected to testify next Monday when a Federal grand jury resumes its investigation of National Football League operations, Federal sources said today.

Paul Plumadore's innate sense of ritual and feel for the theater results in his producing dance ceremonies of mysterious and glamorous interest. "Circa" (a journey) is his most recent work and was danced for the first time by his company Monday evening at the Cubiculo.

NEAK LEUNG, Cambodia, Feb. 2 (Reuters) -- Senior Cambodian offices said today that the Vietcong were returning to sanctuaries cleared by South Vietnamese and United States troops last summer and building new ones opposite South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- New corporate securities offered for cash sale nationwide reached a record $39-billion last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.

New Yorkers have access to a great deal of fine music in local churches, but one series of concerts has turned up this season that is distinctive. This is the one sponsored by the Central Presbyterian Church at Park Avenue and 64th Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The United States Postal Service announced today proposed new rates that would substantially increase the cost of mailing letters, postcards, commercial mail, books and especially newspapers and magazines.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 2 -- Negotiations between international oil companies and the Persian Gulf producing states collapsed tonight, raising the threat of a cutoff of Western oil supplies.
Trading volume on the New York Stock exchange soared to a record yesterday in a highly selective market.
BROOKVILLE, L. I., Feb. 2 -- Linda Mae Jarrigan, a 19-year-old sophomore of C.W. Post College, was found dead today in a wooded area of the 350-acre campus.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 2 -- John Brisker, the American Basketball Association's No. 2 scorer, led the Pittsburgh Condors to a 119-111 victory over the Nets in the second game of a double-header tonight.
