One candidate for the Democratic nomination for President in 1972 and two potential candidates are scheduled to appear tomorrow at a dinner of the New York City Democratic Committee. County committees of the party give dinners from time to time, but this will be the first dinner of the city committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie introduced today a water pollution control bill that would authorize a five-year, $25-billion program for sewage plant construction, with the Federal Government paying half the cost and the states and cities the other half.
The Jan. 16 Op-Ed article by J. C. Thomson Jr. proposes an open admission of American defeat in Vietnam followed by a precipitate withdrawal.

A police undercover agent who infiltrated the Black Panther party and supplied evidence used to indict 13 members for an alleged bombing conspiracy testified yesterday that he was a member of the party before any of the defendants were.

CAIRO, Wednesday, Feb. 3 -- With the cease-fire along the Suez Canal nearing its scheduled end, President Anwar el-Sadat conferred yesterday with the handful of top Egyptian officials forming the country's National Defense Council to decide whether to agree to another extension of the truce with Israel.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 2 (UPI) -The number of persons called in an attempt to get a jury for the murder-conspiracy trial of Bobby G. Seale and Ericka Huggins reached 1,000 today.

A special election next Tuesday in Brooklyn will show whether William J. Giordano made the right decision in resigning an Assembly seat, to which he was elected three times to run for the State Senate seat left vacant by the death of William J. Ferrall.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 2 (Agence France-Presse) -The Central Committee of the governing Workers party has called on the nation's armed forces and people to make new efforts "for ultimate victory and the progress of socialism in North Vietnam."
VIENTIANE, Laos, Wednesday, Feb. 3 -- Defense Minister Sisouk na Champassak announced today what appeared to be the beginning of a major North Vietnamese offensive in northern Laos.
The New York Mets took a double-header of sorts yesterday when they signed Tom Seaver and Jerry Koosman, the best and most expensive young pitchers in the nine-year history of the franchise.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The proposal for a National Advertising Review Board was commended today by the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission who said it "holds great promise for effective action."

BRUSSELS, Feb. 12 -- Britain's chief Common Market negotiator served notice today that his Government would break off the membership talks if the six market countries insisted on demanding "the painful initiation of a new entrant to a secret society."

TOKYO, Feb. 2 -- The oft-rumored invasion of Laos by South Vietnamese troops has begun, the Kyodo news agency reported today in a dispatch from its Saigon correspondent. Though all major Japanese newspapers here have correspondents in Saigon, none of them matched the Kyodo report.
Prices of wheat, corn and soybean futures moved upward together yesterday.

When life was simple in the old days, the sporting life also was simple. But when it grew complicated, those complexities spilled over in tumbling fashion to engulf the entire sphere of athletics, professional and amateur, and that vast murky shadowland in between.

KAMPALA, Feb. 2 -- General Amin today appointed a Council of Ministers made up almost entirely of civilians, half of them civil servants from the old Government.
CAPETOWN, Feb. 2, (Reuters) -- The Government introduced a bill today that would tighten already rigid censorship laws.

BERLIN, Feb. 2 -- Annoyed over East German harassment of Berlin traffic last week, the political counselors of the three Western allies called off a meeting scheduled for today with a Soviet representative.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- A group of Democratic legislators and spokesmen for the State League of Women Voters and the Citizens Union opened an attack today on plans by Republican legislative leaders to put off the scheduled June primary election until September.

PORTLAND, Oreg., Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Portland Trail Blazers, after taking a 17-point lead, was forced to rally in the last four minutes tonight to upset the Milwaukee Bucks, 123-111, in a National Basketball Association game despite a 38-point performance by the Bucks' Lew Alcindor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Nixon asked Congress today to give the Civil Service Commission wider authority to hire, discharge, promote and shift senior civil service employes who are now virtually locked into their present jobs.

The Signal Companies, Inc., plans write-offs and write-downs approximating $57-million against 1970 operations, which will result in a "sizable loss" for the year, the board of directors said in a letter to stockholders yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Feb. 2 -- Israel responded promptly today to Secretary General Thant's appeal for continued quiet along her cease-fire lines with Egypt and Jordan and pledged to observe the truce as long as the Arabs did not shoot.
George Plimpton is a reasonably engaging exhibitionist with a Social Register accent so there is little likelihood that he will stop making a trade of working out at other people's professions.

It seems rather difficult to understand the logic of your Jan. 24 editorial "Securing Middle East Borders." You are definitely right in stating that "it is essential that a Middle East settlement be reinforced with effective international guarantees," but does not this right approach underwrite the Israeli attitude that the first and elementary necessity is to arrive at such a settlement, including secure and mutually recognized borders?

ATLANTA, Feb, 2 -- Nearly 40 years ago an infant wandered away from his nurse-maid and fell into the fish pond outside the Governor's mansion a few blocks from his home here. The story goes that the Governor himself rushed outside and plucked the squalling toddler from the water. The child's name was David Henry Gambrell.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 2 (UPI)--Jerry Lambert, who achieved his greatest fame riding Native Diver, was named the winner today of the 1971 George Woolf Memorial Jockey Award as the rider whose career reflected the greatest credit to himself and his profession.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 2 (AP) -- A convoy of 34 trucks, each loaded with 2,000 gallons of gasoline, drove into Pnompenh today from the port of Kompong Som, the first to reach the capital over Route 4 in more than two months.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Assemblyman Samuel D. Wright said today that state funds to run a special $2.6-million education program in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville section of Brooklyn had virtually run out and that more than 800 people who worked in it would lose their jobs if the program was terminated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Manufacturers' inventories declined by more than $300-million in December and, in an encouraging sign for 1971, the key ratio of inventories to sales fell significantly, the Commerce Department reported today.
BOSTON, Feb. 2 (AP)--Bill Elias the former Navy coach who has been on the Boston Patriots' staff for two seasons, resigned as defensive coordinator to accept an administrative position with the team.
The second annual Pee Wee Russell Memorial Stomp, held in memory of the late jazz clarinetist, will take place on Sunday, Feb. 14, at 3 P.M. at the Martinsville Inn. Martinsville, N. J.
Negotiations on major contract issues between the city and the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association are scheduled to resume today.
Les Wallack, the Rutgers track coach suspended six weeks ago for having instigated a racial conflict with a letter to the student newspaper, was reinstated by the university yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Several times American field commanders and rear-echelon planners have unsuccessfully requested authority to mount a ground thrust into Laos to cut the Ho Chi Minh Trail.

For several days the combination of extremely cold weather and lack of reserve generating capacity -- resulting from the long shutdowns of "Big Allis" and Indian Point No. 1 generators -- had repeatedly forced voltage reductions and appeals for cuts in electricity use.

The Duquesne Light Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the fourth quarter and for 1970.

HARTFORD -- The first thing to be said about "A Gun Play," which is having its world premiere engagement at the Hartford Stage Company, is that its author, Yale M. Udoff, is a discovery.

Two Federal judges in separate cases have ruled that unauthorized wiretapping of radical groups by the Government is unconstitutional. This judicial challenge of the Justice Department's enthusiasm for electronic surveillance represents a significant victory for the liberty of all Americans irrespective of political persuasion.

Prices were irregular yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in active trading. The market opened stronger, drifted downward but closed with a small rally. The exchange index closed at 24.53, up 0.02.

STOCKPORT, N. Y., Feb. 3 -Seven members of one family died in a fire late last night in this town north of the city of Hudson, on the Hudson River. Two others in the family survived the fire.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -An official of the United Mine Workers of America in the mountain coal fields of southwestern Virginia was indicted here today on eight counts of embezzling union funds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Leaders of the airline industry asked Congress today for virtually unregulated authority to raise their passenger fares, but got a distinctly cool hearing before the Senate Commerce Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The new public interest lobby called Common Cause comes up for its first real test of political impact tomorrow when House Democrats vote to retain or dismiss a senior committee chairman.
The Sony Corporation feels certain it has scored a major breakthrough with a new low-cost, single-tube color television camera it has developed.

The BankAmerica Corporation announced yesterday the formation of a venture capital management partnership that will invest $18-million in United States and Western European companies undergoing "a very strong growth phase."

HONG KONG -- When Chi Cheng, Taiwan's 26-year-old track star, announced in December that she was planning to be married to Vincent Reel, her American coach, she met with opposition from her Chinese parents. LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 -- Recycling is becoming almost as popular as cycling. But it continues to be a far more frustrating exercise.

Profits in manufacturing sagged during the final three months of 1970, the First National City Bank reported yesterday. But, leaving aside the impact of the strike at General Motors, the decline was not so great as earlier in the year.

Johnson Johnson announced yesterday that Richard B. Sellars, president of Johnson Johnson Worldwide, has been elected chairman of the executive committee. He succeeds Gustav O. Five years after book sales in America reached the $2-billion mark and publishing became big business, the industry is facing a time of trouble and soul-searching even though more books are being bought than ever before.

AUBURN, N. J. -- For 26-year-old Helen Jackson, a willowy, caramel-colored woman with an Afro hairdo, this was a weekend of "firsts." She took her first plane trip from Kennedy Airport to Syracuse, 30 miles north of this snow-bound community. She paid her first visit to northern New York State. And for the first time she went to the Auburn Correctional Facility to visit her husband, number 60584.

Parents of Intermediate School 142 in South Jamaica, Queens, where a boycott has been under way since November, agreed yesterday to consider inviting mediators to settle their dispute with the local school board. The agreement came after a meeting with Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, Chancellor of the city's schools.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- A group of 10 influential Senators led by Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, introduced a resolution in the Senate today urging the United States to drop its opposition to Communist China's admission to the United Nations.

CONAKRY, Guinea, Feb. 2 -- During a week's visit this correspondent saw the bodies of four former Government officials hanging from a bridge over a main street in this West African capital. Informed sources said four others bad been executed in various upcountry towns.

The liberal Democrats in the House of Representatives have been faring well at the hands of the leadership, but badly in the secret votes of the caucus. This discrepancy occurs partly because conservative Southerners who rarely support the national party are relatively numerous in the House, but the leadership realistically recognizes that the Northern and Western liberals come from the states where Presidential elections are won or lost.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Producers of specialty steel products and their counterparts in the United Steelworkers Union began a major campaign today to limit rapidly rising imports.

Karl Douglas of Texas A. and I. is the latest in a long line of candidates who aspired to become the first successful black quarterback in pro football. Douglas was a third-round draft choice of the Baltimore Colts last week.

The Boise Cascade Corporation, producers of building materials and paper products, had a decline of 52 per cent in 1970 earnings. R. V. Hansberger, president, reported yesterday. Stock of the company reacted to the news with a decline of 1 1/2 points to 46 3/4 on the New York Stock Exchange.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 4 -- Premier Souvanna Phouma said today he would protest to Britain and the Soviet Union, cochairmen of the Geneva Conference of 1962, over what he termed a new offensive launched this week in northern Laos by North Vietnamese and Communist - led Pathet Lao troops.

A truce at least until Tuesday was arranged in State Supreme Court yesterday between the A. P. food store chain and a group of clergymen who have intermittently occupied the company's executive offices since last Tuesday in a protest against alleged racial discrimination.

Merck Co., Inc., a leading ethical drug concern producing both bulk and packaged fine and medicinal chemicals, achieved record sales and earnings in the fourth quarter and for 1970, Henry W. Gadsden, president, reported yesterday.

The Public Serivce Commission called on the state's seven major electric utility companies yesterday to report by March 1 on their plans for reducing electric loads in crises -- and on the effect such moves have on consumers.
Automobile insurance rates will go up sharply throughout New York State in the next few months. Many car owners have already received bills for higher premiums.

The president of the Association of Process Servers in New York was found guilty in Federal District Court yesterday of signing affidavits that he had served summonses that were never served.

And to that I offer the testimony of Thomas Byrnes, famous nineteenth-century head of the New York cops, one of the first to publish photographs with dossiers -- of what must have been some of his favorite crooks and methods.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, its once acclaimed trans-Atlantic industrial marriage with Rolls-Royce suddenly torn asunder in London, said yesterday it would explore the possibility of buying a United States-built engine for its Tristar jetliner.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 4 -- More than 60 people were arrested here in the last 24 hours after a new wave of violence erupted.
Dr. W. J. Cook's world-record 14 - pound - 8 - ounce eastern brook trout still retains the title it earned when he caught it in Ontario's Nipigon River in 1916.
GRENADA, Miss., Feb. 4 (AP) -- A tornado ripped apart a house trailer today and killed seven persons, including the wife and three children of a Grenada policeman.
The bizarre contradictions that indicate the depth of social unrest in this country were never more apparent than in the recent New York police "job action."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4 -- As in every year of the Vietnam war, the abatement of the monsoon rains last fall brought a quickening of enemy activity along the spidery track network through Laos that is known as the Ho Chi Minh Trail.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 4 -- For the last three days Erik H. Erikson, the psychoanalyst, and Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther, have been engaged in lengthy discussions at Yale University.

Amid a large group of construction workers at the site of the city's new Police Headquarters, Mayor Lindsay donned a gold hard hat and affixed an American flag to a bucket of concrete yesterday to mark the topping-out of the 15-story, $57-million building at Park Row and Pearl Street.

DETROIT, Feb. 4 -- The New York Rangers scored only one goal against the Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League game tonight, but that was enough to win. The tally game at 3:47 of the second period and was made by Rod Gilbert, the flashy center.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The nation's railroads and two of the four unions that shut them down with a brief strike in December have reached a tentative contract agreement, a railroad spokesman announced today.

HOUSTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Dr. Gary Latham of Columbia University reported today that the crash of Apollo 14's S4B booster early today near the seismograph erected by Apollo 12 astronauts produced seismic waves that penetrated only 25 miles into the moon in the Ocean of Storms.

Rolls-Royce, the huge British aerospace company which also makes one of the world's finest automobiles, has gone into receivership and the British Government calls its demise "a major national tragedy." Rolls's failure resulted from soaring costs in the development of an engine for the American Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's Tristar jetliner, the L-1011.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The main issue in the latest allied offensive in Indochina is not the "news blackout" on military operations, but the policy question of why the South Vietnamese, with a million men under arms and an air force of over 600 planes, are still relying on massive U.S. air support to break up enemy troop concentrations and supplies.
Cosmos became the nickname yesterday for New York's entry in the North American Soccer League. The name was chosen from 3,000 entries filed in a contest conducted throughout the metropolitan area.

I think that Cardinal Cooke's case for state aid for nonpublic schools in his letter to Governor Rockefeller (news story Jan. 26) is ill-advised and that his assumption that such aid is constitutional as a result of various court decisions, whether or not the "Blaine Amendment" is repealed, is highly hypothetical.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 4 -- A blond, 3-year-old boy struggled in the arms of his natural mother here today as he cried, "I want to go to my mommy," and reached out his arms for the only "mother" he had known since birth.

NEWARK, Feb. 4 -- The Board of Education tonight awaited a reply form the Newark teachers' union to a revised contract package proposed by the Board that it hoped would lead to an early settlement of the teachers' strike.

Sun Ra and his Space Arkestra, those masters of musical mayhem, opened their contribution to the Metropolitan Museum of Art's "Composers in Performance" series on Tuesday night with a 15-minute blast compounded of instrumental shrieks and electronic blare that blew several subscribers to the series right out of Grace Raney Rogers Auditorium.

LONDON, Feb. 4 (UPI) -- A former United States astronaut, L. Gordon Cooper Jr., criticized today the selection of Capt. Alan B. Shepard Jr. as skipper of the Apollo 14 lunar mission, which some persons had thought Mr. Cooper would command.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the Ad Hoc Committee on Office Operations would be reactivated in an effort to keep close tabs on whatever paperwork problems arose from the tumultuous trading volume that invaded the stock market in recent weeks.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 4 (UPI) -- The police arrested an 18-year-old youth tonight in connection with a shooting in Pelham, N.Y., in which a 14-year-old student was wounded.

Aryeh Neier's Jan. 20 letter about the Supreme Court's decision on the James case calls for comment. The craze for electrically heated water beds, inspired less, perhaps, by their promise of a good night's rest than by their reputation for improving sexual relations, is about to be short-circuited.

A Yonkers liquor store owner and his family won the last of New York State's $250,000 lottery drawings yesterday with a ticket purchased for them by a friend who has demonstrated a knack for buying winning tickets.

PARIS -- The U.S. visit of Juan Carlos de Borbon, Prince of Asturias and designated next King of Spain, was a good idea in that it exposed Franco's political heir to a variety of opinions of a more liberal nature than he is likely to hear at home.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The president pro tempore of the Senate is, by definition, the patriarch of the chamber, its leading man in seniority and, usually, in age. As a consequence, he is also likely to be the quintessential old-line Senator: wise, calm, politic and unshakably conserv ative.

Braniff Airways, Inc., reported yesterday that it had a profitable fourth quarter in 1970, but that the loss for the full year had made it necessary to suspend cash dividends in order to conserve cash for future equipment purchases.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The United States command reported today that 29 Americans were killed in action in Vietnam last week, compared with 50 the week before, and that 15 others died of accidents and other nonhostile causes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4 -- Mayor Joseph L. Alioto said today that he would ask to be heard by a Federal grand jury in Seattle that reportedly is investigating his division of lawyer's fees with public officials in Washington State five years ago.

The late Ben B. Seligman has done very well with what may strike some people as a dreary project -- a narrative history of American business from colonial times to the present. William A. Maynard Jr., who was convicted last December of having killed a man in an argument on a Greenwich Village street, was sentenced yesterday to 10 to 20 years in prison.
HOUSTON, Friday, Feb. 5 -Two astronauts of Apollo 14 -the fifth and sixth human beings ever -- landed on the moon early this morning.
MUERREN, Switzerland, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Alpine women of France swept the first four places today in the Arlberg Kandahar World Cup special slalom.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The industrial nations of Western Europe, Canada and Japan added the massive sum of $10.8-billion to their holdings of foreign exchange, almost entirely dollars, last year, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

However, the bill may be more of a boondoggle than a solution.

The London stock market closed firmer in quiet trading yesterday. There was some bargain hunting but the market was short of sellers. The Rolls-Royce bankruptcy step remained a cautionary factor.
